content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Regret. Indecision. Joy. Sorrow. Indignation. Anger. Helplessness. To The Moon can and will unrelentingly tug at your heartstrings. It will bring you to the fullest extent of each and every single emotion listed, woven together by the most hauntingly beautiful piano music in the background.The graphics, though simple, will form images that will stay in your mind - and heart - for a very long time. The story seems simple but goes to so many complex details as the game unfolds them delicately, just at the right moments. I enjoyed every bit of it, from the tear-inducing plot (so much onions) to the little bits of comic banter, whether in exploring Johnny's world or playing the occasional mini-game.I must concede that the *only* flaw is that there's little replayability value; after all, it is a story-game. But what you get in the 4-5 hours of completing is a wonderful and emotional experience that forces you to look deep inside you. What do you want most in life? What would you pay for it? From thoughts on society and legal obligations, to forced self-reflection on your own goals and dreams, this game has it all.In summary, do I recommend it? I cannot assent more wholeheartedly - it's the first game that affected me so much that I actually just *had* to write this review. I had received this as part of a bundle; but on hindsight, I would have been willing to pay full price. You have to get it on sale, or grab whichever bundle it appears in. Because it's just that good. Add to cart, process, install and grab a good pair of headphones for an amazingly immersive experience.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												Don't judge a game by it's cover. Or in this case, it's engine. You might think that a game made in RPG Maker isn't worth your time. Well, in this case you're wrong. Or at least that depends what you're looking for.'To the Moon' does a lot of things right, but most important and memorable it its writing and atmosphere. Long story short, the game is about exploring a dying man's memories to grant him a final wish. What you get is an emotional ride with both ups and downs, mostly the latter. But the game is all about its story and it's perfectly executed.But if you're looking for an RPG, you're looking in the wrong place. The game has no sort of choice-and-consequence system, no fighting (except for one battle, but I won't spoil that!) or nothing that would make this rank as an RPG. The game will always be the same, so there's not much replay value to it.So if you're looking for a game with a great story to invest a few hours into, look no further. Freebird Games will prove to you that you don't need to be a AAA-studio to make an enjoyable and memorable gaming experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												To the Moon is one of the most touching games I've played in years. With such a wonderfully written storyline riddled with humerous and nostalgic references alike, TtM really shines with it's interpretation of memories. When I played the first few moments I expected an interesting Sci-Fi interpretation of how the mind works, which was delivered promptly, but I hadn't expected how utterly mind-blowing of a level it would reveal itself to land on. Flawlessly implementing emotional story-telling, point-and-click gameplay, and an ocean of character progression, TtM leaves you on the edge of your seat, yearning for the next act of the three installments. I haven't felt the pressure of tears behind my eyes as a result from a game since Kingdom Hearts and Shadow of the Colossus were released in 2002 and 2005 respectively. Had this game been released during my preadolescence, it would've been just as impacting on my development as those two games were. In all honesty, even at this stage of my life, I found this game to be rather impacting, as well as eye opening on many levels.To the Moon is a game I'd recommend for all ages, as a casual point-and-click story driven adventure RPG, it has so much to offer to every generation. Undoubtedly worth the extra 'dough' for the heart-string-pulling soundtrack as well, especially considering that 50% of the bandcamp proceeds go towards charities.10/10, will play again.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												To The Moon is simply one of the best story based games ive played in my entire life.A game that went under the radar for many people, developed by a small studio called Freebird Games, To The Moon is an incredible and heart breaking experience, as it will bring the manliest of men to there knees in tears.In short, its about 2 Doctors traveling through the memories of a dying man to fulfill his final wish, there isnt too much I can give away without ruining some part of the story, so hear this, play this game, buy it and play it, this game is simply incredible.This game was an emotional rollercoaster for me and many others who played this game, as you tie bits and pieces of the story together as you progress, you feel youself becoming weaker and more emotional as realisation sets in and you learn how sad the life of this old man really is.The game consists only of clicking around with your mouse, as there is no action, no fighting and no enemies to face, this may seem as a turn off for many, but in reality it is just a better way to immerse yourself in the game and its story, it simply couldnt be represented in a better way.From the outstanding soundtrack, spectacular story and the brilliant dialogue that this game delivers, its simply a masterpiece, and all that in around 3-4 hours of gameplay.9/10I can see why many people will and have enjoyed this game, but can also see why others may not.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
 To The Moon  is a truly beautiful game. It's very essence screams with emotion and you find yourself screaming with it. This game is the kind of game you sit down expecting to try for half an hour at 11:00 at night and find yourself still playing sometime the next morning. It's story proves engaging and litterally enthralls you as you become the game's minion. Entrusting you with simple tasks,  To The Moon  requires one to search in reverse chronological order small memories of a dying man in an attempt to convince a younger reflection of himself to follow a certain path in life, motivating him to fulfill his own death wish. As should be plain as daylight, untrained professionals such as us are provided with every opprotunity by Freebird Games to come in conact, learn about, and fall in love with the characters as we travel backwards through a man's most intimate and poignant moments of living. You spend hours caught up in this man's life, almost understanding him as well as he does himself, and that's where you find you've actually spent hours getting caught up in a magnificent and chancy trap: You slowly realize it as the story progresses, I will not reaveal it here, but you do inwardly question this dying man as you roam his thoughts. It even talks about a topic that is not quite well addressed in media and especially in games, and that is commendable in and of itself. Mental illnesses require the attention of close loved ones. This game explores the "whens" and "wheres" of unconditional love and just how significant it is in the lives of others. The entire time you are investing in a one-way friendship with this man, you are accompanied by a moving, extremely well crafted soundtrack he soundtrack is so fantastic it makes one wish they could either play, pick up again, or practice these songs on the piano. A mix between simplicity and complexity that complements the story line and the artstyle; everything comes together so thoroughly. If one were looking only for music, this game shines as brightly as any lighthouse. Now, in a sea of drama, the pair of scientists one guides through the memories provide comedic relief and this is where I could see where we lost a portion of the (at the time of writing) 440 out of 16010 people who did not recomend this game and that number could have been cut if there had been the following warning: the characters you play will bicker like siblings and they are present to cut tension. If they were not there, the story would be too heavy to handle. I enjoyed their presence and I laughed out loud a number of times as they allowed the developers over at Freebird to show their humor in a creative way. Actually, I find them reminiscent of certain characters Shakespeare would include in his works (i.e. the Porter in Macbeth) in order to plant some kind of restraint in an otherwise constant flow of deep and taxing storytelling. Please do not let yourself be unwilling to play this game because of them. My only personal complaint are the controls. I will say that this game is a point and click interactive story that one should use the arrow keys and enter/space bar for. I found the point and click clunky and not always accurate. I lost nothing in using the arrow keys, though, so it does work. Also, I found there to be too much delay in the memento puzzles for the amount of computing it should take. That did not detract much either as I was too busy figuring out moves anyway. That's it. The end of my complaints. "Use the arrow keys and I thought they could have cleaned up the programming for the puzzles. Otherwise, job well done. Fantastic story. Fantatstic sound track. Interesting art. 15571/16011 would play again." Thank you for your time.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												"I'm too manly for this." -Dr. Neil WattsI usually don't write reviews, but for this game I feel like I must. (Sorry for my English, not my main language)My story is that I was searching for games with easy 100% achievements (Yeah, I'm sort of an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥) and I found this game... Boy, what a game. It had almost everything: The visuals were appealing, the characters were pretty nice, and I got really interested in their stories, the story progression is fantastic, I literally didn't see some of the stuff coming, regarding the events that lead up to the ending which was a little bit predictable and the soundtrack is spot on. A little something that not everyone is a fan of has to be the lack of action; this is a "Point and Click" game, so it may not have the best gameplay in the world, heck, even I found it a little bit grindy or boring in the first half hour, but I'm getting used to that since I've been playing more games like that lately. But in my opinion, the things mentioned before makes up for it. The game is a little bit short, but the feels stay...In conclusion, I'd say this game is completely worth your money, and it's even better on a sale, it gets pretty well discounted. I rate it 5 jars of olives out of 5 jars of olives

content:
Posted: May 24, 2016
												To The Moon genuinely hits a high mark; It's truly got one of the most interesting stories that I've ever sat through in video games ever.You play as two doctors Eva and Watts who are traversing through the memories of a dying patient who's final wish is to go to the moon. I won't reveal any more to the plot because it's much better you sit through the events of the story yourself. It's tearjerking; everyone's review that says this truly means it. I didn't understand the story fully the first time mostly out of the fact that I didn't exactly understand the side-effects of some medical conditions mentioned throughout the game, Google anything you're unfamiliar with; it'll help you out, but after the 2nd time it finally made sense, and when you DO understand every piece of the story, it just hurts in a satisfying, remorseful way. There's no easy way to put it; if you don't feel ANYTHING at the end of the gorgeous ride the game takes you through, you're unbelievably heartless.If stories that certainly make you appreciate life and not take it for granted, and a hint of science fiction is your cup of tea, To The Moon does anything but disappoint. The piano-arranged soundtrack is stunning; I still find myself humming the themes 3-years later, the 16-bit graphics are nice, and the mini-puzzles inbetween are a lovely touch to keep you going. I'm super excited for Kan Gao's next installment to the series 'Finding Paradise' later this year, but for now I will continue to love this game to no end.Thanks, Kan.

Posted: August 23, 2013
												To the Moon is not really a game, but more like... interactive fiction. The two Docs are helping this old man who said he wanted to go to the moon, but he can't remember why. By going back in his memory and hopefully by stitching it back together in a certain way, they can reweave the memory to allow the mind to fill in the details, thus allowing the patient to die with a sense of fulfillment rather than regret. Except the Doctors have met their match... as there are some secrets that this man is hiding... and they must search through the catacombs of his memories to locate the clues... Don't let the cute 2D graphics that resemble Japanese console RPG turn you off. This game is MUCH deeper than that. They simply chose to spend the developement time on the story rather than hiring artists to do bazillion illustrations. At its heart, its a love story, about broken promises, unfilfilled wishes and potentials, and about taking chances, and how one encounter can change a life. It is a short game, and you should have no problem finishing it in a few hours. And you may be shedding a few tears at the end.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												To The Moon was a heartbreaking game to see through to the end; and contrary to how that statement immediately comes across, I am not referring in any way to the emotion of the story.To The Moon is a Point & Click, narrative driven adventure game where you delve through the memories of a dying man to make his final wish come true. As far as the story goes that’s is all I will say because this games story is an absolute masterpiece to behold for any first time players. However, the way the story plays out is what has me so heartbroken about this title.I had this game in my library for at least a year before I ever even booted it up, and even after first starting I really didn't get sucked in. If anything I was lost and uninterested. It may take you a few hours but please, I beg of you, pick this game up and truly see it through until the end. It is hard to get into, I know. The first 30-45 minutes are pretty convoluted and bland, but I think everyone should experience the beauty of the narrative that forms by the end of the game. To The Moon may be short and lack in any replayability, but it is a masterpiece in its own right and deserves your attention.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												This game deserves nothing below a 9, that's the lowest that you can go for a game like this. This game is so well formed, the plot, the characters, how they develop and connect. Given the aesthetic setting, you might assume it's a silly indie game or something that might touch upon deeper emotions and matters without actually going the whole way, deeper and exploring the story completely. However the writers for this game clearly worked very hard on this, with so many connections that it's only up the the player's intellect to actually connect them and evaluate them on a personal level. This game does not force you to do anything, it plays smoothly without anything for the player to worry about missing. Just playthrough and enjoy the game. And if you've paid enough attention, then deeper meaning will be revealed and the greater your appreciation will be for the writing. The game has a few interesting and entertaining moments of comic relief (and believe me, you will need them) and fun cultural references. The timing, presentation and music really manage to hit the right chords.This is a genuinely good game, suitable for everyone to enjoy. Each person will have a slightly different experience but even if you've understood the absolute minimum, it's still a grand game worth remembering when comparing to other future contenders who dare set foot in this very challenging genre.

												If you're looking for a really nice story and are fond of RPGs, you can't go wrong with To The Moon. At a glance, it seems like any old RPG which attempts to fabricate emotion and heart. Yet, To The Moon is without a doubt so much more. A true masterpiece, in my opinion; for it succeeds in using gaming not as a means of the mindless, repetive experiences we all know and love but instead a medium to portray a story. A beautiful one, at that.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Only minor technical issues. Lowres assets (640x480), main menu cursor hover detection is bit wonky, no windowed fullscreen (makes writing a review difficult when each alt-tab takes a couple of seconds), Options menu with F1 - had to figure that out. Sometimes the music is freaking loud compared to the sound effects. Taking screenshots difficult, because no Steam Overlay. External tool gives mostly white frame, needs cutting.Minor tedium sometimes in that you can't click-hold to move, combined with the fact that while left and right image edge is sharp, top and bottom are faded out.Had a little difficulty in one glitchy scene figuring out what to do (had to consult the forums). Might just have been the reloading that eventually made it work; not sure.Unskippable launch sequence, but in this game I can understand it's intended to quickly get you back into the mood of the game. And the game is short enough that this won't be a bother.The frequently reoccuring minigame introduces a little change to the gameplay, probably made to give some more interaction, even if it's a cheap trick for gving a rewarding feeling when the story itself isn't sufficient. (It would have been though. And finding the pieces for the memento is no challenge anyway.)It's OK though. You're basically executing the protagonists' job, and that's not just all-awesome, but also involves routine. This makes the experience more immersive.At first, I was worried the RPG-Makeresque character art style would interfere with the serious style of the story, but that turned out to be no problem. Didn't even need getting used to. (Probably because the character art style is consistently the same throughout the game.)The story has depth and several more and less philosophical aspects worthy of pondering on. Generally not an entirely original theme, but unique in detail. I actually find the writing quite mature and natural. Whatever people complain about in reviews regarding the writing, it must be specifically personal distaste.There might be details to the story though that are worth examining for plot holes. And there's a certain more or less surprising twist that was almost ignored by the story progression, which left me a little confused.If you appreciate beautiful and touching as well as skillful storytelling and would like to experience it with minimal energy investment needed (I myself wasn't very motivated or energetic when playing it, but I'm usually quite thoughtful), then it's definitely a recommendation. Better than watching it as a four-hours movie would have been. In game format, you can occasionally drift off into your own thoughts without freezing the pace, and dialogue speed is in your control, too. So a game is a nice format for this kind of story.The mini-episode DLCs are as thoughtful and entertaining as the main story.P.S.: This game is unsatisfying for achievement-hunters, yet very satisfying for completionists. ;-)UPDATE: After seeing a screenshot on the shop page that I didn't encounter during my playthrough, I realize I should probably try a second one with choosing the other character of the duo. It's a nice touch that you can give at least parts of the playthrough a somewhat more drama or comedy spin based on choices you make. It's not fully linear.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												To be clear, this game has a pretty small amount of classic gameplay. You explore and experience a story. It's not walking-simulator tier, but it's entirely focused on the story it wishes to tell, rather than the gameplay aspect.However, the story itself is awesome. Such a great way to spend around four hours. Few places can you get such a concise and well delivered story, with a strong soundtrack to back its heart. You will find yourself able to recall songs in the soundtrack even after only playing for around four hours, that's a very good thing. Memorable and enjoyable soundtracks are something I love in games.Extremely well worth the money. This gives you so much more than watching a great movie, while costing a fraction of the price. Characters are well developed and each have their own personality that are enjoyable to watch. I'm pre-emptively trying to find the sequel that has just been announced so I can wishlist it. There's an overarching storyline that connects the two main scientists to the next game, as they work on multiple "patients", this game covers a single patient's story. So in future sequels, we'll get to see a continuation of the development of these characters. I just love that! You don't see direct connections like that often.Only gripes are that the sprite grid is a bit too large, like your position is very here-or-there, you can't always position yourself exactly where you want to be easily. Also, in a couple of places I have to switch from using a controller to a mouse because the controller wasn't able to do what I was required to do. Should support all control schemes (especially in simple setups.)Definitely recommended. A character-focused adventure that just about anyone can relate to and enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												It's hard to describe how much I love To the Moon. I say love, and not "loved" because it's one of those games that will stick with me forever. I've never experienced a game that made me feel so sentimental. While it doesn't have much as far as gameplay is concerned, To the Moon more than makes up for it in its intriguing and heartfelt narrative. It intertwines humor and heartfelt drama under a veil of mystery--keeping the player hooked from start to finish. I'm amazed at what this game achieves. If you're looking for in-depth gameplay and top-notch graphics then this probably isn't what you're looking for. However, if you enjoy great storytelling, character development and a soundtrack worth buying and listening to hours after the game ends, then you've come to the right place. Though it's rather short, I loved every second of it and still do not regret spending the money on it. This is the only game I've played on Steam I would urge buying at full price. This is because the creator needs money to support his art of game-making, and seriously, the guy is good.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
												Do not mistake this for a game. It isn't. The elements that have pretensions to being gameplay are linear in the extreme, and very simple to "solve".Do not mistake the lack of gameplay for a lack of merit. To The Moon is an excellent work, which I wholeheartedly recommend. The particulars might not fall into everyone's tastes, but the concept and execution are sufficiently good that it at least deserves a try.Still. There are a few notable flaws. Firstly, the pretensions to gameplay can be mildly distracting, more so the less adept one is at solving the minor puzzles. Secondly, certain parts of the dialogue are highly - and needlessly - intertextually referential, despite this intertextuality having almost no real merit for the larger narrative. Thirdly, the basic point-and-click system used for most of the game is clunky, and may disrupt the pacing of the narrative.A sincere recommendation of an excellent - but not masterful - work.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												What do you do when you want to tell an immersive story via the medium of computer games, but you don't know how to program?Kan Gao decided that that was no problem at all and just used RPGMaker. That explains the retro JRPG look of "To the Moon", which (WARNING!) is not actually a game. It's really more of an interactive story (and a rather short one at that, with 3 - 5 hours of play time)."To the Moon" is set 20 minutes into the future where it is possible to change dying people's memories so that they can make the things "happen" that they wish they had done in their lifetime.The technicians Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts make these wishes come true. Their latest client, Johnny, has a peculiar goal: He wants to go to the moon. He cannot remember where this desire came from, but he definitely wants to go.As the technicians dive into Johnny's memories, more and more questions arise and mysteries need to be unravelled. I'd rather not spoil the plot to you by telling more - discovering things and figuring out the answers from the clues presented is half the enjoyment here.When I first noticed that this was not a "real" game some way into "To the Moon", it annoyed me a bit since it had not been said on the box. What won me back is that the story we're told is quite touching and rewarding. I dare you to not care about Johnny, Eva and Neil by the end of events! To keep everything in memory (and for ultimate impact on "the feels"), it's best played in one sitting, like, say, one rainy afternoon. And do keep a box of tissues and a bottle of water close by, you might need them.(Also, the music is fantastic. The whole soundtrack can be found on Bandcamp under http://freebirdgames.bandcamp.com/album/to-the-moon-ost - give the main theme a try.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												To the Moon tells us a wonderfully written, captivating and touching story of life, death and of a very simple - yet the greatest - thing, called: love. The game does this so beautifully that you are guaranteed to cry many times throughout the course of the events. It's the triumph of storytelling that a game built on an ancient japanese rpg engine (first used by Dragon Quest), with text-only dialogue and without any complex puzzles whatsoever can offer such a deep experience. Because contrary what the engine would suggest, To the Moon is an adventure game and could be best compared to a wonderfully good book.The main concept of the game can be a bit untempting (at least it was for me, even though I do love sci-fi). In the near future people on their deathbeds can order a service with which they can relive their lives in a perfectly ideal way, having artificial memories implanted into their minds. Thus they can pass away peacefully and in happiness. This process requires a specific machine (made by Sigmund Corporation) and skilled technicians who must discover the hidden wish of the patient and fulfill it by taking a different path at certain points of the person's life.The player takes the role of two such technicians, Dr. Eva Rosalene (Senior memory traversal agent) and Dr. Neil Watts (technician specialist). They both have different personalities: Dr. Rosalene being the more serious one (still she also cracks better jokes) and Dr. Watts being childish (and somewhat subordinated to Dr. Rosalene). They also regulary mock each other.Strangely enough they aren't the game's main protagonists. but the dying old man, their current patient, Johnny Wyles and the love of his life, River (who has passed away not long ago). Johnny and River were high-school sweethearts and were seemingly made for each other, still, their marriage wasn't as happy as expected. Johnny now lives alone on a cliff near the ocean, with a beautiful view to a lighthouse, with Lily, the housekeeper and her two children. Johnny's dying wish is a journey to the Moon. The two technicians traverse back through time in Johnny's life via several decisive mementos, that played an important role in his life. With each leap backwards they/we get to know Johnny's life beginning from a few days before to his high school years. In most of these memories, River is also present. When the technicians finally reach Johnny's childhood, they encounter a memory block and therefore unable to travel to the point when Johnny was a small kid. They don't attach great importance to it and begin the installation of his new "memories". However it seems Johnny has absolutley no desire to go to the Moon. At this point Eva and Neil must somehow awaken an interest in him towards the Moon.Eventually it turns out that due to a childhood trauma and memory loss Johnny forgot that he and River had met as children at a carnival. They shared a common interest towards the stars and immediately became friends. Then they agreed that if one of them were to ever get lost (or to forget about this meeting), they would regroup again on the Moon (also we get an explanation why River is holding onto that platypus plush toy so much...)Later, after they meet again in high school and then get married, River emotional distance comes from the fact that Johnny couldn't remember their first meeting at the carnival.The gameplay is very simple: by controlling Eva and Neil the player must explore each memory segment (in the upper section of the screen we can always check which segment of Johnny's life we are in), solve some hidden-picture puzzles and then travel back in time to the next memory. In order to do this however, you'll have to find and unlock mementos by collecting memory orbs. These memory orbs can be acquired by clicking on familiar characters, items, or locations. You can't get stuck, as the solution is often intuitional: for example at the ranch where Johnny and River go horseback riding, you have to catch up with the lively and joyous River and ride alongside her to receive the orbs (this segment contains the loveliest tune in the game by the way: Take Me Anywhere).Besides Take Me Anywhere the main theme is also amazing as is the rest of the music in the game, always perfectly reflecting the current tone of the given memory segment. These piano themes are fantastic and further facilitate the brilliance of the game.The ending is lovely but also a bit of a letdown (don't worry, there is a happy ending :)), because it is predictable what Eva is planning to do with River in Johnny's memory. I think it would've been a bit better if it was up to Neil (who actually changes over the course of the story in a positive way) to rearrange Johnny's memory and leave River in the role she deserved to be in.Still that's only a minor lament from my side and hardly detracts from the game's value. To the Moon points it out how beautiful memories ordinary people can have and is one of those few games that should be played by every single person all around the world. I'm sure the world could be a better place after that.PROS+ superbly written, heartbreaking love story+ great, loveable characters+ charming music+ often sad, often hilarious dialogues+ some of the sections are so beautiful, they're worth replayingCONS- River shouldn't have been removed from Johnny's childhood memory- Dragonball referencesRATING9.5/10

												Easily among my top 10 greatest games of all time. This game doesn't have a whole lot of gameplay but it brings a spectacular story that everyone should check out. The game has a spectacular soundtrack suiting the mood the entire time and I sat down and played this game all in one sitting because the story was just that good. The gameplay is simple point and click to find things and the game will last you from 3-6 hours depending on how much you explore and how fast you are at reading. Posted: February 25, 2015
												Ahem-em... Hrmmm! What? No I didn't cry, I didn't...Okay... maybe just a little ૮´︵ ` აI've... been straying astray from what got me into video games in the first place as a child...Back in the good old days when game developers created master-piece games most of which were in 2D it was all about the original unique trial and error story-telling and new attempts to try out new styles of how to go about making a game since it was something new, cheesy lovable characters, cool/cute characters, character development, albeit this game was short, we learned so much from just experiencing ones past. That goes far beyond deep character development in a new perspective.Now if you will excuse me... I have a very large list of 199x-early 2000 video games to pull out of their dusty retirement.I must reconcile with my already breaking heart and remember what a true game feels like.**Sure, let's go play a game about todays decapitating other players, shooting them, yelling at each other, putting people down. Graphics this, Graphics that! 3Dvs2D This! 3Dvs2D That! Cheesy Dialog this, Cheesy Dialog that.People need to get off their high horses, but then again most of these people with negative reviews more than likely never played any classic JRPGs of the SNES/PS1 eras so it's understandable if they don't get such a moving story.That being said very few developers still create amazing games that FOCUS primarily on character developments and very touching moving storylines, mostly done indie developers. Dust; an Elysian TailOri and the Blind Forest (Coming March 11th)etc

Presentation is a bit meh (would've love to move in a three-dimensional plane to make it easier), but writing is top notch. For some reason, F12 in this game pauses it instead of taking a screenshot?Pros- Pony rides; Disembodied floating heads, at one point, Zombies at another (I'm serious), Compelling story that made me want to keep going.Cons- Abrupt abandonment of flip puzzles, Story is likely hard to follow on first playthrough; I wish environments were a little bigger as there were some crammed areas.So basically, I said the story was a pro and the story was a con. But yeah, I think most people will enjoy it.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
 Beautiful. Before going in-depth with my review for the game, I want to sum it up with that one word alone:  Beautiful.Upon purchasing the game, I didn't know what I was getting myself into. Sure, I've heard praises about it some time ago and it was on sale recently for a very reasonable price. So, I bought the game along with its soundtrack bundled in without any idea what to truly expect. And after just finishing the game recently, I can safely say that what I got was an experience worth every penny. Keyword: "experience".I'll start off by discussing what I think is the main problem that people seem to have for the game (based on the negative Steam reviews).This game is labeled as an "Indie Adventure Role Playing Game". It was also designed through the RPG Maker XP engine. So it is of no surprise that people expect at least a bit of RPG Maker gameplay elements that are typically found elsewhere. But this game doesn't have that. In fact, aside from very simple puzzles, this game doesn't have much else in terms of 'gameplay'. And therein lies the problem. It's hard to call it a 'game' when it barely has any gameplay elements to it. Heck, as long as you keep playing there's no way to lose the game. It's more like a movie with a few interactions added here and there. I personally expected a bit of a challenge too but the game was too easy and too linear. But is that necessarily a bad thing?No. In my opinion, it's not.In fact, because of how straightforward the gameplay is, I was able to progress through the story very quickly in anticipation for what's going to happen next. All I had to do was overcome a bit of a hurdle in order to progress through the story and it didn't bother me at all.That is why I prefer calling it an 'experience' as opposed to calling it a 'game'. It is a  story-driven experience. The lack of any complicated gameplay made all the other aspects of the game shine.The graphics may be your typical RPG Maker stuff, but it's better-looking than most of the games made through the RPG Maker engine. The story...well, without spoiling much let's just say that there are a lot of feels found in this game. One minute I'm laughing at the interactions between the two main characters, and the next minute I'm trying my best to hold back my tears from too much feels (and most of the time failing to hold back said tears; no shame in that). And the music? Oh man, the music...the music in this game is arguably its greatest asset. The music found in the game is very beautiful. Each soundtrack served its purpose in making every scene of the game much more enjoyable and memorable. If you buy the game, I implore you to buy the soundtrack as well. It's worth it.It's a short game; only took me around 4 hours to finish. But every second of that 4 hours was worth it. It was a short but sweet ride.I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												The Bad:-The graphics are pretty terrible.-There is no real gameplay apart from a few very easy puzzles and your basic explore-and-interact. The Good:+The soundtrack is beautiful and used very well throughout the story.+The story is very well written and extremely emotional. Every detail throughout the game is well planned, every mystery has a great payoff, it all connects brilliantly and the dialogue (Text only, no voice acting) is really good.Overall, you play as 2 scientists who alter dying people's memories to fulfill a wish for them (or, at least, make them believe it came true). In this case, they're out to help an old man called John H. Wyles, who's dying wish is to go (you guessed it) to the moon. What makes this case a bit different to their normal ones is that Johnny hasn't the faintest idea as to why he even wants that. He just knows he does. The game's divided into 3 acts. The first one is mostly about establishing the backstory and leanring about Johnny's life. It's pretty slow paced, and mostly sets up questions to be answered later. The 2nd act picks up the pace, and from there till the end I found the game hard to stop playing.It takes a bit over 3 hours to finish, so I recommend finishing it in 1 sitting for maximum impact.

It's all worth it.I'm so thankful for this game.10/10, really.EDIT1: I will never forget this game. Ever.EDIT2: Almost a year has passed and opinion hasn't changed. What. A. Beautiful. Emotional. Rollercoaster.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												SPOILER-FREE REVIEW!In over four decades of playing video games, only a handful have ever elicited strong emotional responses with me. "Final Fantasy VII," "Ico," "Shadow of the Colossus," and "Journey" are among the very few that have had such a powerful effect. "To The Moon" can now take its rightful place alongside those titles. From beginning to end, I never once turned it off or took a break. It had me hooked in from the very moment I turned it on, and it is still haunts me even after its overwhelming finale. This will be a game that I shall remember many, many years from now. There are so many moments that brought me to tears, probably more than any other game, and I loved it. If you are not touched by the game's beautiful story, you have no heart. By the game's conclusion, you will wonder to yourself if your life would have been better had you taken different paths at different times in your past. If given the opportunity to change it, would you?Graphics: 10/10 - The character design, rich colors, backgrounds, and little details made me feel like I was in this world.Sound: 7/10 - There's not much, but what's there is perfectly suited for this game. The heart beats and distorted laughs are memorable.Music: 10/10 - Every track is flawless.Gameplay: 7/10 - Mostly walking around and touching objects. The puzzles are not challenging, but the product's more of an interactive story than a game. Some people could be put off by its simplicity.Story: 10/10 - You WILL cry.Overall: 10/10 - One of the best games I've played in years. Freebird Games proves that you don't need huge budgets, realistic graphics, buckets of blood, or name brand recognition to produce a great game -- and this truly is a GREAT game.There is no excuse; you must play this game before you die. You won't regret it.

												Built around an old-school JRPG game engine, To The Moon is one of the most tear-jerking stories I've ever played. It eschews a lot of mechanics such as choice and combat in order to create an interactive, exploration/adventure that uncovers the beautiful, sad history of a character on their deathbed.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												To The Moon is simply put the most beautiful experience I've ever had in a looooong time. It takes an alternate approach to story-telling by going backwards in the timeline, and really pays off in the end as a result. It only took four hours for me to finish, but by the end I was covered in tears. Despite the lack of gameplay, the simple concept of exploration was enough for me to continue for I felt that any sort of standard gameplay mechanic would draw away from the story itself. It was an unforgettable journey, and if anyone in the world tells you that video games aren't art just shove this game into their face.Brilliant Story. Touching Soundtrack. Gorgeous Pixel Art. Just Play It.P.S. Now I'll never look at a platypus the same way again.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I'd consider myself an averagely strong person that doesn't seem to get overly upset over something, or so I thought, until I played this beautiful and amazing game or... story. The thought of this grief-stricken and heartsick man wanting to indulge into his dream or wish to go the the moon doesn't sound that sad until you actually go ahead and play this game. The intricate and detailed design of the game really hits you hard in the heart. But the thing that really hurt was the music. Kan Gao is an amazing composer when it comes to music, it wouldn't be the same without the beautiful music that he peformed, absolutely stunning. I was attracted to this game not by reviews nor suggestions, but the music that I came across when I was browsing YouTube one morning. That's how beautiful it is.This game has  been nominated for the "I'm not crying, there's something in my eye award!" This game certainly fits this breif and deserves to win. I know i'll be voting "To The Moon".To everyone out there, I recommend this game. It's not just an average game, it's outstanding.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Man… To the Moon, such a hard game to talk about because I don’t want to ruin the experience for anyone.  And that’s what you get here.  This is an experience.  It’s not a “game” don’t expect much “gameplay”, in you don’t have to beat bosses, or solve major puzzles.  There’s a few no loss puzzles, and a few “find a specific object”.  But for the most part they are not hard, and not frustrating at all.  In fact it’s pretty damn easy. It’s also quite a long game, and I have to be honest, I almost didn’t play it more than about an hour.  But when I went back, I played through the rest and honestly.  I’m glad I did.  The game has a VERY strong narrative, and this is what makes me happy to have played it. Not only is the narrative strong, but it works with the mechanics of the game, and the gameplay.  The game is all about memories and exploring them, and the story works right along with that.  There’s some twists and turns but just about everything the game does is “right”. The only two flaws I’d say with the game is the opening is weak (ish) and doesn’t hook you right away in my opinion.  It’d have been great to see the characters finish a job so you have an idea what their job is.    The other flaw is one point in the “game” where I feel the creator felt he had to make it a “game”.  It honestly feels out of place.   Not that it ruins the experience at all, but really didn’t need to see that. So is it good?  Well There’s a lot of discussion about “games as art” and I HATE that discussion because it promotes pretentious games and says “no this is totally what games could be.”  And often times the story is manipulative and weak, and the game is overly dramatic trying to really hammer you over the head. To the Moon doesn’t do that.  Instead it tells an amazing story, and makes the player care about the story to the point where they don’t mind the lack of “gameplay” and really just want to see where the story goes.  It doesn’t explain everything in a hamfisted way, and in fact leaves some of the story semi open for the player to figure out (through googling, rather than just interpretation) which I liked.   Is it good?  No.  It’s great.  Is it ten bucks worthy?  I don’t know, it’s only about 5 hours, and I don’t know if I’ll replay it, but it does something so different and new, and accomplishes it with SNES style graphics.   I recommend it to anyone who wants something different, who is willing to pay for a story rather than a game, and willing to connect with characters on a different level than most games try to manipulate them to feel.

Posted: May 19, 2014
												There are too many reviews about this game, and they all praise the story. But then again there a lot of reviews about many games, and I've played games long enough not to trust them with what I'll enjoy. So this is the only thing I have to say here:Ignore the reviews, don't read about the story. Just give this game a chance. The least I can say about it is that this is a unique, rewarding experience and well worth the journey. So if you have a quiet evening to spare, don't watch a movie, don't read a book, play this instead. For me personally To The Moon is a memory I'm glad I'll be carrying with me.

												I really liked this game. I hadn't read that much about it before I played it, because a friend gave it to me as a gift. As such, it was a pleasant surprise through the game when River started seeming a bit like, well... me, and I realised why. It's a very nice comment on women like River and her sister. The story is very sweet. At times I felt quite tearful! There is no voice acting, which is a shame, but the music adds atmosphere, and there is something quaint about the simplicity of it, and the ability to tell such a good story through this medium. I'd recommend this game, especially to women who know who Tony Attwood or Rudy Simone are.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2013
												I purchased To the Moon on a whim because it had strong reviews and was on sale. Plus, the game description intrigued me, and I thought if nothing else, it might be a decent way to spend the evening.Four hours later, and I am crying harder than I have in months. I honestly don't know how to describe this game without spoiling the magic of it. This is one of the titles I will point to when people contend that video games cannot be art. They absolutely can be, and this indie might well be considered a masterpiece. The story of To the Moon is tragic, beautiful, and sad. It is often funny and sometimes hilarious. It is the first video game that ever stirred my emotions to the point of tears. And it gave me a newfound appreciation for life. Seriously.Some details would probably be helpful. You play as Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts, two specialists who are hired to modify clients' memories so that the last thing they remember on their deathbeds is the fulfillment of a grand and final wish. This is achieved by working backwards through the patient's remembered life, planting the seed of an idea in their early childhood so that their new, artificial life will play out the way it needs to in order for the wish to take hold. Their latest job is an old man named Johnny, a widower who wants to go to the moon. Only thing is, he doesn't remember why he wants to go, only that he must. So our heroes set up their equipment, enter his most recent memory, and start seeing the man's life in reverse.What begins as a standard point-and-click title quickly weaves into a heartbreaking and simultaneously joyous exploration of life, death, love and its flaws, dreams and the crushing feeling of losing them, promises kept and broken, the future, the past, and the importance of making the present count. It portrayed the shattering realities of illness, financial woes, selfishness, and failure. It captured the grief of not understanding someone you love and the tragedies that befall all of us. It illustrates how love is powerful but also incredibly painful and complex. It makes you think about how each one of us is the hero of our own story, and how much it hurts when we don't live up to the title. It makes you think about how we take so many things and people for granted, and the peculiarities of what does and doesn't stick in our memory. It shows us the importance and the absurdity of chasing after nostalgia, of knowing that something in your possession matters but not remembering why. It shows how easy it is to see other people's mistakes in life while ignoring our own. It pointed out how we would rather act than listen. To the Moon made me think about my own real-life relationships and how I could (should) put more effort into them. It made me think about dozens of chance encounters I've had, the dreaded "What if?" It made me smile with its true-to-life depictions of talking to girls, arguing with co-workers, and gently mocking one's friends. And it emotionally wrecked me with its dramatic twists, gorgeous soundtrack, and perfect ending. It's like someone took the first 10 minutes of the Pixar film UP, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, and several classic RPGs and threw them in a blender.Some of the dialogue and the mental images that followed it made me think of other, bigger titles, such as Bioshock Infinite. Oh, how we love our lighthouses... But the story here is much more intimate and private, like reading a journal that someone's kept since they were 5. The visuals are charming, going for an old-school RPG look like Link to the Past or the original Harvest Moon. Cinema was obviously a huge influence on some of the particulars, notably Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and Inception. Still, this is a truly original work, one that will stick in your brain long after it ends. The story's ability to make you cry, laugh (sometimes at once), and reflect is something few video games can do. It's something few movies or books can do. Get To the Moon, and let yourself be affected.Edit: I've nominated To the Moon for the "I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye" Award. There is no other possible contender. Play this already.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Wow. I played this all in one sitting. Start to finish. Absolutely brilliant. Could not put it down. It's like if someone took Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind and combined it with Inception to a create a story about doctors who dive into the memories of the dying to artificially fulfill their dying wish by creatively revising their memories (emphasis on Eternal Sunshine). I was initially (and perhaps unfairly) skeptical of what a story could do with pixel art, but am happy to say I was quite wrong. This was much, much better than I expected. I appreciated all the subtle but extremely significant connections that go completely unmentioned, providing deep rewards for the more perceptive and analytical story-focused players. The story also does beautiful things with an autism spectrum character that left me very impressed. A++ more please.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												It is extremely rare to find a work of art as brilliant as To the Moon. This visual novel revolves around Johnny Wyles, a dying man who has lived a sad, and unfulfilling life. Johnny's dying wish is to go to the moon, though he doesn't know why. To make this wish a reality, he enlists Dr. Eva Rosaline and Dr. Neil Watts of Sigmund Corp. who are determined to send Johnny to the moon one way or another.To the Moon has an incredible story, fantastic artwork, and an absolutely beautiful soundtrack. It evokes a variety of emotions, and contains plenty of comic relief. I would absolutely recommend To the Moon for any casual gamers, particularly those who love visual novels.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												While this game is certainly not bad, it's not exactly good either. But since most reviews are positive anyway, I might aswell tell you why it just didn't work for me.-The storyIn it's core I thought the overall concept was actually pretty original. You pay as two scientist who travel back through a dying man's memories in order to grant him his last wish artificially: taking him to the moon (roll credits). Though during the story, your original objective is often questioned, as you begin to understand that this wish is not what would make your patient truly happy.So, it's really not the story that set me off, it's rather...-The dialogueYou'd think that in a story that's supposed to make you sad and teary, you wouldn't need a character for comic relief. But damnit, the second main character suplied you with a steady ammount of jokes in all the wrong places. I just couldn't take the game serious anymore. At the first half of the story, whenever there was an emotional moment, that same guy, messed it up over an over again. And by the time the game was starting to get deep, it was just too late for me. You see, the sad moments of the game largely depend on how you attached you grow to the characters over time. And maybe it's just me, but I hated both of them.-GameplayWell, interesting gameplay is virtually nonexistent. But that's really not an issue in a story driven game. As I mentioned before, it has a great outline, but it just feels so unrefined at some places that it just wasn't enjoyable for me.-The lengthYou'll probably finish the game in 3-4 hours. And while I don't want to badmouth the content, you may think that it's been a short ride if you don't even have all the trading cards by the time you are done.All in all, I'd say it's okay if you can pick it up during a sale. But I really don't think it's worth the full price if you take a look at what it offers. Just about 4 hours of gameplay which aren't even amazing. But I assume that most people have a far better time, given that they don't dislike the main characters as much as I do.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
To the Moon is an adventure/story that slowly reveals the life an old man on his death bed and the circumstances surrounding his final wish. Your progression leads you to regress through his memories, piecing together the importance of his request and why he chose it. Clever and heart-wrenching, To the Moon promises a bittersweet storyline and a simple, yet beautiful score to accompany it. The game will make you laugh; it will make you cry; it will make you hope for the fulfillment of your dreams.Story: 10/10     It's bittersweet and emotionally-engaging. The dialogue between the characters are often funny and clever, drawing from many modern tropes.Gameplay: 7/10     It features the same type of basic puzzle (with increasing difficulty), intended to give the player some reprieve from just pointing and clicking, and acts as a gate to the next part of the game. Not much variety, but it's what you would expect of a game in its genre.Controls: 7/10     Point-and-click and if you are so inclined, the arrow keys. Movement is a bit clunky, but not terrible.Replayability: 5/10     There are no achievements outside of the completion of the game, so unless you want to relive the story again, I don't see why you would replay it.Fun: 8/10     If your idea of fun is a relaxing game and story time, then this is fun. Think of it as reading an interactive visual novel. That's fun, right?Conclusion:     If getting hit in the feels is your thing, get this game. If the game is on sale, DEFINITELY get this game. Rarely will you come across story that will incorporate so many of your emotions over the span of only a few hours. It's definitely worth the purchase; the music alone is worth the price of the game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I stopped playing Mass Effect 3 for almost three months before I could finish it when I lost one of my favorite characters towards the end due to my own shortcomings. I leveled Cloud and friends for hours on end to try and keep her from dying (name held for spoiler protection) in FFVII. I replayed the same misison in Wing Commander II over and over to try and save Spirit. However sad I felt, it always was a game to me and never shed a tear. Not even close.Played To the Moon, and cried enough to rival that of my lifetime. Many may have missed the many many nuances of the story, and after completion I suggest reading up on it. This story takes reality by the feet and drags into the realm of Science Fiction. Every element, color choice, and dialogue is carefully placed to further the central focus of this game, the story. This emotional story/journey is the central focus (not gameplay, graphics, or gimmics) and is something so memorable. For me, I felt the tear jerking moment coming... but still caught me completely off guard. Excellent sound track. Bravo. Well done.Will play again when I actually man up and buy tissues.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Great story with terrible graphics (game runs on a stupidly small resolution with no options to change that). The gameplay mostly consists of walking around, clicking on things and reading the dialogue. But the writing is excellent. The story is about a dying man whose last wish is to go to the moon. You play as the employees of a corporation that is capable of altering people's memories to give them the illusion of having a different life thus fulfilling their last wish before they die. The narrative unfolds in a reverse chronological order as you go back in time through the old man's memories, learning about his life and finding a way to make his wish come true. It's an interesting way to tell a story and it's executed quite well here.

												This game was truely a great experience, and I very much enjoyed playing it. So I would definietly recommend you to buy it, even for its full price, because this is the kind of developer we should be supporting.The game was a pleasent surprise, as it offered much more than what I had expected from a 2D RPG. The story caught my attention right from the very beginning and it never really went dull. The characters were interesting, and I found the music to be very nice and suiting to the rest of the game. The game mechanics wasn't anything out of the ordinary, and honestly it didn't really need to be either. I found the game to be very well polished, and of very high quality, and I would definietly say its one of the best 2D RPG games that I have ever played on PC.Pros:+ Great storyline, with a very nice paced progression.+ The length of the game is just perfect, and it never feels too slow or too fast.+ Well developed characters.+ Great sense of humor, without being too over the top.+ Nice and suiting music.+ Easy to get 100% steam achievement ( if you care about that )Cons:- I can't really think of anything bad to say.

Posted: July 30, 2015
 This will hit you right in the feels....and you'll be glad it did. Don't be put off by the way this game starts, I was, and I beg you to learn from my mistake.After playing through the first 10 minutes or so i quickly declared the game to be "boring as hell" and "A magnificent waste of my time", but when I stumbled upon it in my library again late yesterday evening I gave it another shot....and played straight through the night just so I would get to finish it, hell I even played the minisodes while I was at it.I would highly recommend this game to anyone, it might not give you that adrenaline rush some people crave but it will sure as hell kick you right in the feels, and you'll thank it for doing so. During this game I laughed, I cried, and most of all I just had a ton of fun. The graphis aren't great, and yeah, sometimes the controls are a little wonky, but the AMAZING soundtrack won't leave you any time or need to worry about that. From some of the very first scenes to the very end, the music grabbed me and pulled me straight through the just as well written story. I would honestly tell everyone to buy this game, take a day off, and just play through it in one sitting. At the end, you'll almost be a different person. This game tells a wonderfull story, and does so in such a way that no matter what you wanted to happen, what you expected, what you hated, what you liked, you'll still love it, just the way it was.This game definitely got itself a place in my heart, and I hope it'll find it's way to your heart too.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												To the Moon is one of those works whose very nature places it at a disadvantage. Like a kicker on an American Football team, this genre (which is most satisfactorially described as an "interactive experience") is not comparable to its peers since it doesn't do the same thing they do. But in all fairness its peers likewise cannot match what it does, and you'd better believe it does plenty!The Negs --This title catches you off-guard, withholding the real meat of the gameplay until about 30 minutes in. And even then, that gameplay meat is lean-sliced turkey over a bagel at best. The "interactor" (rather than "player") functions to only move characters from one cutscene to the next. To the Moon could be outright categorized as a point-and-click game if it weren't for the RPG presentation it offers. The story mechanics are sometimes inconsistent, making the goals unclear, which is especially frustrating when all you want to do is get the characters to the next scene of dialogue. This frustration is not extensive though. There were some bugs in places, and sometimes the ground was just too cluttered with vague textures. Quite literally I continually thought the game was freezing on me simply because my character stopped walking when in reality a small flower, not so different in appearance from another small flower that I walk right over, was just blocking my way. The faults of the gameplay were highly bearable, however, mainly because the gameplay was a minor part of this experience.The Pos --Despite all the underwhelming gameplay aspects, this piece held my attention for 5 hours quite easily. The culprit: the characters. Not the main two doctors - I knew about them. What captivated me were the rest of the cast and their unanswered stories. The writing in this game is keen and well-paced, playing coy about the questions it introduces while not leaving the interactor lost for too long. The dialogue ventures into topics that are realistically gritty and gray. This whole experience works in the first place because the user is immersed enough to accept the story and characters at hand. This immersion is influenced by the detailed artwork, which avoided the half-hearted tiling of textures that RPGs are known for, and by the MIND-BLOWING SOUNDTRACK!!!!! I could not give the ost for this work any more laud than it has already received, but if my two cents count for a thing, the music in this game had me consciously framing each scene to its tone, particularly when the music changed mid-scene.The Verd --To the Moon is definitely one to sit down and just experience one day. It is certainly not the sort of thing that I would do any day to blow off some steam; there is a mood for it. So if you find yourself in the mood to watch The Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind but in a form that requires you to read a little more, then pick up To the Moon (there are actually very similar tones between the two works, and the atmospheres line up pretty well too). As a video game it merits a [7 / 10], but as its own genre of entertainment it steals [10 / 10]. Touching on troubling topics and tearducts alike, To the Moon earned its place as a title that everyone should play once and discuss for a long time after.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
To the Moon is an adventure/story that slowly reveals the life an old man on his death bed and the circumstances surrounding his final wish. Your progression leads you to regress through his memories, piecing together the importance of his request and why he chose it. Clever and heart-wrenching, To the Moon promises a bittersweet storyline and a simple, yet beautiful score to accompany it. The game will make you laugh; it will make you cry; it will make you hope for the fulfillment of your dreams.Story: 10/10     It's bittersweet and emotionally-engaging. The dialogue between the characters are often funny and clever, drawing from many modern tropes.Gameplay: 7/10     It features the same type of basic puzzle (with increasing difficulty), intended to give the player some reprieve from just pointing and clicking, and acts as a gate to the next part of the game. Not much variety, but it's what you would expect of a game in its genre.Controls: 7/10     Point-and-click and if you are so inclined, the arrow keys. Movement is a bit clunky, but not terrible.Replayability: 5/10     There are no achievements outside of the completion of the game, so unless you want to relive the story again, I don't see why you would replay it.Fun: 8/10     If your idea of fun is a relaxing game and story time, then this is fun. Think of it as reading an interactive visual novel. That's fun, right?Conclusion:     If getting hit in the feels is your thing, get this game. If the game is on sale, DEFINITELY get this game. Rarely will you come across story that will incorporate so many of your emotions over the span of only a few hours. It's definitely worth the purchase; the music alone is worth the price of the game.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2013
												A touching journey through the life of Johnny, a man on his deathbed, who has but one wish... to go the moon. Why the moon? That is explored by Dr. Watts and Dr. Rosalene via a memory device, reminiscent of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. In this case though, the doctors are able to not only view, but take part in the memories.The gameplay is by far the weakest aspect of To the Moon. It is a mixture of finding objects and completing dull puzzles. It's a means to an end, really. At no point would I say the gameplay was enjoyable, but I was compelled to continue by the beautiful story.The story is wonderfully told: it respects the players intelligence, allowing certain realisations to hit quite hard. I still find myself thinking about it, months on. Couple the story with an outstanding soundtrack (seriously, grab the soundtrack edition) and you have something very special.  +Heartfelt story+Great Soundtrack+The doctors have a nice dynamic-Game elements are boring/unnecessary-Movement can be a little awkwardTo the Moon would be better suited to another medium in my opinion. It's definitely not the first time it has been said, but it truly would make a better movie than a game. Even so, buy.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												It's not so much as a game as it is an interactive storybook. One where  you flip the pages to the very end.The wording "To the Moon" is truthful in wording and truthful in where it leads. Physically and emotionally tolled, you will be affected as you take on the journey of an ideologically driven man - lying on his deathbed- to his dream of landing on the moon. He wishes it not only for his own sake, but for the women he loved so much as to let her die. His final action and wish is a gift of placation and apology for her sake. You control two scientists who enter dreams in an effort to change the memory of any ailing, near death patient in order to achieve their dreams mentally, but not physically. Their characters are often juxtaposed with the backdrop of the bitter, saddened clients they have, but it serves as a humanizing reminder of the need for human emotion in the times of desperation. They don't serve as the main character, but as (you) -> The person who journeys from the start and to the end of the story, not the creator.There isn't much of a game here to be had besides a few puzzles here and there, scattered as a movement of progression. Each puzzle serves as a pinpoint of interest in the client's life reminding the player of the human aspects of the person's mind they are investigating. May it be a simple baloon or some pickles, each pinpoint from the puzzle has its purpose of showing how human the character is.Verdict: This is a journey, a story of a man's unattained wish and you must complete it. I recommend it to the fullest to whoever enjoys games for their stories and not just for their gameplay. This is purely an interactive story.

But the story, art, and music's amazingness completely eclipsed anything that could be found wrong elsewhere. I was completely blown away. You must play this game, if only to watch your soul shed a few scars, and your heart become a little less cold.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												"In GameSpot's 2011 Game of the Year awards, To the Moon was given the "Best Story" award, which was won against Catherine, Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective, Portal 2, and Xenoblade Chronicles." Also, this game has Metascore rating of 81 which is pretty unusual for some indie pixel art.I've accidentally found this game in my collection, it was purchased in some bundle and became long forgotten. I decided to start it at least once to see what is it about and reduce number of unplayed games on my steam account.And it definitely wasn't a mistake. The game is a great story, presented in a clever way that keeps you interested for straight four hours. I won't lie - there isn't a lot of choice or freedom in this game, it is more of an interactive fiction that tells you about the entire lifetime of one person, so you could grant him a wish he couldn't get in his real life. You just sometimes press buttons to move to the next story point, but it is nicely told, gives you something to think about and with a plot twist. Everything we love about stories.And one more thing: there is no city, but there is a man. And there is a lighthouse.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												To The Moon by Freebird games. This is such a great game. One of my favourites for sure. Don't watch the videos on YouTube, just play it. It might look basic/boring, but play it to the end and you will not be disappointed. I highly recommend playing it if you haven't already. [Overall rating 8.5/10]Gameplay is pretty average. There isn't much exciting about the gameplay. You click to move, search for objects, click objects, talk to NPCs and that is about it. Don't expect a lot from the gameplay but what it lacks here, it excels in storyline and audio. I believe the gameplay is meant to be quite simple so that more people can experience the story. Even though gameplay is a big deal in video games, this game was amazing still. [Gameplay rating 6/10]Storyline was something else. Beautiful. When you finish the game and reach the credits, you want to applaud... after you've wiped away the tears of course. If' you're just starting this game, I can't stress how important it is to play this game to the end just for that experience alone. The story alone makes up for the simple gameplay and graphics. [Story rating 10/10]Graphics are retro style, like something from a SNES time RPG. Don't expect something cutting-edge from the graphics, but they are detailed enough for you to see facial expressions and catch the emotions needed. [Graphics rating 8/10]Audio is amazing. I find that I'm listening to the full soundtrack regularly. The song, "Everythings Alright" by Laura Shigihara still gives me the feels when I hear it. Amazing voice, and amazing soundtrack. Audio often helps a great deal with infusing emotions into a story, this is definitely the case with To The Moon. [Audio rating 10/10]Instead of showing gameplay or epic moments in the game. I will leave you with a YouTube link for the full soundtrack. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												An absolutely beautiful story, delivered in a pace slow enough to let you contemplate every moment, but still making you play a second time to fully comprehend all the little details. Clearly, this game has been crafted with plenty of passion and experience.The very introduction reflects the entire game's mood perfectly. The protagonists are having delightful interactions, eventhough they drove over an animal and had a car accident.  Throughout the entire game, you will experience this contrast of cheerful colours, bright music and lighthearted dialogue against cruel reality, shocking revelations and gruesome secrets.As for the story itself, the characters are all congenial in some aspect. There are no uninteresting interactions and no unexplained plot conveniences. Besides some joke content not relevant to the story (instead to brighten the mood), there are no plot holes or unnecessary story elements. Everything of the actual story makes sense in the end, but a few questions about the frame story remain unanswered, probably to be expanded on in the next "episodes".If you like story-driven games and don't mind the pixelated graphics, you should definitely consider playing this game!

												I'm not gonna lie, I got a little choked up, but because I'm a real G, I sucked those tears back in. It's a story worth experiencing, and has a soundtrack worth buying. I mean for $15 you get a great game and some great music, whereas for $60 you could get Call of HaloField: Generic Wrfare: Jetpack of the Year Edition: Nazi Zombie Socialists mode (this joke went on for way too long, I apologize). It's all in perspective. But I digress. Get this game. It's a no-brainer. This story is what I can only describe as: one of the few horses that you can't not ride. This, along with TellTales The Walking Dead, and a few others that I can't remember at this late hour, all fall into this stable of must-ride stallions (This joke will make sense once you buy the game). Overall, this game gets, and I can't believe I am saying this, a 10/10. Give FreeBird your money, and dont wait for a sale you cheapskape.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2016
To the Moon's strength lies in its story. It pertains to a man on his deathbed named Johnny who wishes to go to the moon via the alteration of his memories. This is done by you, the protagonist, and a partner.  All the other aspects of the game only serve to move the narrative forward. This is often done through puzzles and the hunt for important objects in Johnny’s life when delving into his memories. Despite the rather weak gameplay elements of the game, the more than stellar story make up for any shortcomings. When To the Moon concludes, a tear will likely be running down your cheek.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
Simply Amazing!TL;DR? Get this game! You will not regret its purchase especially at its price. For the five hours you will invest in the game, it will leave a mark on you forever!Pros:★ The story is one of the best I've ever experienced.★ Has a seamless feel to the game keeping you engaged.★ Cheap but definitely not nasty.★ The soundtrack is amazing and adds to the story.★ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.Cons:✖ Lack of any real 'gaming' may discourage some.✖ Left me crying like a little ♥♥♥♥♥.'To the Moon' would appear to start off like any other indie video game and may take a good five or ten minutes to understand on how it has been set out. But once you fall into the world of mystery that surrounds this game, you quickly become involved in a story that will leave an impressionable memory and have you wanting to reach for the story once again. Now if you are after action or involvement with a whole heap of WASD key bashing then this game does not suit that purpose. But if you are after a quiet evening and are ready to be involved in an amazing story then 'To the Moon' will be exactly what you are after.The only hiccup I have with this game is the puzzle sequence and found that it is Freebird's way of calling this a game. Whilst I do enjoy walking around talking to people and exploring the environment I found that the puzzle part wasn't exactly needed in the end development. Personally I love the piano and this game hits all of the perfect tones for the emotions it's trying to set. The music to this game plays a big part to each area you walk into and sets the mood very nicely. I don't want to give too much away as the mystery of the game is the gem in itself, but I promise you will find a connection to every single character that you find in the game.This is a game I know I will come back to in years time to come, just so I can listen to its story once again like any great book.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												This game came highly recommended to me, so I purchased it during the Steam 2013 Winter Sale. This little short story game is really touching. This game has all the feels. I recommend playing through the entire game in one go. It has only a few hours of game play altogether.Don't read any spoilers for this game. It WILL ruin the game for you.The gameplay itself wasn't great and rather repetitive. You are basically just walking around collecting items and checkpoints while solving some easy puzzles. But if you can get past that, it is well worth your time to go through it so you can see how this story unfolds.I highly recommend this game.At the very least, you should check out the soundtrack to this game. The soundtrack is amazing.
