content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This is one of the best games I've played in the longest time. Finally an RPG that focuses on the story. It's hard to say much without spoiling something, but I can say the characters were amazingly deep. I really could see this being turned into a movie. O_oThe game doesn't have much gameplay as a "game" most people are familiar with. It's more like a storybook, but once the ball gets rolling it was hard for me to stop watching. I was able to play this whole game in one sitting. Honestly not sure how long it took. I kinda lost track of time. I'm pretty sure I've been sitting here all day.I give this game:10/10 ★★★★★and two big thumbs up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2015
												This game has been in my library for quite some time, only when a friend recommended this that I started playing it one bored afternoon. I'm quite open to games but nonetheless I honestly thought this game was going to be boring after browsing through the store page. But seeing that it was recommended to me and that it's also got great reviews, I decided to start it. I didn't know what to expect, the game starts off a bit confusing as it's premise was very new to me, and I'm sure it  will be as well for some of you. What caught my attention and....emotions was the characters, their decisions, motivations and story. It all got me curious and I continued on wanting to learn more as I also got attached to them, some scenes are very heartwarming and sweet and others are innocent and depressing. The way the story is laid out in terms of memory links creates a very interesting and strong medium that makes it very easy to relate and observe the characters from. The game was never frustrating and you'll definitely find yourself pausing occasionally, if you're like me that enjoys a good soundtrack whilst revering the scenes and characters.This is certaintly a great game, if you are looking for a great story, short game with a great soundtrack, I'll also highly recommend this to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												This game has the BEST story of any game I've ever played. I read a lot of reviews about this game and all of them said that it had the saddest ending of any game ever. At first I was like pfffft yeah right and I was very hesitant to buy it. I randomly bought it yesterday and played through it in one sitting. It's about 4 hours long. Let me tell you this, this game has the saddest, most amazingly written story of any game I've played, any book I've read, or any movie I've seen. If you don't shed a tear by the time you've finished playing this game I refuse to believe you are a human being. The way that everything plays out and the soundtrack the accompany the setting go perfectly together. I know that 10 bucks seems like a little much for a 4 hour game but this is not just a game, it's an amazing piece of art that I think everyone can enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												This game has such a phoneomenal story. The gameplay is fairly linear and simple but it acts as the perfect vehicle for something like this. It definitely could go a lot further with some of its elements but that may be what they intend to do with the sequel that is in the works.When I played this I literally could not stop until it was all over. It was so emotionally charged and engaging that I stayed up all night to finish it and I really love sleep. There were so many moments in this game that made me cry (in both the sad and the extremely happy ways). It has the feel of many SNES RPGs so if you played a number of those growing up it will manage to pull at those nostalgic heart strings as well. Play this game. It's cheap and doesn't take long to complete. It's such an amazing experience that I could not imagine I would willingly pass it up.

												This game has been in my library for quite some time, only when a friend recommended this that I started playing it one bored afternoon. I'm quite open to games but nonetheless I honestly thought this game was going to be boring after browsing through the store page. But seeing that it was recommended to me and that it's also got great reviews, I decided to start it. I didn't know what to expect, the game starts off a bit confusing as it's premise was very new to me, and I'm sure it  will be as well for some of you. What caught my attention and....emotions was the characters, their decisions, motivations and story. It all got me curious and I continued on wanting to learn more as I also got attached to them, some scenes are very heartwarming and sweet and others are innocent and depressing. The way the story is laid out in terms of memory links creates a very interesting and strong medium that makes it very easy to relate and observe the characters from. The game was never frustrating and you'll definitely find yourself pausing occasionally, if you're like me that enjoys a good soundtrack whilst revering the scenes and characters.This is certaintly a great game, if you are looking for a great story, short game with a great soundtrack, I'll also highly recommend this to you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
“The ending isn’t any more important than the moments leading to it.”To the Moon is a story driven RPG game, developed and published by Freebird Games. You play as Dr. Watts and Dr Rosaline, employees of Sigmund Corp., a company that invented a machine that can create artificial memories by traveling through the memories of the subject. Their job is offering wish fulfilment to dying people, since implanting memories conflicts with the patient’s real memories, only people near death may request to have the procedure. Their patient today; Johnny Wyles, an old man with hours to live. His last wish; to go to the moon.Story:You know that scene at the start of Up where there’s the 5 minute montage of Carl and Ellie’s life from when they were kids, through their marriage, then when they were old? And it’s the saddest♥♥♥♥♥♥you’ve ever seen? To the Moon is almost exactly that.I’ll say right off, if you’re not into story driven games, don’t buy this game. To the Moon is all story, and light on gameplay. If you’re looking for good characters, great dialogue and a touching narrative driven experience, go ahead and pick this one up.With that out of the way, To the Moon is one of the most sappy, mushy emotional games I’ve ever played. And I mean that in the best way possible. To the Moon had me in tears. And if it doesn’t do the same for you, well, you’re probably just a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. In all seriousness, this is a game that will tug on the heartstrings. This is one giant feels train and a half. The story may be a little cliché at times and some moments are a little predictable, but that didn’t stop the game from being one of the most touching gaming stories I’ve played.One of the things that most caught me off-guard about the game was how funny some of the writing was. I don’t think I’ve ever played a game that had me tearing up in one scene, then laughing my♥♥♥♥♥off the next minute. The writing is great and although some of the humour has varying degrees of success, especially some of the pop-culture references, the vast majority of it resonated with me. “FREE PONY RIDES IN SPAAAAAACE!!!” Also, “You never cockblock someone in the middle of a Kamehameha.” To the Moon is a short game, clocking in at around 3 to 5 hours at most. It’s undoubtedly short compared to most other story driven games, but given its price (a steal when it’s on sale) and incredible story, the length of the game is justified in my opinion. It’s a game that’s as long as it needs to be.


The promise. 
A Screenshot of To the Moon
By: Sergio




Gameplay:Gameplay mostly consists of point and click style exploration and tile solving puzzles. To the Moon is about as minimalist as it gets without being a full-on visual novel. Whether you’re fine with that is up to your personal preference in games. Puzzles were fairly simplistic and most of the hidden objects you need to find to progress to the next scene are easy to find. Controls were somewhat finnicky, mostly down to the fault of the engine the game was developed in. Movement and interaction with objects in the environment at times was awkward, sometimes your character won’t move at all despite on clicking the object.Whether To the Moon is classified as an outright game or interactive entertainment is an argument for another time, but given the limitations of RPG Maker and the small indie team that developed the game, the lacking gameplay is mostly made up for. Just don’t go in expecting revolutionary game mechanics and you can get by it.Graphics and art design:Given the limitations of RPG Maker, it's somewhat understandable that most games that use that engine are hindered graphically. “Every RPG Maker game looks the same” is a common phrase, but still one that rings true. To the Moon is no different, it’s and RPG Maker game that looks like every other RPG Maker game. It by no means looks bad, the game looks perfectly okay. The game uses what it has to work with, and from a graphics standpoint, it’s acceptable. Perhaps it could have looked a bit nicer had the game been able to run on higher resolution monitors (the game is stuck at 640x480 and locked at 30fps, something else you should take note of if that concerns you.)Soundtrack and audio:The soundtrack is fantastic. The “sad piano song playing at heartwarming/sad scene” cliché is true, but the music works so well. There’s great use of leitmotifs, songs that will make you smile, songs that will make you cry. There’s so many tracks on the OST I loved, though if I were to pick the absolute highlights they would be To the Moon – Main Theme, For River, Moonwisher, Moongazer, Take Me Anywhere,  Once Upon a Memory,  and of course the absolute tear jerker;  Everything’s Alright.Conclusion:If you’re looking for a game that is guaranteed to make you cry (unless you’re a soulless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥), To the Moon has you covered. You’ll laugh, you’ll cry, you might be an emotional wreck by the ending. Though it’s light on gameplay and some will debate whether it’s even a game or an interactive story, To the Moon is an incredible experience. It’s by no means perfect, far from it, but for experience you get, it’s hella worth it. A beautiful story, fantastic script and a great soundtrack, you should give this one a shot.


To the Moon 
A Screenshot of To the Moon
By: Nick

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												There are certain games that leaves a horrific scar, be it for bad or for worse; and there are games which leaves an emotional scar, making the experience sweeter and satisfying. Do not let the RPG Maker tag deceive you -- To The Moon isn't an RPG: if anything, it's on the far-end of the spectrum, simply because the game has no combat mechanics of that sort. Instead, it relies on something triple-A games sorely lack and aspire to achieve: a player-invested story built upon multiple layers. And the game wears it like a proud dogtag. What should be the focal point is always the story. About two "doctors" that help a man relieve his dreams again, eventually finding out the entire cause of it, and granting his wish of making it To The Moon. The game straddles the line between hope and despairity; loss and gain; tragedy and happiness -- all in under five hours (counting the 2 minisodes which are absolutely must-plays). To The Moon is an all-round experience that leaves you wanting more, and hopes that after you've gone through all the sobbing tissues right by your side, that you still have a bottle of scotch waiting for you once the game ends. Because trust me: you'll need it. Brilliant story, brilliant soundtrack -- To The Moon is one of the best gaming experiences of all-time.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Breathtakingly beautiful.I have just finished playing through To The Moon and I'm still shaken from the experience. I was in tears for a good 30 minutes. It's hard to describe why it affected me the way it did, just as it's hard to write a review/recommendation for this game.At it's core To The Moon is a very simplistic game. You walk around clicking the spacebar to find out about certain objects or to go through hours of dialogue that this game has to offer. That's it.However, this is some of the finest, best, most emotionally touching dialogue I've ever seen in any game, ever. The themes of death, love, loss, disease and inner battle are all addressed so well, it's actually quite surprising. It proves that video games stand on their own as a wonderful method of storytelling, because this story couldn't be told through another medium.As you can read on the Steam page it tells the story of two doctors trying to fulfill a dying man's wish. The pair travel backwards through his memories to see how they alter the future to make his dream come true... And that's all that can be said without spoilers.Unfortunately this means I'm going to have to leave this "recommendation" on a simple "trust me" basis.So, trust me, this is a game you want to experience.These are three hours of your time that will impact an touch you emotionally in a way you probably haven't experienced in a game before.And lastly, this game will really make you think about your life and your choices.There is no one I wouldn't recommend this game to. Even if I don't know you personally, I still want you to buy this game and let it affect you the way it affected me. Hope this convinced you to purchase and play through this brilliant story telling masterpiece.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Time spent: 4.6 hours from December 23 to 26 (at almost midnight!) This review however is done at around 12 am on Dec 27.To the Moon is a highly crafted and excellent art game. Its key points are its story and music, which are both well made and very engaging. Starting off with the art design, it feels like a retro RPG with pixel art and illustrations. These things are not terribly different from other games, but drives the point of the story very well. It can feel a bit bland and like a freeware RPG, but the art is for the most part stylized with the pixel art style and great art pieces with a good retro effect and being well connected to the story.Next up is the music. From the start in the title screen, the music is already carrying emotion to it, and the entire soundtrack is done very well. The music carries an instrumental feel with some more ambient or whimsical touches depending on the current mood. Laura Shigihara does have a track in this game, and it also has great emotion and musical quality to it. By carrying emotion and being well composed, the soundtrack of this game is very good and drives emotion in tandem with the story.Last is the critically acclaimed story. Like most people say and what I did, go into this game without reading any spoilers. The game does make you sad like others say, but also laugh, smile, and keep you on the edge of your seat. Without giving any potential spoilers, it is a well done story with many captavating moments for an excellent game. The gameplay is more like a visual novel rather than a pure RPG. Exploration is the bulk of the game, which is good to drive the story and keep you engaged. Now and then, some other gameplay is given like puzzles to break up the story flow a bit. Although the gameplay isn't much, the story is the game's main attraction that is worth the experience for.To the Moon has to be played to experience it in its glory without breaking it with spoilers. The music and story are strong in this game that they evoke many emotions from start to finish. It gives an amazing experience that people should really try out, for its story and music are well crafted in a kind of RPG visual novel.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2016
												9.5/10I've always thought indie games were just the cheap way of making a game and after this game, I lost that view entirely. I bought this because it was on sale and I wanted to try something new and short. I did not expect this game to be as great as it was and only started it out of boredom. I'm so glad I did. **The reason my hours are shorter than most is because it was played on offline mode most of the time**The story is unique with many plot twists. The company doesn't put too much work into gameplay because it's the story you are supposed to focus on. If you expect it to be a full shooting and destroy everything game, you'll get a few puzzles for your enjoyment. You play as Johnny and has a very quiet wife, and although she doesn't say much she is one of the most loving characters in the game. The graphics are also quite nice in an indie way. You CANNOT play this game in long breaks, it's one you'd want to continue and even if you didn't, the ending is cute so go play to the end anyways. I've recommended this game to three people so far, and all three love and enjoyed it as much as I did. It's simplistic gameplay with a strong story makes one amazing game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Honestly before you read this review consider that I have been playing it for 4 hours straight because I got so caught up in the story.First of all the story, kudos to the guy who wrote it. Although it was confusing in the end it all made sense and it turned out to be a very nice story.Second of all the music, very well chosen and it's worth listening to. Even somewhere in the middle of the game I recall I heard a women singing a song and I really want to know what her name is so I can lookup more music from her.Next we have the main characters, the two mains were really the classic combo that this game could use. One of them is very serious and the sentimental type and the other one is the joker, although another side gets revealed later on in the game. At one moment I really felt that I want to scold the gamemakers for one of the decisions made by one of the main characters. But after completing it I felt different and felt like it was better that way.Unfortunately the movement was a bit wonky. Either decide between using point to click or moving with keys but don't use both in a game. Another small downside is that there are some repetitive mini games in the game itself. I found that annoying honestly.But if you want to play a game with a pretty good story with a twist I consider you to pick it up for the cheap price it is.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A little game that could, To The Moon proves that even with humble beginnings one can surpass the best in so many ways that really matter. It's not held back by its RPG Maker roots, short of iffy controls at times because of mouse implementation, and is one of the rare games made with it that actually show just how much can be done when motivated people take things seriously. There is little in terms of gameplay and the game handles like an on-rails adventure, but the story is what truly sells it. I think the highest praise I can actually sing about To The Moon's story is that it's one of very few games that, as far as I remember at least, actually made me take a deliberate break just to process everything. Subject at hand is handled masterfully and emotions overflow throughout the game as things fall into place - so much so that if it doesn't stir SOMETHING in you by the bitter and yet extremely satisfying ending, you've probably completely missed the point. Or you're not a human being.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												This game is so very touching. It's not realistic or logical (but it's not meant to be either).It plays like a dream. Imagine how dreams can be rather senseless and illogical, but have that special, mystical feeling to them? Well, that is how this game feels like.This is not to say that the story doesn't make sense, because it does (for the most part).So the story takes off with a patient (i.e. Johnny) at old age - on his deathbed - and wanting to fulfil his desire of going to the moon.But how on earth is a man of such age to achieve such a thing?Well, that's where a brilliant duo of doctors (aka Dr. Neil Watts & Eva Rosalene) come in.They specialize in the art of memory-alteration, through use of a sophisticated machine, which is then connected to a patient's head - via a helmet - so as to grant them access to their patients' memory and alter their memories (as needed).The game is played in a chronological, linear fashion (meaning, there's a certain routine to follow), which involves hopping from memory to memory, by interacting with mementos (i.e. items of sentimental value to the patient) which serve as a 'bridge' between one memory and the next & triggers the time-travelling process, within the patient's mind.It's interesting to note however, that time-travel occurs in a backwards fashion (meaning, as you play you get to see the patient at old age first, and then hop back in time to a younger version - again & again - till a certain age is reached).This is done for the purpose of creating a point of 'ignition' (in regard to Johnny's end-life desire of 'going to the moon'), meaning; the two doctors look for an ideal timeframe within Johnny's past to alter his memories, so as to encourage the fulfilment of his dream.Mementos (encountered within the patient's mind) have to be 'activated' in order for them to serve as a 'link' to a specific memory. This is achieved by touching them & going thru a process of solving a mini-puzzle.The puzzle is of the 'tile'-type (where tiles are flipped in a methodical way so as to have them form an image - this is always an image of whichever memento is being worked on at that moment).Also; these mementos are wrapped inside a protective bubble and have to be 'released' thru a certain mechanism, which is achieved thru the collection of so-called 'orbs' scattered across any area (i.e. school, home, yard, etc., ... ) that is up for exploration within the patient's mind.Whether or not Johnny's dream is eventually achieved is left for the player to find out at the end of the game (no awful cliffhanger there, phew!).The way the story ends, does make way for yet another episode (and hopefully this will be the case!).There was such clever use of sound, music and words that created a beautiful experience and atmosphere maintained throughout the whole game.Admittedly... it had me crying. The music, the story... the characters. Ahh... I love when a game has that effect on me - that's why I ultimately play - to have a good time. And I sure did!NB I played this game with a Steam buddy and that impacted my experience positively (it's one of those games that serves as a great way to bond and share the many 'feels' evoked by the story).UPDATE - NOMINATION:This game should be nominated because:- the plot in itself is very endearing (i.e. clever use of sound, music, scenarios)- the plot unfolds in a very original manner- it touches upon real-life issues with a fun sci-fi twist- gets you thinking about life, stimulates the mind & pulls quite a bit of heartstrings!

												This game has the BEST story of any game I've ever played. I read a lot of reviews about this game and all of them said that it had the saddest ending of any game ever. At first I was like pfffft yeah right and I was very hesitant to buy it. I randomly bought it yesterday and played through it in one sitting. It's about 4 hours long. Let me tell you this, this game has the saddest, most amazingly written story of any game I've played, any book I've read, or any movie I've seen. If you don't shed a tear by the time you've finished playing this game I refuse to believe you are a human being. The way that everything plays out and the soundtrack the accompany the setting go perfectly together. I know that 10 bucks seems like a little much for a 4 hour game but this is not just a game, it's an amazing piece of art that I think everyone can enjoy.

I was simply AMAZED how much heart and soul they put into this "game." The score is beautifly done and lends well with the atmosphere of the game. It tugs on the right heart strings every step of the way and I could not close out of it once I started. Finishing it in one sitting is how it is meant to be enjoyed. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												-CONTAIN SPOILERS- This game had one of the greatest storylines added to an 8-bit game. (Short summary, two employers of a company named "Sigmund Corporation" help an elderly named John Wyles fufill his desire to go to the moon.) Now these two are to travel through Johnny's memories collecting energy from specific objects to get to his earliest memories. That would allow them to plant artifical memories, making it seem like he had the desire all along and had already acheived it. Understanding this, I had a feeling it would be another typical game, just a bit different than the other ones. Oh how was I wrong.This story had much more feeling to it, much more meaning. It's so weird knowing how it all is going to end, yet looking forward to the process of getting to that point. Looking into a person's dark past is really heart racing, really shocking. I'd have to say a few of the most shocking things in that game were; (not in order)1) Finding out River had Asperger's Syndrome.2) This should have been obvious but I didnt quite catch it, Johnny having a deceased brother.Another great aspect to this video game was the comical moments to sort of relieve the tenseness. Nicely timed, not too silly to ruin the whole development but not too "ha, not funny". Eva was so cute in her little battle against a squirrel. hehe.I'd also say the artwork was beautiful, and the backround music was a giant bonus. (Especially because they use the piano as the main instrument, no words needed to set the mood. ) For River (Johnny's Version) & For River (Sarah and Tommy's Version) is definitely a recommended song! The only unsatisfying part to the game is the ending. I felt pretty empty and left confused at it. Episode 1? What is there going to be a series of games? Is this Final Fantasy? (It's never final, lol.) And how the screen flashes like they are still in a memory, whaat? Well, it was intended to confuse the audience but it left me irritated. Well enough of me rambling, I conclude that this was a wonderful game and I definitely recommend.Yup.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Although the gameplay is not the best around, I can safely say it accomplishes what it wants to. To tell a story.The music is as great as it gets and the language - the characters' dialog, even their body language - offer a unique story-telling experience, backed up by the simplest game mechanics a game can have. I'd primarily tag it as a novel, always leading only to one possible outcome-ending, thus no choices are made by the player.Great game. Can't express enough how much I loved it. I recommend it for all the people to experience it, though I believe the story itself targets the more grown-up, or, might I say, mature gamers.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												Heart-touching. I've never known a game that could describe such a beautiful story as To The Moon. The music, the atmosphere, the witty dialouge and the heart-melting story of Johnny and River is one that I will not forgot. The ending left me speechless as I was in tears. Never has that happend to me before from a game, nor a movie. The events have made me think about my own life what I should do with it. I found myself relating to Johnny's memories, wishing I had talken a different path. This game is augmented by a breathtaking soundtrack that sets the tone for scenes. The song "For River"/"To the Moon" will be one I listen to over and over while I contemplate my life as I am reminded of this game. This probably sounds very corny, however I speak the truth. Give this game a chance, play it alone and turn up the volume. It will grow on you and you will not forget the story of Johnny and River.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												This isn't my typical game. Between stealth games, first-person shooters and action RPGs, I don't frequently delve into the "interactive story" game genre. I was almost embarassed to put the game on my wishlist, given how cheesy and pretentious the trailer looked.With that out of the way, I have to say that To The Moon does its job really well. The premise is interesting and the execution is even better, with a strong plot throughout that feels unique. The characters are especially well-written. Some have complained about Dr. Watts disrupting the feels, but I enjoyed his humor and I think he kept the game from becoming too full of itself. (Whenever I thought something was cheesy or pretentious, Watts was there to back me up). The later parts of the game were mind-blowing and very emotional. The story is great!The graphics look old and "nostalgic" (which actually ties into the story, if you think hard enough), but are still quite detailed and very pretty backdrops for the key story moments. The soundtrack repeats itself a lot, but is still very good and always fits well with what is currently happening in-game. Actual "gameplay" is mostly minimal, but there are several special sequences where gameplay is used effectively to convey emotion. Every part of the game strengthens the story in a big way.9/10Wear a helmet

Posted: March 8, 2015
												★★★★★ - "Do not miss this game" PROS:- The story is beautiful, you cannot prepare yourself for it.- Soundtrack to this game compliments this game superbly.- Emotional, it can make you cry but it can make you laugh too.- Human, although its fairytale like, the game feels so touching and personal therefore, memorable.- The puzzles are just right, they're no challenge whatsoever but its no puzzle game. They link the story together, never making you work risking detaching you from the story.CONS:- I didnt enjoy the dodging and plant pot shooting part of the game, it didnt fit and stole emotional immersion from the game.VERDICT?To the Moon is a bit of a masterpiece. I love games which are unique and memorable, reminding you how diverse the gaming industry is and what creatively talented people are out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
												Great story with terrible graphics (game runs on a stupidly small resolution with no options to change that). The gameplay mostly consists of walking around, clicking on things and reading the dialogue. But the writing is excellent. The story is about a dying man whose last wish is to go to the moon. You play as the employees of a corporation that is capable of altering people's memories to give them the illusion of having a different life thus fulfilling their last wish before they die. The narrative unfolds in a reverse chronological order as you go back in time through the old man's memories, learning about his life and finding a way to make his wish come true. It's an interesting way to tell a story and it's executed quite well here.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I was fortunate enough to aquire this game for free using Playfire Rewards. What a steal. I installed it and played around with it for about 15 minutes and thought it was just going to be a silly little RPG game that would be mildy entertaining. I was mistaken. "I hate being wrong but love it when I am set straight" - Harlan EllisonThese words proved to be true for this game.  To start off, I will say this game is less of a game and more of a story. A beautiful, masterfully told story. It is challenging to go into why this game is so great without spoiling it but I will say that it has much more depth than it would seem from some simple screenshots. So I'm going to try my best to describe the story without spoiling it. It is a very memorable adventure, featuring it's moments of grandeur, happyiness, silliness, and sorrow. The soundtrack accompanying this game is beautiful, yet a little repetitive. However it works for the game. The gameplay itself, or lack therof, is my main gripe. It consists of very grindy "puzzles" and tends to detract from the story rather than add to it. I found myself often rushing through them just to get on with the story. All this being said, it is still a near perfect game. The director, Kan Gao, did an extraordinary job making sure the game flowed well and felt satisfying at the ending. I would highly recommend this game as a short and sweet distraction from the world. It was much more fun than I was expecting. I await the sequel with great anticipation

Posted: May 4, 2016
												To The Moon is a game about 2 scientists/doctors who help grant the wishes of people on their deathbeds by altering their memories. They respond to a call from the caretaker of a man that wants to go to the moon, and so the scientists travel through his memories in order to alter them. It's very heartwarming and has a lot of depth. I would recommend it to people that love plot, a good soundtrack and science fiction that has to do with technology. It took me a little over five hours to finish it, so there's a good amount of gameplay and things to do.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												To The Moon is one of those games you instantly fall in love with. With it's simple, but elegant design, incredible writing, and thrilling, heartfelt tale. Beauty is a perfect word to describe it. The storytelling is masterful, and complex, and charming. The characters are lovable. You play as the two scientists who assist the man in the pursuit of his dream, and often act as the comic relief for emotionally tense situations. Much of the gameplay is a variation between puzzles and "point and click", however, I advise you buy the game on sale, as its only a good solid 3-4 hours when playing normally without guides.To sum eveything up, To the moon is a game I highly reccommend for people who love a detailed and great storyline, while also having a complex and incredible experience of emotions.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												This game was truely a great experience, and I very much enjoyed playing it. So I would definietly recommend you to buy it, even for its full price, because this is the kind of developer we should be supporting.The game was a pleasent surprise, as it offered much more than what I had expected from a 2D RPG. The story caught my attention right from the very beginning and it never really went dull. The characters were interesting, and I found the music to be very nice and suiting to the rest of the game. The game mechanics wasn't anything out of the ordinary, and honestly it didn't really need to be either. I found the game to be very well polished, and of very high quality, and I would definietly say its one of the best 2D RPG games that I have ever played on PC.Pros:+ Great storyline, with a very nice paced progression.+ The length of the game is just perfect, and it never feels too slow or too fast.+ Well developed characters.+ Great sense of humor, without being too over the top.+ Nice and suiting music.+ Easy to get 100% steam achievement ( if you care about that )Cons:- I can't really think of anything bad to say.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												To the Moon, what can I say about it? The game is absolutely wonderful! It tells the story of a man on his death bed who wants his last wish granted before departing the world. Enter Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts, two scientists who have been hired to grant this dying man's wish before it's too late. You play as Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts and take a journey through the man's life from end to start in this heartwarming adventure. You'll learn about the love of his life, his friends, his family and his one wish!

												I really enjoyed this one. It's more of an interactive story than a game, but it's kind of brilliant how that perfectly fits the story. It's about memories that have already happened and you're meant to observe with minor input. It's charming all around and when everything ties together you'll♥♥♥♥♥♥bricks... or maybe cry if that's a thing you do.Now to the complaints! The concept is bold and it's a great accomplishment that it mostly works as a video game. But while the dialog itself has personality, there are parts of it I really dislike. All of the characters (children and elderly) speak at an 18 year old age level. It's supposed to take place in the future, but they use lots of contemporary nerdy video game and anime references. I like how they try to mix jokes in with the sadness, but the out of character meta jokes feel lame and take me out of it.So I'd recommend it to people who already like games and are looking for something story oriented, heartfelt, and different. I'd like to recommend it to people who are less in to games (because they'd easily be able to cope with the limited gameplay), but I think the in-jokes would be too off-putting for them to take the rest of it seriously.TL;DR - Memento + Inception + The Notebook. There's a 1 hour demo, so give it a try!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
												Yes, this is a sad but thoughtful game. After playing it, I don't even know whether I should be happy or not. Perhaps makers of this game want this reaction. When I entered the house and hear the song 'For River', I can feel the sad inside it. When I finished the first time leap in the old man's memory and meet the old man behind the house, I can even feel his loneliness. He just stand there watching the light tower and maybe he was thinking the old time he spent with his wife. Then every time I leap the memory, I come closer to the truth why the old man wants to go to the moon, and in the last memory, when the old man was a child and went to the festival with his mom and brother, when he went to that cliff far from the noisy party, saw the stars and moon and finally met River, my tears went out, just an accident changed the old man's life. Because that accident his mom lost her mind, he also lost his brother, and the most important thing, he forget the first time he met River and the promise he made with her. River had mental illness but she tried her best to let Johnny remember her. The rabbit, the moon, the light tower, even that toy and bag, every thing was shown to Johnny but he still didn't remember anything. Though at last two doctors finally achieve the old man's dream, but we all know this is just a fake. The past cannot be changed, the story of Johnny and River is still there and two doc can still remember that sad story. And of course as the player I can also still remember their hard and sad life. Two poor patients finally leave this world, but their story won't leave this world. Ehh, I seldom write a article but this game deserve a long article. I strongly recommend everyone play this game and listen to the song 'For River', which full of Johnny's love to River. And at last, just like River said, 'I'm happy now, that's enough.' I hope everyone can find their own happiness through their lives, no matter how hard life is, just don't give up, do what you most want to do, just like River and Johnny.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												This game was truely a great experience, and I very much enjoyed playing it. So I would definietly recommend you to buy it, even for its full price, because this is the kind of developer we should be supporting.The game was a pleasent surprise, as it offered much more than what I had expected from a 2D RPG. The story caught my attention right from the very beginning and it never really went dull. The characters were interesting, and I found the music to be very nice and suiting to the rest of the game. The game mechanics wasn't anything out of the ordinary, and honestly it didn't really need to be either. I found the game to be very well polished, and of very high quality, and I would definietly say its one of the best 2D RPG games that I have ever played on PC.Pros:+ Great storyline, with a very nice paced progression.+ The length of the game is just perfect, and it never feels too slow or too fast.+ Well developed characters.+ Great sense of humor, without being too over the top.+ Nice and suiting music.+ Easy to get 100% steam achievement ( if you care about that )Cons:- I can't really think of anything bad to say.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												★★★★★ - "Do not miss this game" PROS:- The story is beautiful, you cannot prepare yourself for it.- Soundtrack to this game compliments this game superbly.- Emotional, it can make you cry but it can make you laugh too.- Human, although its fairytale like, the game feels so touching and personal therefore, memorable.- The puzzles are just right, they're no challenge whatsoever but its no puzzle game. They link the story together, never making you work risking detaching you from the story.CONS:- I didnt enjoy the dodging and plant pot shooting part of the game, it didnt fit and stole emotional immersion from the game.VERDICT?To the Moon is a bit of a masterpiece. I love games which are unique and memorable, reminding you how diverse the gaming industry is and what creatively talented people are out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I was fortunate enough to aquire this game for free using Playfire Rewards. What a steal. I installed it and played around with it for about 15 minutes and thought it was just going to be a silly little RPG game that would be mildy entertaining. I was mistaken. "I hate being wrong but love it when I am set straight" - Harlan EllisonThese words proved to be true for this game.  To start off, I will say this game is less of a game and more of a story. A beautiful, masterfully told story. It is challenging to go into why this game is so great without spoiling it but I will say that it has much more depth than it would seem from some simple screenshots. So I'm going to try my best to describe the story without spoiling it. It is a very memorable adventure, featuring it's moments of grandeur, happyiness, silliness, and sorrow. The soundtrack accompanying this game is beautiful, yet a little repetitive. However it works for the game. The gameplay itself, or lack therof, is my main gripe. It consists of very grindy "puzzles" and tends to detract from the story rather than add to it. I found myself often rushing through them just to get on with the story. All this being said, it is still a near perfect game. The director, Kan Gao, did an extraordinary job making sure the game flowed well and felt satisfying at the ending. I would highly recommend this game as a short and sweet distraction from the world. It was much more fun than I was expecting. I await the sequel with great anticipation

content:
Posted: November 17, 2016
												There are certain games that leaves a horrific scar, be it for bad or for worse; and there are games which leaves an emotional scar, making the experience sweeter and satisfying. Do not let the RPG Maker tag deceive you -- To The Moon isn't an RPG: if anything, it's on the far-end of the spectrum, simply because the game has no combat mechanics of that sort. Instead, it relies on something triple-A games sorely lack and aspire to achieve: a player-invested story built upon multiple layers. And the game wears it like a proud dogtag. What should be the focal point is always the story. About two "doctors" that help a man relieve his dreams again, eventually finding out the entire cause of it, and granting his wish of making it To The Moon. The game straddles the line between hope and despairity; loss and gain; tragedy and happiness -- all in under five hours (counting the 2 minisodes which are absolutely must-plays). To The Moon is an all-round experience that leaves you wanting more, and hopes that after you've gone through all the sobbing tissues right by your side, that you still have a bottle of scotch waiting for you once the game ends. Because trust me: you'll need it. Brilliant story, brilliant soundtrack -- To The Moon is one of the best gaming experiences of all-time.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												An amazing game. It's not you're typical game, and it will make you question some things about life: like most empathy games. In about 4 hours, this game took me on a rollercoaster of emotions. From Dr. Watt making me laugh with his relevent comments, to Dr. Rosalene's pure determination to get the job done, and finally the tears that came on slowly from the realization that, nothing you did actually mattered, and John didn't really understand what River was trying to communicate with him. The ending might not make sense at first, but after a while of thought or looking at the wiki will only make the tale more heartbreaking. 10/10. I wish i could expericence it again.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												I stopped playing Mass Effect 3 for almost three months before I could finish it when I lost one of my favorite characters towards the end due to my own shortcomings. I leveled Cloud and friends for hours on end to try and keep her from dying (name held for spoiler protection) in FFVII. I replayed the same misison in Wing Commander II over and over to try and save Spirit. However sad I felt, it always was a game to me and never shed a tear. Not even close.Played To the Moon, and cried enough to rival that of my lifetime. Many may have missed the many many nuances of the story, and after completion I suggest reading up on it. This story takes reality by the feet and drags into the realm of Science Fiction. Every element, color choice, and dialogue is carefully placed to further the central focus of this game, the story. This emotional story/journey is the central focus (not gameplay, graphics, or gimmics) and is something so memorable. For me, I felt the tear jerking moment coming... but still caught me completely off guard. Excellent sound track. Bravo. Well done.Will play again when I actually man up and buy tissues.10/10

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
 This will hit you right in the feels....and you'll be glad it did. Don't be put off by the way this game starts, I was, and I beg you to learn from my mistake.After playing through the first 10 minutes or so i quickly declared the game to be "boring as hell" and "A magnificent waste of my time", but when I stumbled upon it in my library again late yesterday evening I gave it another shot....and played straight through the night just so I would get to finish it, hell I even played the minisodes while I was at it.I would highly recommend this game to anyone, it might not give you that adrenaline rush some people crave but it will sure as hell kick you right in the feels, and you'll thank it for doing so. During this game I laughed, I cried, and most of all I just had a ton of fun. The graphis aren't great, and yeah, sometimes the controls are a little wonky, but the AMAZING soundtrack won't leave you any time or need to worry about that. From some of the very first scenes to the very end, the music grabbed me and pulled me straight through the just as well written story. I would honestly tell everyone to buy this game, take a day off, and just play through it in one sitting. At the end, you'll almost be a different person. This game tells a wonderfull story, and does so in such a way that no matter what you wanted to happen, what you expected, what you hated, what you liked, you'll still love it, just the way it was.This game definitely got itself a place in my heart, and I hope it'll find it's way to your heart too.

												Powerful story. Quick game but really touches you. I was very impressed how small the development team was and how much they were able to accomplish. I cannot really tell you much about the game since the story should be experienced as a whole without any hints, but I can say that it is the journey of a man's life and how two scientists figure out why he wants to go to the moon, hence the title.This game probably could be beaten in one sitting, 3~4 hours.It gets you very emotionally invested in the characters, and the plot is very thick and rich with cool details and sequence of events of things that will tie in later that eventually come back to support an idea of the story. The use of the flashback and the overall mood and tone the game creates is unique and special.9.5/10, very worthwhile. Definitely buying the sequel when it comes out.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
“The ending isn’t any more important than the moments leading to it.”To the Moon is a story driven RPG game, developed and published by Freebird Games. You play as Dr. Watts and Dr Rosaline, employees of Sigmund Corp., a company that invented a machine that can create artificial memories by traveling through the memories of the subject. Their job is offering wish fulfilment to dying people, since implanting memories conflicts with the patient’s real memories, only people near death may request to have the procedure. Their patient today; Johnny Wyles, an old man with hours to live. His last wish; to go to the moon.Story:You know that scene at the start of Up where there’s the 5 minute montage of Carl and Ellie’s life from when they were kids, through their marriage, then when they were old? And it’s the saddest♥♥♥♥♥♥you’ve ever seen? To the Moon is almost exactly that.I’ll say right off, if you’re not into story driven games, don’t buy this game. To the Moon is all story, and light on gameplay. If you’re looking for good characters, great dialogue and a touching narrative driven experience, go ahead and pick this one up.With that out of the way, To the Moon is one of the most sappy, mushy emotional games I’ve ever played. And I mean that in the best way possible. To the Moon had me in tears. And if it doesn’t do the same for you, well, you’re probably just a heartless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. In all seriousness, this is a game that will tug on the heartstrings. This is one giant feels train and a half. The story may be a little cliché at times and some moments are a little predictable, but that didn’t stop the game from being one of the most touching gaming stories I’ve played.One of the things that most caught me off-guard about the game was how funny some of the writing was. I don’t think I’ve ever played a game that had me tearing up in one scene, then laughing my♥♥♥♥♥off the next minute. The writing is great and although some of the humour has varying degrees of success, especially some of the pop-culture references, the vast majority of it resonated with me. “FREE PONY RIDES IN SPAAAAAACE!!!” Also, “You never cockblock someone in the middle of a Kamehameha.” To the Moon is a short game, clocking in at around 3 to 5 hours at most. It’s undoubtedly short compared to most other story driven games, but given its price (a steal when it’s on sale) and incredible story, the length of the game is justified in my opinion. It’s a game that’s as long as it needs to be.


The promise. 
A Screenshot of To the Moon
By: Sergio




Gameplay:Gameplay mostly consists of point and click style exploration and tile solving puzzles. To the Moon is about as minimalist as it gets without being a full-on visual novel. Whether you’re fine with that is up to your personal preference in games. Puzzles were fairly simplistic and most of the hidden objects you need to find to progress to the next scene are easy to find. Controls were somewhat finnicky, mostly down to the fault of the engine the game was developed in. Movement and interaction with objects in the environment at times was awkward, sometimes your character won’t move at all despite on clicking the object.Whether To the Moon is classified as an outright game or interactive entertainment is an argument for another time, but given the limitations of RPG Maker and the small indie team that developed the game, the lacking gameplay is mostly made up for. Just don’t go in expecting revolutionary game mechanics and you can get by it.Graphics and art design:Given the limitations of RPG Maker, it's somewhat understandable that most games that use that engine are hindered graphically. “Every RPG Maker game looks the same” is a common phrase, but still one that rings true. To the Moon is no different, it’s and RPG Maker game that looks like every other RPG Maker game. It by no means looks bad, the game looks perfectly okay. The game uses what it has to work with, and from a graphics standpoint, it’s acceptable. Perhaps it could have looked a bit nicer had the game been able to run on higher resolution monitors (the game is stuck at 640x480 and locked at 30fps, something else you should take note of if that concerns you.)Soundtrack and audio:The soundtrack is fantastic. The “sad piano song playing at heartwarming/sad scene” cliché is true, but the music works so well. There’s great use of leitmotifs, songs that will make you smile, songs that will make you cry. There’s so many tracks on the OST I loved, though if I were to pick the absolute highlights they would be To the Moon – Main Theme, For River, Moonwisher, Moongazer, Take Me Anywhere,  Once Upon a Memory,  and of course the absolute tear jerker;  Everything’s Alright.Conclusion:If you’re looking for a game that is guaranteed to make you cry (unless you’re a soulless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥), To the Moon has you covered. You’ll laugh, you’ll cry, you might be an emotional wreck by the ending. Though it’s light on gameplay and some will debate whether it’s even a game or an interactive story, To the Moon is an incredible experience. It’s by no means perfect, far from it, but for experience you get, it’s hella worth it. A beautiful story, fantastic script and a great soundtrack, you should give this one a shot.


To the Moon 
A Screenshot of To the Moon
By: Nick

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This is the best story in a video game I have ever experienced.  The story made me feel so many emotions, whether it be laughter from the banter between the two scientists, sadness from the multiple depressing moments, or happiness from the ending.  The soundtrack is brilliant, fitting the scenes perfectly with virtually no lyrics except for the song "Everything's Alright" which appears near the end.  With subtle hints throughout the story, this game's story is just perfect.  The gameplay is weak, mostly just walking and clicking on things.  If you want a short game with an amazing story, buy "To The Moon".  If you want a game with lots of fun features and lots of variety in gameplay, this may not be what you are looking for.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												The following contains NO spoilers:A nicely told love story about an old man... a man... a teen... a boy and a girl... a teen... a woman... an old lady. The story follows two scientists that travel backwards through a man's memories while trying to find a way to input a new memory.I was surprised by the way the developers proved that telling the story backwards was the right way to do it. It's not only a thing of finding out how it all started but also understanding some bits of dialogue that although they didn't seem out of place, you couldn't truly understand at the time (even when you had no idea that they were important)I finished the game in about three hours and the lenght was spot on, it's well paced and frankly really good. Ps: I really think this could become a good short anime series (about 5 or 6 episodes long), I know it hardly has to do with the review, but it's just a thought that came to me.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												10/10 - One of the best gaming experiences of my life.This morning, I was browsing the Steam Store and spotted that To the Moon was on sale. Actually, I didn't know anything about this game, only that I remembered I had heard the title before and that it had received many positive reviews. So after a little hesitation, I bought it for a mere 1,59 Eur.Six hours later, the game is finished, its only achievement unlocked, and I can safely say that no game has ever touched me so deeply than To the Moon. At the end, I have to admit, I cried like a baby.The beginning was a bit of a struggle: To my taste, the game starts slowly. The visuals are ok, but too old school. There are many conversations between characters I don't know, and I have to move around with those characters a lot and touch items to activate events I don't really understand or care about. After a couple of minutes I thought I would quit, but there were two things that kept me in: the aforementioned positive reviews (I was still curious as to what this game would unfold into), and the music, which is brilliant and beautiful. So I stayed, listening to the music, and moving my characters around, touching items and making conversations.And then, the story started to unfold. Through the eyes of Eva and Neil, I was watching the memories of the old, dying John's life: love, sadness, mistery, tragedy, missed opportunities. And then it hooked me. By the time I reached the fair and watched River and Johnny meet for the first time in their lives, I was filled with so much emotions that I had to stand up and take a walk before I could continue.Maybe when I'll be lying on my death bed, I will call Sigmund Corp. and ask them to grant my last wish: make me go back in time so that I can pay the full price for this fantastic game.Edit - Two years have passed, and my opinions hasn't changed a bit, so I just nominated To The Moon for the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” Award.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												The reason mainly why I recommend this game is because of the truly amazing and original storyline it has along with the character development regarding the introduced characters. This game (story) just never bores you. It has something that wants you to keep playing, something that wants you to explore more of the things that lay ahead of you. Humor, romance, adventure, puzzles and fantasy it has it all. Really worth the pocket money exchanged for the game. Not to mention the soundtracks. They are BEAUTIFUL. The soundtracks are just so overwhelming and so well placed in every scene, that you can't help to live with the characters. To have feels so deep that somehow your heart will bump against your chest painfully along with the pixelated tears that drop down your cheeks. It is unimaginable how much work was put into everything to create this splendid game of artwork, but what I can say is that this was truly one of the best games I've played on the Steam Community. To the RPG and Adventure lovers like me: surely try this out, especially if you're in for tearjerkers.

content:

"But when I'm gone... Who is going to watch over us?"If you have a human heart that beats, then you need this game. The emotion you will have playing this game is intense, it seems so real. The way everything connected in the end, nothing was left unanswered. The message it provides also goes extremely deep, making me rethink everything. Saddest game I ever have played, and I can say without a doubt, the saddest game I ever WILL play. On sale or not, 10/10 would completely recommend. And I don't mean 10/10 as in a lot of people do with reviewing other games today, when they say that to every game that is good. I mean it sincerely, there's very few games like this out there, and I'm glad I got to experience this one. Even the soundtrack is amazing, which I 100% recommend getting along with the game. Anyone giving this a thumbs down just doesn't truly understand the gem that this game is.PS: Be ready to cry. And I mean really cry, not just have tears come to your eyes.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												The music, which has been received very well as far as I've heard (pun!) since its release, alongside the storyline going along themes that people can relate to worldwide no matter the culture and age especially with the underlying themes of the game brings, for this reviewer, a connection or at least the prominent idea of the importance of many things everyone has in common in life--and the simplicity of experiencing existence, and memory.Personally, before playing this game amongst many other things, I felt cloistered and numb to most feelings (primarily due to depression), and coincidentally amongst many other things playing this (or at least listening to the music) helped quite a lot, and felt like breaking this 'shell' of being able to feel less, maybe because of the simplicity of its presentation or the humor [which may be different from person to person, as Dr. Watts can sometimes be a bit too silly], but all these add to the wholeness of detail in the game; lighthearted comic relief, and witty insight in turn. This game would be 'personal' too, on many levels with many people, as far as many reviews can note. Personally, I loved being able to feel--and personally, reflecting on the memory from all exposure within this game brought me to tears.Happy tears.Alongside touching experiences that are coming to society's eyes in recent note (Asperger's/Autism, etc), the game is also presents and showing its stuff rather than telling it all (given the dialogue and such) by letting you experience everything through the eyes of characters themselves, or at least those nearest to them to get their story.The Developers and their team are also very spirited and communicative folks! That's a major plus--including how they treat people, fan and otherwise alike.Would recommend this game fully--alongside recommending it for generations to come. The DLC (including the comic) are also worth the experience! (Wordless--picture only comic)E: My English may not be that good in writing this review! Apologies ahead!

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												To the moon is a very nice 'visual novel' kind of game with a couple of puzzles, but with the main focus on the story.The story is about a dying man that has a final wish (yes, you guessed right, he wants to go to the moon). In this story there is a way to make this happen, but not in a 'story' kind of way, but as if you actually went to the moon.To make this happen two doctors travel backwards through the patients life to find his major 'triggers' that made his life happen the way it happened to ultimately change them to another path.I really enjoyed 'playing' through this game, because the writers not only wrote an excellent story, but also made sure it had emotion, humour and drama.For me this interactive kind of 'books' are a welcome addition to my library.

												A heartbreaking and beautiful story, and an absolute must play in my mind.  This should be made into an film...As for the gameplay itself... The controls aren't the best ( it is worth noting that it's clearly made for mouse play, so don't fret it when your gamepad doesn't work ) and at the start the gameplay isn't fully clear with the links and mementos (which again.. it becomes pretty intuitive), but none of this should stop you from playing this game.  It is absolutely worth playing despite any minor flaws.  As a side note.. there is only one achievement, and it is granted simply for completing the game.  This is actually quite perfect, because the only thing that is important about this game IS the story.  Enjoy it.  Don't expect a lot of gaming as this is just the chosen vehicle for the narrative.  Don't stress about missing anything.. you won't.  Just enjoy the story.  Also.. the music is great.Bonus points for all the nerdy pop-culture references.See you on the moon.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Very interesting little game. It got a considerable amount of press when it was just launched, and deservedly so, as being an oddity in the market. An RPG Maker title without real RPG elements, without a usable inventory, without quests, without fighting mechanics (no, THAT part does definitely not count), and completely story-driven... no wonder many have erroneously tried to argue that "it's not a game".Well, it is and it isn't, I guess, if you use a restrictive and limited definition of what a game is. You certainly won't have a good time if the only thing you care about is graphic resolution or gameplay innovation. But it is certainly an experience that's worth having if you care about storytelling, infancy dreams, the mistakes we make as we grow and how our past and present are inextricably linked.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I went into this game not expecting much out of it. It was cheap and I was bored. A lot of my friends had played it and said good things about it, and there's not much I can say in detail without spoiling, however, here are some criticisms and praises of the game.Criticism:The control scheme takes some getting used to, and you'll find yourself getting stuck on objects you didn't know you could. You can move by either clicking an area, or using the arrow keys on your computer (I didn't try playing with a controller or game pad). The game also tends to be a bit repetitive in gameplay, where you are continuously, until the end, doing the same thing over and over again to get more and more of the story. It's also a pixel art game, so if you're looking for amazing graphics, look elsewhere.Praise:The score for this game is absolutely amazing. I love all of the music from the game, and it is used to fit ambiance of the scenes very well. The game is very immersive in its story, where, if you take the time to care, you'll develop a bond with the characters as you traverse time. The overall story is absolutely amazing, and where the game lacks in overall gameplay, it makes up for in this story. If you're looking for an emotional, story oriented game to spend a couple hours on, this is definitely not a bad purchase. I'd most certainly recommend this game to anyone who wants a heavily story oriented game.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												*sigh*What can I say about this game. Well, I expected more, I feel empty.The story is good, it keeps you interested enough to keep on playing. It has some really interesting and totally unexpected plot twists. The characters are likeable, you can get attached to them. It also has some awesome references that I'm pretty sure everyone loves. Music is also great.Now, there are some small mistakes like I wanted options in the game. On fullscreen the game was slightly to the left, resulting in a black area on the right, wanted to switch resolution to solve the problem. The game also a bit loud, being able to control the volume would be nice. Controls are a bit clunky.Other things I didn't like. There are some holes in the story, I feel there are parts that requires explanation, things that the game doesn't tell you, where I feel it's necessary. I also don't get emotionally attached to River and John, at least not much. I honestly do not believe that they loved eachother. River was cold all game not even caring about Johns feelings, and I think she is selfish, while I don't think John really loved River, looking at the not looking up the illness of River, the girl was just a person who is not like everyone else for John. Since I felt no real love between them, I couldn't really grew to them. The story itself is emotional, but mainly because of the two doctors.I built up emotions, I wanted to cry but I couldn't. I'm not attached to John and River, so I'm not really touched by their death, despite the fact that I'm insanely emotional and it's easy to get me crying.Anyhow, all in all, the story is not bad, if you can buy that the two of them loved eachother, you are going to enjoy it a lot more than I did. It's not a Professor Layton: Unwound Future(the story that touched me the most), but it worths that 4 hours it requires to play it through.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												I recommend this game whole-heartedly.  I feel like I should say that before stating that I don't think it's much of a game at all.  There are definitely occasional game elements - puzzles, plants and zombies (oh, I get it now), and I'm very proud of the 97% hit rate I got on whack-a-mole - but To the Moon isn't built around any of that.  To the Moon is simply a story: an intricate, emotionally honest, well-crafted story that is an utter amazement to experience.  The rest of this (non-spoiler) review is entirely about the story.First off: the construction.  I have one criticism here, and it's that the beginning felt like it stretched a bit too long before diving into the meat of the plot.  Other than that, the story is uniformly excellent.  Characters are relatable and flawed and real, and they are expressed organically through the story - shown rather than told.  The pacing of the plot is excellent, as is the rhythm of the frequent beats of humor against the somber moments.  And the overall arc is deftly woven: nothing happens in the end that isn't earned in the beginning, and it is rather amazing how recurring jokes such as the jar of pickled olives are transformed into something far more meaningful by game's end.Second: the content.  At its core To the Moon is a story about the faith required to have any sort of relationship with another human being.  This is not a point that is hammered in; instead it is subtly expressed in moments spread throughout the game.  Moments where a character is lonelier with someone he loves than by himself.  Where a debate is held over the notion that caring for another can also be selfishness.  Where two people with an asymmetric understanding of each other (and aren't all understandings between two people fundamentally asymmetric?) struggle forward into the future based on nothing more than. . . faith.I don't think I can go into any more detail without dipping my toe into spoiler territory, and To the Moon deserves better.  I will say that it feels like the story has changed me, colored my notions of the world in ways I can't quite define.  Any game that does that deserves to be played.I have developed an (unfortunate) habit of including a fairly inane story at the end of my reviews on Steam.  I'm going to pass that up in favor of - again - simply recommending that you enjoy the story of To the Moon.  Here's an attempt at a topical haiku instead!-----------------------------------------The moon is an eyeAlways watching from aboveNothing else sees all------------------------------------------Yeah, you do better.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Time spent: 4.6 hours from December 23 to 26 (at almost midnight!) This review however is done at around 12 am on Dec 27.To the Moon is a highly crafted and excellent art game. Its key points are its story and music, which are both well made and very engaging. Starting off with the art design, it feels like a retro RPG with pixel art and illustrations. These things are not terribly different from other games, but drives the point of the story very well. It can feel a bit bland and like a freeware RPG, but the art is for the most part stylized with the pixel art style and great art pieces with a good retro effect and being well connected to the story.Next up is the music. From the start in the title screen, the music is already carrying emotion to it, and the entire soundtrack is done very well. The music carries an instrumental feel with some more ambient or whimsical touches depending on the current mood. Laura Shigihara does have a track in this game, and it also has great emotion and musical quality to it. By carrying emotion and being well composed, the soundtrack of this game is very good and drives emotion in tandem with the story.Last is the critically acclaimed story. Like most people say and what I did, go into this game without reading any spoilers. The game does make you sad like others say, but also laugh, smile, and keep you on the edge of your seat. Without giving any potential spoilers, it is a well done story with many captavating moments for an excellent game. The gameplay is more like a visual novel rather than a pure RPG. Exploration is the bulk of the game, which is good to drive the story and keep you engaged. Now and then, some other gameplay is given like puzzles to break up the story flow a bit. Although the gameplay isn't much, the story is the game's main attraction that is worth the experience for.To the Moon has to be played to experience it in its glory without breaking it with spoilers. The music and story are strong in this game that they evoke many emotions from start to finish. It gives an amazing experience that people should really try out, for its story and music are well crafted in a kind of RPG visual novel.

												Honestly before you read this review consider that I have been playing it for 4 hours straight because I got so caught up in the story.First of all the story, kudos to the guy who wrote it. Although it was confusing in the end it all made sense and it turned out to be a very nice story.Second of all the music, very well chosen and it's worth listening to. Even somewhere in the middle of the game I recall I heard a women singing a song and I really want to know what her name is so I can lookup more music from her.Next we have the main characters, the two mains were really the classic combo that this game could use. One of them is very serious and the sentimental type and the other one is the joker, although another side gets revealed later on in the game. At one moment I really felt that I want to scold the gamemakers for one of the decisions made by one of the main characters. But after completing it I felt different and felt like it was better that way.Unfortunately the movement was a bit wonky. Either decide between using point to click or moving with keys but don't use both in a game. Another small downside is that there are some repetitive mini games in the game itself. I found that annoying honestly.But if you want to play a game with a pretty good story with a twist I consider you to pick it up for the cheap price it is.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A little game that could, To The Moon proves that even with humble beginnings one can surpass the best in so many ways that really matter. It's not held back by its RPG Maker roots, short of iffy controls at times because of mouse implementation, and is one of the rare games made with it that actually show just how much can be done when motivated people take things seriously. There is little in terms of gameplay and the game handles like an on-rails adventure, but the story is what truly sells it. I think the highest praise I can actually sing about To The Moon's story is that it's one of very few games that, as far as I remember at least, actually made me take a deliberate break just to process everything. Subject at hand is handled masterfully and emotions overflow throughout the game as things fall into place - so much so that if it doesn't stir SOMETHING in you by the bitter and yet extremely satisfying ending, you've probably completely missed the point. Or you're not a human being.
