number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												This game is so very touching. It's not realistic or logical (but it's not meant to be either).It plays like a dream. Imagine how dreams can be rather senseless and illogical, but have that special, mystical feeling to them? Well, that is how this game feels like.This is not to say that the story doesn't make sense, because it does (for the most part).So the story takes off with a patient (i.e. Johnny) at old age - on his deathbed - and wanting to fulfil his desire of going to the moon.But how on earth is a man of such age to achieve such a thing?Well, that's where a brilliant duo of doctors (aka Dr. Neil Watts & Eva Rosalene) come in.They specialize in the art of memory-alteration, through use of a sophisticated machine, which is then connected to a patient's head - via a helmet - so as to grant them access to their patients' memory and alter their memories (as needed).The game is played in a chronological, linear fashion (meaning, there's a certain routine to follow), which involves hopping from memory to memory, by interacting with mementos (i.e. items of sentimental value to the patient) which serve as a 'bridge' between one memory and the next & triggers the time-travelling process, within the patient's mind.It's interesting to note however, that time-travel occurs in a backwards fashion (meaning, as you play you get to see the patient at old age first, and then hop back in time to a younger version - again & again - till a certain age is reached).This is done for the purpose of creating a point of 'ignition' (in regard to Johnny's end-life desire of 'going to the moon'), meaning; the two doctors look for an ideal timeframe within Johnny's past to alter his memories, so as to encourage the fulfilment of his dream.Mementos (encountered within the patient's mind) have to be 'activated' in order for them to serve as a 'link' to a specific memory. This is achieved by touching them & going thru a process of solving a mini-puzzle.The puzzle is of the 'tile'-type (where tiles are flipped in a methodical way so as to have them form an image - this is always an image of whichever memento is being worked on at that moment).Also; these mementos are wrapped inside a protective bubble and have to be 'released' thru a certain mechanism, which is achieved thru the collection of so-called 'orbs' scattered across any area (i.e. school, home, yard, etc., ... ) that is up for exploration within the patient's mind.Whether or not Johnny's dream is eventually achieved is left for the player to find out at the end of the game (no awful cliffhanger there, phew!).The way the story ends, does make way for yet another episode (and hopefully this will be the case!).There was such clever use of sound, music and words that created a beautiful experience and atmosphere maintained throughout the whole game.Admittedly... it had me crying. The music, the story... the characters. Ahh... I love when a game has that effect on me - that's why I ultimately play - to have a good time. And I sure did!NB I played this game with a Steam buddy and that impacted my experience positively (it's one of those games that serves as a great way to bond and share the many 'feels' evoked by the story).UPDATE - NOMINATION:This game should be nominated because:- the plot in itself is very endearing (i.e. clever use of sound, music, scenarios)- the plot unfolds in a very original manner- it touches upon real-life issues with a fun sci-fi twist- gets you thinking about life, stimulates the mind & pulls quite a bit of heartstrings!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Like many others, I bought this game because so many of my friends insisted it was a masterpiece. At first, I thought I'd made a mistake: while it had an interesting beginning, it seemed to go downhill from there. Up until the end of Act 1, the gameplay was repetitive and, of course, the story didn't make sense at the time.Act 2 and beyond changed all that. Suddenly, the story made sense! The story and the meaning behind it pieced themselves together in such a beautiful manner and in a way that I had never expected. Initially, I thought that going through a story backward was gimmicky and would make the story incredibly convoluted, but it didn't. Going through the story in the way it's presented gives everything new shades of meaning. It essentially functions as foreshadowing in reverse and it's incredibly effective. You see the pieces of a man and a woman's life come together. It's so interesting because you know where they end up before you know all those tender or tense moments that led up to them coming together.By the time the story had ended and the game was over, my heart was officially touched. The characters I had thought a little boring at first grew as characters by the end. Every single character had personality, even the minor characters that the main story isn't about. To me, the ending was satisfying. It brought up ethical issues over what the doctors in the game were doing and those issues are brought to light even further in the holiday special. To some, it's probably a happy ending, but to others it's bound to be a concerning ending. It all depends on how you feel about the events as they unfold.I have zero regrets about purchasing this game. It's been over a week since I've played it, and even just thinking about the game fills me with happiness and reminds me of all the great moments the game had. The story, the music, the humor and charm behind the game -- all of it creates such a positive experience that I honestly don't feel words are enough for it.Sure, this game isn't for everyone, but even if it's not your cup of tea, you'll probably get something out of the experience. And, even if it turns you didn't like it in the end, it's obvious how much love Kan Gao and his staff put into this game. It's definitely a game worth getting.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Where do I start... At first, I thought this game was just going to be some cheap indie that wasn't fully functional and had very little detail to the story... Boy was I wrong about everything.Synopsis: The game is based around Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts who are employees of a company that goes by the name Sigmund Corp, the whole idea behind the Sigmund Corp is Fulfilling the wish of those on their death bed using technology that is capable of constructing artificial memories, and their challenge of fulfilling Johnny's wish of going to the moon. Throughout the story, you meet some quite extravagant and lovable characters, such as River. As the story progresses, you can't help but feel distraught about the struggle that River and Johnny had gone through in their life. If you're a fan of Indie RPG's with a hint of Adventure, Mystery and Drama, I really recommend you try this game out :). The genres work well together which ultimately makes the ending of this game a work of art which I absolutely loved.9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												To The Moon is beautiful. It is not about the visual itself that is beautiful but rather, how the story is presented. In this game, you play as two scientist/doctors who have have a very peculiar job, in which they give people another chance to live, all the way from the very beginning... but only in their patients' heads.In this game, they are tasked in fulfilling the dream of an elderly man, Johnny, who last wish is, obviously, to go to the moon. In order to grant these wishes that the duo needed to travel within Johnny's memory in order to rewrite it according to his wish, all the while learning on why he wanted that wish in the first place.The gameplay for this game is minimal at best. While using the 16-bit JRPG visual from RPG Maker, it is definitely not a RPG game. It strip down any reference to a RPG and can be more related to a Point-and-Click game, or a visual novel. They only gameplay it has is mostly memento finding and some puzzle solving and even then, it is simple.While it lacks in gameplay, it definitely make up in the story, which is told in reverse. It starts with Johnny on his deathbed, with more explained through his memories. As you learn more about your client, you will definitely feel more attached to him and starting to understand his feelings. Through this, various emotions such as joy and sadness can be felt by the players themselves, especially once they understand the whole story in the end. To put it in simpler words: The story is awesome.The game soundtrack is also very beautiful. Nothing can be said to the soundtrack besides the fact it fits the story very much. It does not only fits it but also enhance the experience of the game very much, making it very memorable.To The Moon is definitely not just a game. It is a storytelling medium in the form of a video game, and definitely one piece of evidence in showing that video game can be an art.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												English Review :"To The Moon is a briliant simple game"Previously, several game sites rate this game for its beautiful story. And the game won awards for an indie game category. Come with curiosity, I'll tried the game ... and ... To The Moon becomes one of the melancholy and emotional game I've ever played. There is laugh, there is love, there is sad and sacrifice. Sometimes the game make me smile, sometimes make me sad and cry. For a game, To The Moon becomes one of a tearjerker title that ever exist.This simple game had premise with a sci-fi element become complex & brilliant from the begining. There is a dying old man had a one last wish before he die, he want to go to the moon. So this is a job for Dr. Rosalene & Dr. Watts, they can enter the memory of the patient looking for memory fragment and manipulate it. From the present time to the past until his child era. Reverse driven-story like this, remind me of a french movie directed by Gaspar Noe entitled Irreversible. For the gameplay, this one made by RPG Maker engine but diffrent. This is not a Fantasy RPG like the other one. But becomes an adventure game with briliant soundtracks and story-driven plot. Characterization in this game is so powerful and can give an emotional impact to player. Maybe, if this one not a game. Plot of this game can be a novel. And I can predict, its become a best seller title. But, if this one become a movie. I can predict, its become a box office movie which won several award if made seriously.Rating : 10/10 - "A Perfect Game"Indonesian Review :"To The Moon adalah game sederhana dengan kemasan dan isi yang sangat brilian."Sebelumnya banyak yang mengatakan bahwa game ini memiliki cerita yang sangat bagus. Dan juga menang beberapa award untuk kategori game indie. Dengan rasa penasaran, sayapun mencobanya ... dan ... To The Moon, menjadi salah satu game paling melankolis dan sangat emosional yang pernah saya mainkan. Ada tawa, ada suka, ada duka, ada cinta maupun pengorbanan. Beberapa kali sempat tersenyum dengan plot jenaka, namun di adegan yang lain mampu membuat air mata menetes. Untuk kategori games, To The Moon mampu menjadi salah satu tearjerker yang pernah ada.Premis cerita game berbau Sci-Fi ini sangat sederhana namun eksekusinya menjadi sangat kompleks dan brilian. Seorang pasien lelaki tua yang sudah akan meninggal dunia memiliki permintaan terakhir dimana dia ingin pergi ke bulan. Dan ini merupakan pekerjaan dari Dr. Rosalene dan Dr. Watts dimana mereka bisa masuk ke dalam pikiran si pasien mencari kepingan memori dan memanipulasinya. Dari masa tua, sampai kembali ke masa lalu di masa anak-anak si pasien. Cerita yang berjalan mundur ini, mengingatkan saya pada film perancis yang pernah disutradari oleh Gaspar Noe yang berjudul Irreversible. Plot cerita di film itu berjalan terbalik.Untuk masalah gameplay, game ini dibuat dengan engine RPG Maker namun sangat berbeda. Ini sama sekali bukan game fantasy rpg, seperti yang ada kebanyakan. Namun menjadi game adventure yang dibumbui dengan soundtrack serta plot cerita yang brilian. Bukan hanya itu, karakterisasi tokoh yang cukup kuat mampu memberi impact yang kuat terhadap player secara emosional. Mungkin jika tidak menjadi game, plot cerita di game ini mampu diangkat menjadi sebuah Novel yang saya prediksi bisa menjadi Best Seller. Dan jika menjadi sebuah film mampu juga mendapatkan Box Office maupun Award jika digarap secara serius.Rating : 10/10 - "Game Sempurna"

												Great concept for a game, and decent excution but the controls and the main characters felt lacking.  I appreciated the humor provided by the scientists but I found the story of River and Johnny to be very forced and not relatable at all, when I found out why she actually died  (being autistic, she wanted to build a house next to a lighthouse instead of get medical treatment for some other life threatening condition)  i lost it...as someone in the medical field, this is the first time ive heard of someone with the condition dying from the idocy of their relatives...the premise behind the game is fantastic, i just hate the story that they decided to go with...the DLC fixed this issue largely by providing a new storyline but it is unfinished and is being released in small packages, I cant wait for the next installment for the DLC!

content:
Posted: February 6
												Ahhh, To The Moon. The single best game I have ever had the great honour to have the privilege of playing. Such a short game, and yet so many hours I have spent replaying the masterpiece. To even call it a game is an insult to the perfection radiating from it. To anybody who understands this reference (The Fault In Our Stars), I understand how Hazel felt about the ending to An Imperial Affliction. I need to find out what happens; to Lily, to Neil and Eva, to the *platypus*. I cannot wait for Finding Paradise, despite it being a different patient, we still get Neil and Eva, and their story gets to continue. I can only hope that they get a happy ending as well.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												So, you're on the fence about buying "To the Moon." It's understandable, money doesn't just grow on trees. But, let's pretend you've got some money floatin' around, and you're looking for something good, something stimulating, but most importantly, something relatively cheap."To the Moon" is the game for you.Assuming the ending hasn't already been spoiled for you, this game will lead you through a (mostly) text-based adventure, wih plenty of twists that will more than likely cause you to finish it in one sitting. However, the brief nature of the game detracts nothing from the story - and believe me, the story is worth experiencing.If you're looking for something to think about, something to make you feel, or just something to immerse yourself in, "To the Moon" is a great game with plenty of suprises, incredible characters, and superb writing that will pull you inside it's world. This is one of the few games that I can truly say is worth playing and experiencing.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												This game i would recommend to any gamer that likes a good story since this have exactly just that. The story is well written with a good OST. Many that played this game have gotten emotional after the ending or right out cry just like me.The story is about an old man on his deathbed and his wish is to as the title of the game implies to the moon. Your job is to fullfill that artificially, by doing that you have to dive into his memories to find the reason as to why. You start with his memories when he is a old man then as you progress you get to the memories of when he is in his 50s and then 40s and then 30s and so on. But the further back you go the more you learn about him but you also learnt something that will change the whole thing. Well i won't spoil it, you got to play it for yourselves in order to understand.Pros:- Really good story- Simple but interestingly smooth- Beautiful OST. You get the feels each time you hear the OST again just like Key Visual Art's game.Cons:- Not a game for anyone that doesn't play games for a good story.- Can take some time to get into.9.5/10 This game is a hidden gem. If it had a high budget or got a remake with a much better engine i believe this game would get a lot of attention.P.S this game is 3-4 hours long.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
Get on the Feel-Train!Normally I do not play those "little" (2D) games, but I thought that this game won't dissappoint me, when it is on sale - And I was right.(without spoiling) "To the Moon" is about the dying, old man John Wyles who has the last wish to fly to the moon. The two scientists Dr. Roselene und Dr. Watts have an equipment with which they are able to project a memory in John's mind - to fullfill his dream. And while the two doctors put together the puzzle pieces of John's life, they try to figure out why the old man just wants such a thing as a last wish.At the beginning the story is a little bit confusing but that disappears after some time - so don't get unmotivated!++ beautiful story++ very nice soundtrack (worth to buy)+ nice design+ funny elements+ unexpected changes+ feel-train+ worth the moneybad aspects:- really short (4-5 hours)- the humor is sometimes a bit exaggerated- first and maybe also the second hour is a bit "slow"- 1 achievement (will only unlock if you play the last part in english)To conclude:"To the Moon" is one of the best Indie-Games in my opinion! This game actually triggered something in me, what made me think about it. But not for a hour. No. I was so touched, that a week later, it still brought tears into my eyes. I would be really happy if somebody of YOU will buy this to share this nice experience. A game which is beautiful and sad at the same time deserves: 8,5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I didnt think much of this when i first saw it in my library, thought it was just a plain rpg the same as all the other rpg's.But when i started playing it i was just blown away because the music is so thought through and is very considerate when it comes to the actual history of the game. I was totally blown away by the brilliant and delicate music and history of this great little rpg game.I have played through the story twice, and gonna go for my thierd time aswell. The emotions that builds up while playing this game, just forces you to shed some tears for especially one of the characters. The fine balance between too much and too little story-play is so fine tuned you rarely see such a good of a story in other games, both of this genre, and other.This recieves a good 10\10 from me, and 10\10 would definately play it over, and over, and over.Kudos to the developers of this game who truly knows how to make and tell a good story, and a big kudos to the music composer. This was truly a experience i would love to relive again not knowing what to expect.Warning: do not play through this in public, because you will shed some, if not many tears playing this game !

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												To the Moon will be a memorable game for me. I was brought to it by the soundtrack and recommendations of people that enjoyed it as well. First of all, it's a point and click game, which can make it a little boring at times, and the controls and resolution options can be a little wonky. The small amount of puzzles were quite simple. The whole game is easy, but i really don't think the difficulty is the point of this game; rather, its strength lies in its story and character. The story kept me going even when i got bored of it, and there is just the right amount of suspense and curiousity in it. Perfect amount of suspense, because in the end it all fit perfectly. I got rather attached to the characters and setting. I finished this game in about 5 hours, so i will tell you this game is definitely worth your time, short playthrough as it is. This game is worth the odds. :)

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												This is NOT a game. It is a story that is played through, without much action by the player. Think of it as more of a slide show on steroids where you get to click the conversation along. Very good storyline, I will rate the story a 10/10, which speaks alot. On the other hand, as it is like a movie, the actual playtime is averaged at 1 hour per playthrough and since it is story based, there is no replayability. My take? Get this if you are buying it on discount, but I definitely wouldn't pay a full 10 bucks for a 1 hour game with no replayability. Very interesting note - This game was made using the RPGMaker engine which can be bought as a separate program for people to make their own games.

												Not a bad spin on the narrative-driven "walking simulator" - there's actually a level of gameplay involved and the writing is charming and evocative. The backwards story progression helps and gives a lot of "That explains it" moments. To be fair, the ending is a little bit contrived to the point of deus ex machina and honestly would have had far more gravitas without it. That being said, the ride up until that point was great. Give it a whirl if this seems like your thing!

content:
Posted: February 27, 2016
												"To The Moon" is an indie story-telling game.  It wants you to experience the events through The Good+ Deep Story-telling experience using 2d RPG-style gameplay with cute nostalgic pixel art+ Soundtracks+ Characters were fun and sometimes can be relatable.The BadThe game really has no major problems since it is focused on story. So the following are probably minor issues that I think could've been improved for perfect game design.- The controls are not customizables and are configured weirdly. For one thing, you can move the character using the ARROW keys on keyboard. That feels awkward when you want to use the mouse as well (since the mouse can be used to highlight the items you can interact with).(UPDATE) There is a way to customize the keys by pressing F1 during playing.- Character movement on the level is stiff. When you press once on an ARROW key to move, the character will move precisely one tile for example. You can't stop in mid movement so sometimes it feels hard to take turns.- Gamepad uses analog only. Would have been a lot better with D-PAD option.Final VerdictI highly recommend this game if you are interested in story. It is not a long game and might take you 4-6 hours at most. So you could probably think of this game as an interactive pixel art movie. If you are looking for gameplay only, then I do not recommend you to get this game.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												You need to give the game a chance to get up to speed. The first 30 minutes to an hour feels like some uninteresting attempt at a walking simulator made in RPGMaker.However, once you reach the point where you start to travel back in time through the memories of the dying man, things start to become really interesting.The music is top notch, and brings a well done story to the next level.I had extremely high expectations after hearing about this game. And although it wasn't the greatest story in videogames ever, it was certainly really good, and well worth the 3-4 hours of your time.

												First of all, this is a very informal review. These are my thoughts after taking some time to take everything in.Alright. I have played a lot of games over the years. Be it on steam, console, mobile devices, anything really. Some for more than 10x the amount of hours I spent on this game. But there is no other title that I've played that deserves a full 10/10 rating. From the story to the soundtrack and everything in between, I absolutely love this game. And much like some of the other reviews, I really can't explain why without spoiling the story. At first, I was a little bit skeptical about getting the game. But the reviews I saw were amazing, and all in all it's only $11 CAD. Let me tell you, if you've got this far into this review and haven't got the game yet, buy it RIGHT NOW. It's so cheap and really is something to remember.**As a note, if you buy the game, plan on setting aside about 3-4 hours of your day. Once you get into the story, it really consumes you and you wont be wanting to stop till you complete your goal**

												First of all, this is a very informal review. These are my thoughts after taking some time to take everything in.Alright. I have played a lot of games over the years. Be it on steam, console, mobile devices, anything really. Some for more than 10x the amount of hours I spent on this game. But there is no other title that I've played that deserves a full 10/10 rating. From the story to the soundtrack and everything in between, I absolutely love this game. And much like some of the other reviews, I really can't explain why without spoiling the story. At first, I was a little bit skeptical about getting the game. But the reviews I saw were amazing, and all in all it's only $11 CAD. Let me tell you, if you've got this far into this review and haven't got the game yet, buy it RIGHT NOW. It's so cheap and really is something to remember.**As a note, if you buy the game, plan on setting aside about 3-4 hours of your day. Once you get into the story, it really consumes you and you wont be wanting to stop till you complete your goal**

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game, I really truly did.During the big sale I saw that To The Moon was only $2 and snatched it up right away because I'm cheap. For the years I've known about the game I've heard nothing but great things about it, and while my expectations weren't high, even things I didn't have standards for were disappointing.The gaming mechanics were terrible, within the first ten minutes I had to navigate my way to the house because I kept bumping into flowers. A flower blocked my path. And this continued for most of the game, small objects blocking my way and I couldn't tell what would block me and what wouldn't. Lining up to interact was also hard as most things were off-center.The pacing was entirely too fast, I get that it's a short game, but there was no time to take anything in. Most of the gameplay is walking around and interacting with things hoping to find orbs to break an orb to do a puzzle to get 2 minutes of "character development" (I use that VERY loosely) and you do it over again.  This lasts for 16 memories.  There's literally nothing else to do in this time.The humor and dialogue between the doctors is extremely weak. For 2011 omnomnom and weaboo jokes were probably the norm and funny, but in 2016 I'm just cringing. Neil is extremely unlikeable and it got to the point where I started skipping most if not all of his dialogue because I couldn't stand to listen to him anymore.The horse part with no explanation kept me trapped for a good five minutes,  as did the Zombievas. I didn't realize I could keep using the attacks and got trapped in a corner, incredibly frustrated. The way the game treated River was also pretty terrible.  She had autism yet they talked about her as if she were a bug. With her "condition" and if she would ever be "normal" and to tiptoe around her, I hated John for most of it because he refused to try and understand his wife. He was offered many opportunities to understand her autism and what it meant for her socially, but refused the help. All he wanted was a nice "normal" wife and you could see him get frustrated with River for a mental disability she couldn't control or help. I couldn't take their love story at all seriously because John was such a terrible husband to River. She's autistic, possibly high functioning, talk to her for once instead of hoping it'll just disappear. I just couldn't feel any emotion for anyone because of all these things. I'm disappointed that I didn't like the game as much I thought I would, however I'm glad I only paid $2 instead of the full $10, it's definitely NOT worth $10.However, the pros are: The music is wonderful and River was the only character with somewhat of a personality and she was the only character I could really feel for, despite John constantly bringing her down. If I'd replay this for any reason, it'd be to study River's character more.Update after playing the minisodes: Even more boring and a waste of time, none of the characters developed and the open ended ending  with the possibility of Eva dreaming it all  was extremely underwhelming because nothing was done with it. There's a million unanswered questions and there's never going to be answers to them. I played out of curiosity when I should've just left it alone.

number of helpful: 27 of 52 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												I really tried to like this game; I had heard nothing but praise towards this for years so finally this sale I decided it was time to get it but I really just did not like it at all. So here is why:First lets start with the surface level reasons, the stuff that hurts enjoyment but could be looked over by those who enjoy it:Controls: The controls are just plain bad, if you use the keyboard the map is designed in a grid (as in 1 press up goes one block) however the actual design of the area does not make this clear, causing keyboard controls to feel floaty, as if when you let go of the button the character will continue moving until they reach the next grid block. The mouse controls a little better with characters auto moving to where you click, but when switching surfaces or rooms they will randomly stop despite having more to move towards; overall it just controls poorly.Art Style: I know this one is just an opinion and I'm sure many will disagree but I just really don't like the art style; I can't really put a finger on why but it just rubs me the wrong way.So now for the more pressing reasons why I don't like this:Dialogue: This game isn't funny; the character's say cutesy jokes and puns so so often (especially Dr. Watts) but they just arent funny, I cringed through so much of it. Overtime these characters progress and make jokes less often but it just feels like a blatantly obvious way of showing chracter progression, take a bland character and make them say jokes then stop saying jokes and it will make it feel like they differed greatly.Emotion: All of the big emotional moments felt pointlessly manipulative; often having important bits of information or character motivation hidden simply for a twist later.Theme: I also disagree with the point the game tries to push about manipulating the past to be happy but I wont go into detail because spoilers.Ludonarrative Dissonance: The primary gameplay mechanic is finding these glowing orbs to go deeper into memories, but how does wandering around looking for glowing orbs relate to the themes of manipulating the past or memories what so ever? These things are completely arbitrary, if there aren't enough inspectable objects in the room to attach orbs to the game will literally just give you them for walking around.Overall I really disliked this game, I really wanted to like it, and I have heard nothing but positive regard from others but I just cannot see why. And it isn't just a matter of me not usually playing this sort of game, all of my favorite games are the artsy slow type that your 'average gamer' would hate (Her Story, Gone Home, Pathologic, etc) but this just did not click with me.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I'm generally not a fan of these types of games. When I first discovered this, I debated about getting this game for a few months, And only decided to when the game went onsale over the Steam Summer Sale.The game itself is very nice, I was intially intrigued by the idea of the game, I only further came to like the plot by having the perspective from the two doctors. The only thing I'm dissatisfied with is the cost of the game. Generally what I'd like to think is for every dollar you spend on a game, You will in turn get at least that many hours of lifetime on it. That being the case, The lifetime on this game is only going to span about 3-4 hours. For that reason I find it's rather expensive, The sell price should have been something around the $5 range.So while I would recommend this game to other people, And maybe even a few who aren't normally fond of this genre, I wouldn't advice buying it unless it goes onsale.

Posted: June 17, 2014
												One of the best RPG Maker games I've ever played, with some heavily emotional moments. If you're looking for an actual RPG, you won't find one here.This is a story driven point-and-click mystery game, with great music, and with some creative usages of the scripting tools that the software offers. Well worth the money, for an average of 4 hours to complete the game. Shame that it didn't offer multiple endings, especially given that the game keeps track of your overall score for the minigames, but doesn't end up doing anything with that. An extra scene at the end, as a reward for having a good record, would've been nice. Maybe that's something to consider for the upcoming sequel?10/10, right in the feels.

Posted: June 13, 2014
												Wow, this game is brillaintFirstly, don't be put off by the graphics. It looks like an RPG, but plays like an adventure game.While there are puzzles, which are somewhat basic, they aren't the focus in this game. This game is all about story.You take on the role of two people basically performing Inception on a client; jumping back through his memories to make him think he went to the moon. It's strange seeing the events play out backwards, but it's fun piecing it all together. There were a few moments where they game had thrown me off completely about the context of some events, making it all the better when they were revealed later in the plot. It's apparently also part of an episodic game so I want as many people to play it so we can get the rest sooner.Only bad thing to say about it; DAVID'S MAIN MORPH IS A LION.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												To be 100% honest.. I did not know about the game untill I bought it on steam by "accident".I bought it and tried it and I was stuck in the story after the first 5 minutes of the game.During my stream (I stream on twitch daily) I told my chatters that this could actually be a really good game.What I did not know was that the game had already been out for about 2½ year before I started playing.I will give the game following Puppy-Points after playing through the story twice:Story Mode: 10/10 - A really sad story that made both me and most of my chatters cry like kids who just lost their candy.Game Interaction: 9/10 - The way you move around, talk to other characters, playing around with the "puzzles".. Is amazingly well done / created. Good Job!Graphics: 9/10 - The animations, characters looks and the anumals in the game were really good looking. Animations on the main characters were stunning and you could actually FEEL what they were saying. Not just read it.Feelings: 10/10 - The feelings were following: Happyness!Start of the game was as it was supposed to be. Very humoristic and you got stuck in both Watts and Rosaline at first view. It made me really happy in the beginning that they had humor in this dark story (Yes I read the game info before I started playing). Sadness!The sad feelings came in at around 15 min mark when we started to know what was actually going to happen. When we realized that (SPOILER!!) the Lighthouse had such a big part in the story. Also that "For River" was a song that was going to be stuck inside you for the rest of your gameplay. AMAZING!Anger!Anger was something I felt during late-mid/late gameplay when I was thrown around the feelings for Rosaline and Watts when they were getting so close to their goal. What was I to belive? Happyness again!When we at the ending realized what has happened through the WHOLE story.. I couldn't bare anymore.The feelings fly throu me like a bullet and hit the heart twice.I have never been so sad about something happy ever and I will hopfully never be. Because thatf eeling was to be honest really damn scary.My Total points of the game will however end at 9/10.Why not 10/10? WHATS WRONG?!Following:The game is actually a game for kids / teens. This makes me wonder.. Is the story really going in at younger ages?I belive that people between 10 - 16 will have a hard time following the time-warps that takes place in-game. Even I (25 years old) had a hard time following this. (Hence why I played it twice).Also.. The story ends with (Sry.. no spoiler here).. and I am wondering.. What had actually happened here?Did it turn out well/good for both parts? Or was it just the one main character that actually had anything good out of this?After I played the game I went over to youtube in a flash and started reading about what people were actually thinking about the ending. And my god! So much argumentations about what was actually happening.I have however decided to belive that the good part of all of this belongs to myself.I have never played a game that short who has inspired me or touch me like To The Moon did.If you have not yet played the game.. Just do it. It will take you a maximum of 3 hours (depending on how much you will cry).If you have played the game.. What do you give this game as in points? I am intrested in knowing that. Maybe I can learn something that will make me put that last point into a full 10/10.Worth the money?No doubt - Hands down.Worth the time?Skip a movie.Worth the tears?Yes. Thank you, my dear developers, for making this game. I will play the rest of the games in the series very soon.You will hear from me again./ PuppyStream.net™

Posted: January 14, 2014
												Recommendations are usually based around opinions of the subject matter at hand. For games it has become common to break down the subject matter into categories. Things such as Story, Controls/Gameplay, and Graphics. Each one of these is discussed before giving a general overview or perhaps even an opinion, thus the recommendation. "To the Moon" was both designed/composed by Kan "Reives" Gao, with the help of his development team Freebird Games and Laura Shigihara who also helped compose some of the music. The game was made around the RPG Maker Xp engine. Simple controls and graphics accompanied by a wonderful soundtrack. So, why do I recommend this game? Despite it's simple look and controls "To the Moon" has an incredibly moving story. I won't go into too much detail about it since you are more than capable of reading the game synopsis yourself but It revolves around Johnny and his dying wish. Going into too much detail would do the story an injustice, because to date it might be one of the most memorable visual novels I have played. Don't ruin it for yourself by watching any video or reading too much into the story. "To the Moon" is an incredible experience and I highly recommend it.10/10 ~ Would cry again.

The gameplay itself isn't exactly "Top-of-the-line" But the way they made it, it doesn't need to be. Most games that rely this heavily on the story that I've played (ex: Heavy Rain, PS3) Had little to no replay value, but this one, I kinda just wanna play it over and over again. I cannot reccomend this game highly enough, whether you're old, young, a major gamer, or even if you hate games (why you'd be reading this in that case, I have no idea) you will fall in love with this one. Don't play it without a box of tissues, because it WILL make you cry if you have a heart.

Posted: September 13, 2012
												An absolute triumph in storytelling. It feels real - not in the setting, of course, but in the emotion. The people, what they feel and what it makes you feel is all so real. It is touching, sweet, sad, uplifting and poignant.  I laughed - the game's moments of humor are really spot on. More importantly, I cried - at times due to sorrow and even at times with bittersweet joy. I connected with the characters and with the story in a way few games have managed to induce in me.  There's no fantastical elements here - besides the general structure that allows the story to be told. The important parts are all very human and relatable. It's a deeply personal story.Do you like storytelling? Then you MUST play this game. Its ability to tell a story is up there with The Longest Journey and Bastion. Don't care that much about story? Play the game anyway. In four hours (it's quite short), To The Moon may just change your mind about that.

Posted: May 5, 2014
												What do Roadkill, a dying man and zombies have in common? Nothing! And yet To The Moon crafts these elements together to form such a seamless and beautiful experience that will remain with you long after the credits roll.To the Moon follows the story of two scientists whose role is to visit the dying, and alter their memories of their life so that they can die fulfilled. In this instance, they visit a comatose old man, "Johnny", whose final wish is to visit the moon - the only issue is that he has no idea why he wants to do so. Admittedly this may sound depressing, but the dialogue between the two scientists is refreshingly full of humour to keep things perky.To The Moon is an absolute masterpiece of a game - the soundtrack is unique and accompanies the story perfectly, and although the graphics are in 16 bit style and the actual 'gaming' aspect of it is more point-and-click than anything, none of this detracts in the slightest from the genius and depth of the whole experience. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - worth every last penny. You owe it to yourself to play this.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												One of the ever rising problems with modern games is their simplicity. They're short, utterly simple, and rarely worth finishing. What makes a game worth it? Is it complexity? Pretty graphics? Reward-factors? Difficulty? Absolutely not, because To the Moon is a short, utterly simple game... and it's definitely worth it.To The Moon is much less a game than it is an experience. Although simple in design, the depths of what it achieves is hard to surpass and simply cannot be passed up. You owe it to yourself to play it.Despite being made in RPG Maker XP, I can't say anything more than that it's simply what's used to pass on the story to the player. It's there, but never really makes the player feel like it's an RPG... it's more of a visual novel, with RPG Maker visuals instead of pictures. Is this a bad thing? Maybe, but what if there's something inside this game so powerful that it'll let one overlook anything iffy about its design? What if it's possible to lose yourself in a different aspect of the game? If it's the story, wouldn't it be like getting lost in a really good book? Yes, yes it would.The game's story is easily its most prominent aspect. There is some side-dialogue you might miss out on, but nothing else is going to sneak by. The story in To the Moon is amazing, sure, but are there any problems with it? Possibly. You see, To the Moon, if it suffers from anything, is its simple dialogue. Sentences are often short and consice. There isn't the same amount of detail you'd get in a novel. However, the pacing of the story, the characters, the plot twists, and everything that comes flying at you like a shuttle makes this one possible issue forgivable, if there really is an issue at all. Because in all of its greatness, I have to find something wrong with it. Honestly, it's a struggle...In addition to its great story, To the Moon has an absolutely amazing OST. Again, like the story, it's also simple. I could delve into detail about this like in the above paragraph, but I'll just stop and tell you that it fits perfectly. Every track only adds to the scene. There is absolutely nothing wrong with its simplicity. I'm done talking about that. Its best to hear the music while playing the game. The music and writing combine to deliver something fascinating, so revel in the simple beauty of the arts.And that's exactly what makes To the Moon an amazing game. Its simplicity. It's a short, to-the-point, and beautifully written story. At the end of it all, yes, I cried.In this world full of AAA games that suffer in some regard from being too simple, is To the Moon a game that stands out among the rest? Yes.Should you play it? If you value what makes video games worthwhile, then yes, you should.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												What 'To the Moon' isn't: an action game, a role-playing game, an adventure game.What 'To the Moon' is: a beautiful interactive novel that tells a poignant, human story.Using wonderfully retro pixel art (reminicient of the SNES), To the Moon tells the story of a man's life in reverse, spinning a tale that is equal parts melancholy and uplifting.  The gameplay interacions are absolutely minimal - there are some light hidden object mechanics, and a realitive easy recurring puzzle..... but that's not really the point of the game.  To the Moon is a schmultzy (in a good way) story set against a lovingly-crafted canvas and set to some utterly captivating piano scores.  The game looks and sounds amazing, and if you don't get misty eyed at least a few times then I don't know what's wrong with you.If you loved 'Gone Home', or other recent pieces of interactive fiction, then you should nsap this gem up right away.

												It only takes two or three hours to play through this game, but wow how good it was.  Two scientists take a patient through his life, attempting to rewrite his memories so that he lands on the moon.The writing which starts out hokey, really tightens up once you get into it. Posted: January 14, 2014
												Recommendations are usually based around opinions of the subject matter at hand. For games it has become common to break down the subject matter into categories. Things such as Story, Controls/Gameplay, and Graphics. Each one of these is discussed before giving a general overview or perhaps even an opinion, thus the recommendation. "To the Moon" was both designed/composed by Kan "Reives" Gao, with the help of his development team Freebird Games and Laura Shigihara who also helped compose some of the music. The game was made around the RPG Maker Xp engine. Simple controls and graphics accompanied by a wonderful soundtrack. So, why do I recommend this game? Despite it's simple look and controls "To the Moon" has an incredibly moving story. I won't go into too much detail about it since you are more than capable of reading the game synopsis yourself but It revolves around Johnny and his dying wish. Going into too much detail would do the story an injustice, because to date it might be one of the most memorable visual novels I have played. Don't ruin it for yourself by watching any video or reading too much into the story. "To the Moon" is an incredible experience and I highly recommend it.10/10 ~ Would cry again.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												A recommendation isn't enough for this game, simply put, it's a masterpiece. It deals with the subjects of death, tragedy, buried memories and so much more and although some of the twists may be pretty easy to guess, the way in which the story is told ensures that this does not lower the quality of the game whatsoever. Easily the greatest element to this game though, is the way it creates emotion in the player. The humour is top notch, when something good happens for someone you are genuinely happy for them and most of all, this game is SAD. I have seen many different reactions about the ending, personally, I think it's tragic, but it works and it brings the game to a fantastic close.Presentation wise, the first thign you may notice is that the graphics are very similar to the style of the SNES (in my opinion, it is particularly reminiscent of Chrono Trigger). This works perfectly and after playing through the game, I can't imagine it with another art style. However, despite all this, the one thing I haven't mentioned yet is easily the games greatest asset, which is saying a lot considering everything else. The music in this game is just... stunning, probably my favourite soundtrack of all time, or at least in the last few years. A great mixture of instruments, mainly piano, adds to the games already fantastic environment, and each song sets the tone amazingly and is absolutely perfect for what is happening in the game. Should you buy it? If you're a fan of heavily story based games, then yes and if not, give it a go anyway. 10/10

YouTube™ Video: TO THE MOON REVIEW - GAME GALAXY 

			Views: 907		

			To the Moon Trailer = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sqkJuSV-23U Freeboard Games = http://freebirdgames.com To the Moon is an amazing emotional adventure PC game with a touching story and the best...		

This is one of the most emotional games I have ever played. My wife happened to be sitting next to me during my play session last night and we both were in tears at the end of this game. The story of “To the Moon” is so incredibly sweet and has such great writing it’s incredible. The reason I love video games as we know them today is not only are they fun, but I love getting told REALLY good stories that are interactive. A good story will transcend any graphical style or not having millions of dollars behind you. This gets the label of an “indie” game which initially puts a bad taste in some people’s mouths but I don’t why  - It just means these are games not made by a giant conglomerate or corporation. This year I’ve found myself trying more Indie games out as I’ve been thoroughly impressed- For example - I have always loved the Call of Duty games for their camapaign modes - I thought they were interesting, put you in an action movie, and had some good writing - particularly Black Ops 1- But I just played Black ops III and this story was so terrible - This is supposedly a AAA game but you know what I had WAY more enjoyment with To the Moon and the writing in TO THE MOON BLOWS this out of the water. Seriously. This game was designed on the RPG Maker XP engine - and really holds that 16-bit RPG feeling intact that I’m in love with - Just the other day I was talking to my wife and I was telling her how We will never see another AAA RPG title in the 16-bit style of old Final Fantasy Games, Chrono Trigger, or Dragon Quest games - and that I really prefer that art style when there is a really good story. There is something to reading dialogue apposed to voice actors. I love where voice acting has reached in video games, but a story like this is just really potent when you’re reading it and internalizing it. In this world there exists a technology that allows doctors to implant artificial memories. This is sort of like a mix of the films Eternal Sunshine of a Spotless Mind and Inception - The idea is that a patient will ask for these memories to be created and when they wake up they will have memories of things that didn’t actually happen to them. The catch is that this process interferes with the the patients real memories and the result of receiving this new set of memories means your mind and body will shut down as a result; ultimately the patient will die. This procedure has been legalized for patients on their deathbeds to help fulfill their wishes they never accomplished in life and so they can die without any regrets.The Story begins with you taking control of two doctors. Dr. Eva Rosalene & Dr. Neil Watts as they arrive at a house on a wooded cliffside of the dying Johnny Wyles to fulfill his wish which is To Go to the moon. Although he does not know why he wants to. The machine they bring with them allows the doctors to enter into the mind of Johnny and traverse backwards through his memories with the goal to plant the seed of desire that would alter his life into becoming an astronaut and ultimately getting him to the moon. During each memory sequence you control the doctors and you collect memory links which will allow you to unlock a mementos that tie back to an earlier part of the Johnny’s life which will allow you to jump further back into his memories. Unlocking a memento also includes a mini game where you have to reconstruct the image of the item before making the jump. Although the doctors are meant to remain professional and not get emotionally involved - Both Dr. Watts & Dr. Rosalene get emotionally invested in their own ways as Johnny’s past is revealed. Throughout the game as much emotion as there is Dr. Watts is always there for comic relief and there is a lot of tongue and cheek humor that will keep things light. But the subject matter is wrapped in a mix of nostalgia, sorrow, love, and desire that it still overwhelms you and this is reinforced by the INCREDIBLE Music in this game. Just like I talked about old RPGs having power in you reading the dialogue there is power in the music and the MUSIC really propels and drives this story and will tug on your heart strings. Kan Gao & Laura Shigihara did an unbelievale amazing Job on the music. Seriously guys - it’s incredible. A complete side note I wanted to say is there is one line that really struck me in this game and it’s said in passing, but it really struck a cord with me. As you travel through the memories strangers and other people will be representing as ghostly figures as Johnny doesn’t remember what they looked like and Dr. Rosalene says “The World would be a lot more beautiful if people just remembered faces more.” That’s really such a great line.This game is drenched in love and you can complete the story in about 4 hours. It’s an incredible story and I am definitely going to be shouting this from the mountain tops and telling everyone I know to play it. All I can say is Kan - Thank you for creating this beautiful work of art. I will definitely be checking out your other game A Bird Story next. - If 16 bit graphics can move you emotionally - that’s a stamp of approval that it is a great story. Of all the games I talk about this is my HIGHEST recommendation. Go Grab it on Steam - It works Windows, Mac, or Linux - and get ready to Go TO THE MOON -

Posted: December 28, 2014
												4/4 thumbs upThis is a nice story-oriented game about two doctors traveling through the memories of a terminal patient to piece together a perfect memory before he dies: to go to the moon.  The story itself is about 5 hours long, and because it's so well-scripted you'll be hard-pressed to put it down and not finish in one play-thru.It's heart-wrenching at times, funny at others, and though some incidents might seem disjointed it all comes together beautifully in the end.  Wrap this up with nice classic SNES era visuals, an inexpensive price-tag, a few little fun puzzles, and quality soundtrack and you have an excellent game to play through in a rainy afternoon lazing about the house.The only thing I feel could be improved is including a little more direction in hunting for clues; sometimes you'll find four of the five and find yourself wandering around clicking on everything to try to find the last one.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												"Because one day.... I'm going to befriend one of them"To The Moon is honestly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The story is among the best in any form of entertainment and will simultaneously break your heart and move it. With its amazing 16-bit graphical art style, To The Moon is a beautiful story about love and grief, reminding us how easy it is to overlook the simple, yet beautiful moments in our lives.Also the music is phenomenal and stands among the best in video games! Just starting up the game and drowning yourself in To The Moon's main theme is an experience in itself. The piano piece "To the Moon/For River" is arguably one of the most beautiful, albeit repetitive, songs I have ever listened to.In terms of gameplay, there isn't much to do. You can tell the doctors where to go and what to interact with (kinda like a point and click adventure game) but besides that, gameplay is fairly lacking. However, your main reason to play this amazing gem should be because of its poignant story, not its gameplay. To The Moon is easily one of my favourite games and is hard not to recommend it to anyone who appreciates a good story. I applaud Kan “Reives” Gao for writing such a beautiful story, for composing an elegant score, and for creating such an emotional, touching experience.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												I can safely say there are very few games that have touched me so deeply. I'm proud to say this is one of them. The game made me laugh, cry (both from joy/relief as well as from sadness), and panic. It also made me ponder the meaning of life and the inherent fallibilty of the human brain, as well as the long-lasting effects that everyday choices can make.Granted, this isn't really as much of a game as it is a visual novel, one of which has little to no branching paths therein, but I digress.I truly enjoyed the game's narrative and characters. The chemistry between the two main characters is infectious, and there was more than one time I'd burst out laughing from the banter between them. The references (for the most part) are relevant, recognizable, and genuinely funny. The plot was riveting, and had several startling and brilliant twists. I can honestly say I NEVER would have seen the Joey/Johnny twist coming (and I'll leave it at that, so as not to spoil it for prospective players), and I'm VERY good at predicting plot twists.There are some flaws in this game, as there always are. Nothing's perfect. The list of my gripes follows:1. I wish a lot of the items I picked up served any real purpose through the game. Maybe leading to a secret ending or something? I had that origami rabbit in my inventory the whole game. Not once was it utilized.2. As far as I know, the memento puzzles are nothing but busywork and your amount of moves doesn't affect the game in the slightest.3. The health monitor for your client is apparently just there for window dressing, as I never saw it change unless the plot demanded it, and even then, the effects in the memory, as well as what other NPCs say, tells you of his change in condition, leaving the health monitor to be rather superfluous.4. The game essentially boils down to "hover your mouse over things until you find something to click on". Granted, sometimes you find things that are merely there to set the scene, and that's a good thing, but I'd prefer some indicator on things I can click on.5. Targeting for the mouse seems really wonky at times. In the whack-a-mole minigame, the highlighted box that shows where the hammer is supposedly going to impact seems remarkably imprecise and highly unpredictable. Also, if, on the memento flip puzzles, you click another row before the first one finishes flipping, the next row to flip will be whatever row your cursor is over at the moment the first flipping finishes, and it often isn't one you wanted clicked.6. The animorphs puzzle is wrong. Then again, it's a really minor thing that (as far as I can tell) bears no real effect on the story, so that's a minor gripe.7. They never go into how or why River died. They mention how there's an operation that can be performed, and that it's expensive, but they never really go any further into detail.8. They made River's disorder rather ambiguous. Granted, it was kind of obvious to me, seeing as Human psychology has always fascinated me, but they never mention the disorder by name. I was playing the game alongside a friend, and had to explain to him what River's disorder was, because he thought she was just awkward. Many people probably had to google the author of the book River's doctor gives to Johnny, just to know who Tony Attwood even is.Despite these shortcomings, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who's willing to take the time to get invested in the story and characters.

Posted: August 25, 2013
												When I read about this game, I thought it would be some kind of anime story with some memory exploring. Oh boy was I in for a surprise, I had never expected how much this game would affect me.There aren't enough words to describe how amazing this game is. The story is excellently weaved together. The characters all have very distinct personalities, even the two scientists have such distinct personalities you can clearly tell how they would react in situations. (The male one being the sillier and quirky) Exploring the old mans past makes you relate to him as if he was a person you knew in your real life. It's so easy to like him, but also relate to all of his struggles. There are many moments of sadness where my heart aches for him.The most striking character for me is potrayed with a disability in the autism spectrum. Usually when you see these kind of characters, they are either stereotypically good at math (autism) or they are self-absorbed ragers (aspberger). As I have high functioning autism myself (basically between autism and asperger), there are so many ways I could relate to this character and her perception of what love and friendship is. People in the game are also portrayed in the way they view her, because she really stands out as strange and emotionally distant. But the main character, Johnny, just likes her so much he won't let the things get in the way. He spends enough time with her to understand how she works, instead of others that look at her and think she just refuses to be civilized. Excellent portrayal of this disability.The soundtrack is fantastic. Especially "Moonwhisher". I have spent hours and hours crying to this lovely track. It's so incredibly touching. There are few wordless tracks which moves me in the way this one does. It really sets the mood when you are watching a sad scene in the game. Many of the other musical pieces are also great. One of them, "For River", even has a background story in the game as to why the musical piece is so simple at the beginning with just two notes. So when you follow the story to the end, then hear the musical piece in the various adaptions, it really fills my eyes with tears. I liked the graphic of the game. The old school pixels were all very well done and the areas portrayed all feels like they spent a good time to make sure it wouldn't be repeatetive. Nowhere do I remember feeling myself lost. Each area has their own uniqueness, so it is easy to find your way.I love the way the story is told. It literally starts you near the end, then you tread your way back slowly until you reach the start of Johnnys life, then it is like climbing back up again to find parts that were skipped over during the transition there. It doesn't just end there though, the game offers a final piece to the puzzle with a great plot twist. The game starts out by making it seem the issue is easily solved, then it builds up and you realize there is so much more to the game.The only possible complaint I could make about the game is a mini-game you play each time you transistion in a memory. I just thought it was distracting and not fun. It's over quite fast though.This is a game I would recommend to everyone to play at least once. Especially if you enjoy deep, emotional stories that truly explores the personalities and life of the characters.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												Man, this game...I very rarely write reviews for anything, let alone Steam games. If I wrote a review for every steam game I owned, I'd be here a long time.I originally fired up this game because it has steam cards. I don't even remember how I ended up with a copy. Probably from a Humble Bundle. Regardless, the steam cards enticed me to open it up. With every game I've ever opened for steam cards, I gave it a spin, and I am happy I did.Initial thoughts were ho hum as it took a little bit to get into the game. It was also very focused on trying to get me to use the mouse. Let me say right now to anyone thinking of playing this game, only use the mouse to try and identify items to click on. Move around with the keyboard, it'll make things much easier on you.Initial thoughts aside, I trudged on as I watched my steam inventory tick up on the cards collected. However, as I got deeper and deeper into the game, I found myself fascinated as story events started to reveal. There was quirky humor, shocking reveals, and sad moments. However, the story wraps itself up well and I found myself amazed as I looked back, picking up on small things that happened with no reasoning until things revealed through the ending.The story flows together well. The soundtrack fits in perfectly. The characters have enough depth to keep them interesting, without being overbearing. Overall, this game is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone. I'm not normally an artsy fartsy story telling game kinda guy, but this one was fantastic. Just get ready for tears, because holy crap that reveal.Now if you excuse me, I need to go play 12 hours of Street Fighter to make up for the emotional carnage this game has played on me. :D

VirtuesTo the moon is a story about the life a couple has shared and all the friends, love, hardships and ceremony that entails. This game has it's sights set on your feels and you may find a few things quite touching.The gameplay is generally watching canned bits of plot, proceeding to explore the area to find 5 colored orbs, & locating a memento. Once you've done this and located the memento you break a barrier around the memento with the orbs and finish things off with a tile flipping puzzle. You then move on to the next area and repeat the whole process.I enjoy the humor in this game quite a bit. It's a good mix of cornball, referential, and just plain odd.PitfallsThe game doesn't seem to support multiple resolutions or even the steam overlay. Screenshots don't work well because of this. I'm used to taking an excess of screenshots during gameplay and constantly found myself missing the ability to do so easily.I experienced an odd glitch during the course of my playthrough in which I became capable of walking on any surface of the current screen. I was forced to reload due to inability to interact with anything at that point though.The controls feel a bit loose an imprecise on a wireless xbox 360 controller. The D-pad cannot even be used in an attempt to counter this frustration. You are limited to the left analog joystick. It's necessary to utilize the mouse for the tile flipping puzzle sections. Near the end of the game there's some different gameplay mechanics that I just switched entirely to keyboard in order to better aid in progression.Spoilerific ShortI felt the game could've ended appropriately shortly after finding out about the death of the twin brother. Instead the game continues trying to right wrongs Quantum Leap style inside the dying seniors brain. This makes sense only in the context of the altruistic attitude of Dr. Rosalene. I don't feel it actually helps the story. Instead of just discovering what actually had happened in the past and bringing it to the surface to be faced she retcon's the past and tries to remedy it with a pretty bow of modified memories. This left the ending feeling kind of lame and predictable to me.All told I rather enjoyed this game despite any issues I had with it.70\100

Posted: March 6, 2016
												To the Moon is an engaging, original, and emotional story delivered in game form using the RPG Maker engine. The player follows along as two scientists delve into a dying man's mind in order to fulfill his last wish of going to the moon. It is told very well with good music, enjoyable writing, and some lackluster humor. Altogether, it's an enjoyable ride that I recommend to those less interested in a typical game, but playing along through a good story.

Posted: January 30, 2014
												"Because one day.... I'm going to befriend one of them"To The Moon is honestly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played. The story is among the best in any form of entertainment and will simultaneously break your heart and move it. With its amazing 16-bit graphical art style, To The Moon is a beautiful story about love and grief, reminding us how easy it is to overlook the simple, yet beautiful moments in our lives.Also the music is phenomenal and stands among the best in video games! Just starting up the game and drowning yourself in To The Moon's main theme is an experience in itself. The piano piece "To the Moon/For River" is arguably one of the most beautiful, albeit repetitive, songs I have ever listened to.In terms of gameplay, there isn't much to do. You can tell the doctors where to go and what to interact with (kinda like a point and click adventure game) but besides that, gameplay is fairly lacking. However, your main reason to play this amazing gem should be because of its poignant story, not its gameplay. To The Moon is easily one of my favourite games and is hard not to recommend it to anyone who appreciates a good story. I applaud Kan “Reives” Gao for writing such a beautiful story, for composing an elegant score, and for creating such an emotional, touching experience.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												"To The Moon" is very much a game that is a greater than the sum of its parts. Individually I don't think they are uniquely powerful in anyway. But as a whole this game is brilliant. Its a well put together experience with the narrative and music really capturing you and taking you on an adventure as you go through the world and story in the game. This is a game I really can't reccomend enough and I assure you that you will have some kind of emotional response. My response from the game, was that I actually had to stop the game maybe a third of the way through and call my mother. I just felt compelled to do it, and I'm pretty sure anyone who plays the game is going to get a similarly strong reaction to the game.If you want to read a longer review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/09/to-moon.html.

Posted: August 25, 2013
												When I read about this game, I thought it would be some kind of anime story with some memory exploring. Oh boy was I in for a surprise, I had never expected how much this game would affect me.There aren't enough words to describe how amazing this game is. The story is excellently weaved together. The characters all have very distinct personalities, even the two scientists have such distinct personalities you can clearly tell how they would react in situations. (The male one being the sillier and quirky) Exploring the old mans past makes you relate to him as if he was a person you knew in your real life. It's so easy to like him, but also relate to all of his struggles. There are many moments of sadness where my heart aches for him.The most striking character for me is potrayed with a disability in the autism spectrum. Usually when you see these kind of characters, they are either stereotypically good at math (autism) or they are self-absorbed ragers (aspberger). As I have high functioning autism myself (basically between autism and asperger), there are so many ways I could relate to this character and her perception of what love and friendship is. People in the game are also portrayed in the way they view her, because she really stands out as strange and emotionally distant. But the main character, Johnny, just likes her so much he won't let the things get in the way. He spends enough time with her to understand how she works, instead of others that look at her and think she just refuses to be civilized. Excellent portrayal of this disability.The soundtrack is fantastic. Especially "Moonwhisher". I have spent hours and hours crying to this lovely track. It's so incredibly touching. There are few wordless tracks which moves me in the way this one does. It really sets the mood when you are watching a sad scene in the game. Many of the other musical pieces are also great. One of them, "For River", even has a background story in the game as to why the musical piece is so simple at the beginning with just two notes. So when you follow the story to the end, then hear the musical piece in the various adaptions, it really fills my eyes with tears. I liked the graphic of the game. The old school pixels were all very well done and the areas portrayed all feels like they spent a good time to make sure it wouldn't be repeatetive. Nowhere do I remember feeling myself lost. Each area has their own uniqueness, so it is easy to find your way.I love the way the story is told. It literally starts you near the end, then you tread your way back slowly until you reach the start of Johnnys life, then it is like climbing back up again to find parts that were skipped over during the transition there. It doesn't just end there though, the game offers a final piece to the puzzle with a great plot twist. The game starts out by making it seem the issue is easily solved, then it builds up and you realize there is so much more to the game.The only possible complaint I could make about the game is a mini-game you play each time you transistion in a memory. I just thought it was distracting and not fun. It's over quite fast though.This is a game I would recommend to everyone to play at least once. Especially if you enjoy deep, emotional stories that truly explores the personalities and life of the characters.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												Man, this game...I very rarely write reviews for anything, let alone Steam games. If I wrote a review for every steam game I owned, I'd be here a long time.I originally fired up this game because it has steam cards. I don't even remember how I ended up with a copy. Probably from a Humble Bundle. Regardless, the steam cards enticed me to open it up. With every game I've ever opened for steam cards, I gave it a spin, and I am happy I did.Initial thoughts were ho hum as it took a little bit to get into the game. It was also very focused on trying to get me to use the mouse. Let me say right now to anyone thinking of playing this game, only use the mouse to try and identify items to click on. Move around with the keyboard, it'll make things much easier on you.Initial thoughts aside, I trudged on as I watched my steam inventory tick up on the cards collected. However, as I got deeper and deeper into the game, I found myself fascinated as story events started to reveal. There was quirky humor, shocking reveals, and sad moments. However, the story wraps itself up well and I found myself amazed as I looked back, picking up on small things that happened with no reasoning until things revealed through the ending.The story flows together well. The soundtrack fits in perfectly. The characters have enough depth to keep them interesting, without being overbearing. Overall, this game is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone. I'm not normally an artsy fartsy story telling game kinda guy, but this one was fantastic. Just get ready for tears, because holy crap that reveal.Now if you excuse me, I need to go play 12 hours of Street Fighter to make up for the emotional carnage this game has played on me. :D

Posted: September 1, 2015
												I loved this deeply emotional and philosophical game. The themes are very accessible in terms of the common human experience they explore, yet they are presented with very interesting nuance and complexity. The Memento-like mechanic of moving backwards through time in vignettes works really well to create a solid narrative suspense.The minisodes are not as good. They explore the social implications of the technology that is at the base of the game as well as some mystery about the main characters, which is interesting, but the gameplay is weak, involving a lot of back and forth between screens.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I always liked pros and cons lists for reviews.  Here's my attempt at a good one (sorry about the crappy formatting, I can't figure out how to clean it up):Pros: Tear-jerker.  I cried.  Most people that played this cried.  Those that say they didn't cry, probably cried. Creative story telling!  It's such a well-written game.  Because of it's unorthodox approach it keeps you interested throughout the game.  Simple game mechanics.  It's practically a point&click adventure.  Retro graphics pull you in.  The game is simple but looks beautiful.  A lot of love went into piecing this game together.  Short.  You can finish this game in one sitting.   The music is fantastic.  This game has such a great soundtrack.  Some games have good background music, then there's those rare gems where the background music might as well be another character in the game since it plays such a huge role.Cons: Clunky unresponsive controls at times.  I got stuck a lot. Humor just didn't work with me.  The game presents such a beautiful premise about love and regret so the humor at times felt out of place and awkward.  Specifically the male doctor.  I feel like the game would've been much better without Dr. Watts.  Gameplay, because it's so simple, feels repetitive by the time you reach the final act.   I don't really think this is a con, but I can't list it as a pro:  The game isn't suited for younger audiences.  I feel like quality of story-telling this game provides would be wasted on a younger person who can't relate to the themes in this game.   The ending of the game will leave you with questions and you will want to know more about the characters, and realizing they're not real people will make you sad.All-in-all, this game was a treat.  It got such good reviews and I'm glad I finally tried it.  Definitely recommend it.

Posted: October 28, 2012
												A strange combination of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Citizen Kane," and a push puzzle game. Which might sound terrible, but the results are pretty awesome. Although there are mini-puzzles to solve, it's really more an "interactive story" than a game, per se, but the "story" elements are top notch and even kind of revolutionary, considering that this was made in RPG Maker. It's rare that any piece of storytelling uses its medium to the fullest to achieve its ends so well.It is heavy on the sentimentality at times, but usually it's smart enough to pull back with a bit of humor, or a non-sequitor, or just a genuinely well observed piece of writing before things venture into "maudlin" territory. Over all, though, it is very well written.
