												This game, really, is just one notch above a visual novel in terms of all round interactivity.  However, I don't see that as a bad thing. The story is worth the price of admission here.  Without spoiling anything, the writing has all the tenants of a professionally honed story.  Comedy, tragedy, mystery and a strong narrative that constantly makes the player want to know what will happen next. Thankfully beatable in one sitting, as you will very likely not want to stop once the game has its talons in you.The characters are fantastically realized, with some subtle and very subtle details for the eagle eyed player to pick up on some of the finer details of things. The true power, in my opinion, of a great story is not only to make the audiance feel; but also to reflect.This charming, masterful jewel of a game should be played by anyone who claims games are an artform.  It shines on its own. However, in a sea of macho frat-boy shooters and gritty action games, it's all the brighter.

												This game is one of the most beautiful games I have every played. If you have not yet experienced this wonderful, heartfelt story, then get your butt in gear and play it. Let me be upfront and say this. I am not an emotional guy. I don't every cry. Over anything. But, this game had me crying by the time the credits rolled. They were legit tears. Now, onto the game. This is not like any other game you have played. There is no action, no battles. Instead, all you have is an absolutely breathtaking adventure though a man's life. Never before have I experienced such a beutiful thing. I felt like he was a real person with an actual life. And not just another character sprite. The character design in this game is fantastic. Everyone is so well thought out and everything is so well written that you can't help but love all of the characters. This music in this game is also beautiful. Every song is wonderful. When you buy this, don't forget to add the soundtrack. It is well worth the money.In conclusion, this game is more than a game. It is a journey through a man's life. You see his happy times. His sad times. And everything inbetween. You need to buy and play this game. It will make you laugh and cry. Even though this game is only 10 dollars, I would have happily paid 60 for it. It is that good. Please, but this game and enjoy.

Posted: March 21, 2015
												To the moon, is an indie game that will take you on an emotional roller coaster. This game with it's story, and execution will make the biggest of gaming men choke up with this beautifully story. Are you ready to ride this roller coaster of feels?Game play: 5While this game is a very story driven, it kinda of lacks in any real game play. You run around as one of the two main characters either in the dying old man johnny's memorys or around his house and outside of it.While inside the his memorys you are task to find key pieces to his memorys after each scene that plays out to unlock earlier memorys. Pretty simple, you look for the “shines” that shows up. After each memory chapter you are given a small puzzle of flipping tiles of a picuture to complete the memory. Overall the game play isn't the main focus here.Story 10The story takes place with an the old man named, johnny, who is on his death bed with only one wish. To go to the moon.  The two main characters you follow are, Dr. Eva Rosalene and Dr. Neil Watts who are from the Sigmund Corp. who has technology that altar the memory’s of people. They usely use the technology on people who are dying to grant them one last wish. It is the job of Rosalene, and Watts to altar johnny's memory to send him to the moon. While digging deep into the memory’s of Johnny you find out about his wife who passed away years ago. Who has had mental problems who befriends a light house.  You also find out more about his pass on why he wants to go the moon even though he doesn't know himself. You'll end up meeting other characters from his, from his childhood to his aduit life who plays a big role in his life. With some dark twist.This game proves that sometimes isn't not always about having the best game play or graphics to have a compelling story to get you immersed in whats going on.Graphics: 9This game goes with a 16-bit graphic style, with mostly bright and colorful graphics mix with some dark looking graphics to set up each scene nicely. Ir's like playing a classic Super Nintendo game. They paid attention to details to make sure they where fitting for the story thats unfolding in front of your eyes.Music: 9The music is well placed and helps to set the mood for each scene. The music goes hand and hand with the story. They did a great job in matching the music to how they wanted you to feel at that current moment. They also did a great job on the music overall. Having a great story and music can mean all the difference on how well a game like this could do, over all the music mixes well with the story and adds a unique experience that you wont find in many other games. Final Though:I found this game one of the best story driven indie games that I have ever played. The story gets really deep and it will touch most peoples hearts, While giving you a lot of overwhelming feelings that you though you didn't have. The story is a sad story, and can make almost anyone cry or at least choke up. I can safely say that I can compare this to the aeris death scene in final fantasy VII when it comes to emotional feelings.As soon as I started playing. I was immersed in the story with in the first 15 minutes or so. I didn't even want to get up for anything. I only got up one time to use the bathroom, even then I was holding it in for at least an hour before hand. I beat this game in one sitting from start to end. I won't lie to you. I was crying by the end. I remember walking out of my room and my roommates asking why are my eyes so red and I said back to them “im just really tired I didn't get much sleep last night”.If you are wanting a heavy story driven game, then this game WILL be for you. There isn't any real amazing game play here but the story makes up for it ten fold. So for the people who are more about action style games, don't bother in picking up this game you'll most likely find it boring and not to your liking. This game is just overall amazing plain and simple! It's a MUST buy for any story driven game fans out there.Final Score: 10For more reviews and other fun stuff check out my tumblr. www.rogue32807.tumblr.com

Posted: March 31, 2014
												To the Moon is a fantastic game. It's a story about two people named Dr. Rosaline and Dr. Watts and they give people a last chance to live out their final wish through their memories and make them think they actually did it. The patient they are currently working on is a man named Johnny whose final wish is to go to the moon. He doesn't remember why, but that's all he wants to do.Simple right? No, his story goes far back to his childhood and you must travel through the years of his life, find out why he wants to go to the moon, and give it to him.The story is fantastic, the soundtrack is great too, and characters are likable and memorable. It is also a game that will tug at your heart strings as you journey along. It is a very emotional game, and I bet you will be tearing up at the end at how good it is.Pick it up now and play through a fantastic experience. Also get the soundtrack too because it too is also great.

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I first came across this game when I was younger, when I watched PewDiePie play it four years ago. I was 14 and completely moved, marathoning the entire series in one night, until about four in the morning. The song that Johnny plays stuck with me for days afterwards, along with the heartbreakingly bittersweet story.Then, a few years later when I was 16, I remembered the game fondly but I had mostly forgotten about it when I saw in my subscribtion feed that Markiplier had begun playing it, and I was overwhelmed with emotion. I was older, and some things that happened in the game had begun to happen in my life, and the game went from "completely moving" to "soul crushing masterpiece". My brother and I watched the game together, and despite only being in piano lessons for about three months, I began learning the songs.Now, at 18, "For River" is a song that my entire family asks me to play at every gathering, especially my Nana, whose husband is very ill. I wish I could tell her what that song means, because everyone, especially her, should know. This game is brilliant. It's heartbreaking, bittersweet, and emotional. It manages to crush your soul while also providing light comic relief, until you're left sobbing with a smile, gasping for air through your laugh-crying while you text your loved ones that you love them.

Posted: July 16, 2015
 To the Moon  brings forth laughter and tears: it is at once light-hearted and heart-rending; its ambivalence, its fancy, its tame obscurity are remarkable; it is witty and laden with quaint allusions and references that produce at least a few smiles; the game's music is beautiful and truly interwoven with its scenes and emotions; visually, it is aesthetically and emotionally fitting (I think) to the story it tells; because of its great human depth and winged fantasy, it feels almost palpable, as though its depiction of joy and sorrow (mingled with high wishes and hopes, and a bit of life's complexities, ambiguities and contradictions) made up its soul; the characters feel very much alive, and the fact that one must imagine their voices (with their subtle intonations) gives it a special charm, especially when softly directed by the superb score; the narrative and its gentle windings, the tender symbolism and the plentiful details throughout (some telling, some cryptic) are also excellent; (the two minisodes are especially revelatory, intriguing and puzzling); doubtless, a most memorable piece.

												This game is simply humorous and enlighting. The fact the you get to make an elder man's goal become "reality", or at least change his past for the better, is just beautiful. I also love how this game is named after a heavenly body, which in this case is the moon, and how this game includes things to do with astronomy! This game is certainly an outlier from every other video game I've played throughout my life. The OST is beautiful and FABULOUS! The piano music is amazing and very grand. I also love the music box version of Everything's Alright. There's nothing to hate when it comes to its OST and sound FX. Everything blends in amazingly and correctly. The graphics are better than what I expected! HQ graphics. The way Johnny's grand piano was designed is so mind blowing and perfect in every way. The way the lighthouse, "Anya", was designed was also giving it the perfect touch to the outside scenery of the cliff. And the characters didn't look crippled, they seemed normal and "human like". The animals were so cute and so life-like, too. They all had perfect figures and their limbs were proportionate. This is game is honestly my favorite game! To The Moon is a game that I didn't expect much of, but ended up being quite possibly my favorite game. This game is absolutely worth full priceI could say some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t here about how "To The Moon tells a masterfully orchestrated tale of humanity: Remembering who you are and what you mean to those who love you" and, to be fair, it does. The problem is that there's just nothing I can really say to make you play this game other than this: Trust me. It's short, it's sweet, and maybe a little salty from all the tears, and it should be at the very top of the "To Play:" list for anyone that enjoys a good story. Hell, for anyone because it tells a story that's relevant to all of us. The StoryThis game doesn't have a story. it is a story, but that's what makes it so great. The story focuses on a man named Johnny, and his final wish: to go to the moon. Now, that's all the detail I'm going to tell you, because [insert ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about experiencing the story here]. I mean, yeah, that's what makes a good story, a great story. It's also probably why I liked this game so much to be honest, because I went into it fully blind. I picked it up in a hmble bundle, like, years ago, and just played it. I have to say, it was not what I was expecting. I was originally gonna put this in that last paragraph, but went on a tanget that I just dont want to take the time to move it somewhere else. ANYWAY, let's move on. This story is one of humanity and unconditional love. Well, kinda. At least on the unconditional love part. It is most definitely a story about humanity. One that teaches that you need to remember who you are and what you mean to those who love you (which, conviniently, is the same fluffy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that I said I wasn't gonna put in here. So I'm a liar. Sue me.). Something that I know that a lot of people need to hear.And it's just ♥♥♥♥ing good.The GameplayIt's not much. RPG Maker isometric perspective. It doesn't need much though. It's a story. A good one. (see above)I don't even know why I added this sectionThe MusicYes.In all seriousness, the soundtrack is great. One of the best things about this game. You can get it on steam  or on Bandcamp[freebirdgames.bandcamp.com]My personal reccomendations are Everything's Alright and any version of For RiverRantI. ♥♥♥♥ING. Love. This game. That is all.Hey, and if you like this there are other games from Freebird on steam. You can get Bird Story here  or, next summer, you can get Finding Paradise here.

Posted: July 20, 2014
												After almost two years, I finally got around to playing "To the Moon". It's billed as an adventure game, but is really just a wonderful story told through JRPG mechanics.  Great pixel art, good scripting and a wonderful soundtrack all make the experience enjoyable and very touching.  It's a bit of a slow burn, at first, but once you get past the story setup, you'll be hard pressed to stop playing until the end."To the Moon" will tug at your heart in surprising ways.  What are we and what is life, but the sum total of our memories and experience?  And, at the end of your life, if you could change something from that experience, would you?  And at what cost?It's really thought-provoking stuff, and is told in a way that will make you smile, make you reflect on your life...and break your heart.  Start to finish is only about three hours and, at the end, you'll get that same bittersweet feeling as when you finish a wonderful novel.

Posted: July 17, 2014
												I loved this game. A heart-warming story with a great soundtrack, a bit of humor and some interesting questions. Gameplay is quite linear and a bit repetitive, but I really enjoyed the ride. It is also a bit on the short side, which is good, considering the mechanics. The story makes it worth it, and I really hope there is a sequel or a new chapter in the future. Definitely one of the best indie games I've played in a while. Just remember the game is more of an interactive story than anything else (and I happen to like interactive stories), so if that's your cup of tea, then this is definitely recommended. I'll make sure to recommend this to my friends!

Posted: July 25, 2014
												In a nutshell, "To the Moon" is the story of two doctors looking to fulfill the wish of a dying man named Johnny. His wish is to go, you guessed it, to the moon. The problem with that is he doesn't know why and it's up to the two doctors to find out and they do this by going into his memories. I won't spoil any of the plot for you but the journey is one well worth taking. I wouldn't exactly call "To the Moon" a game per se. You basically look around the level for fragments of a memory which trigger a memento that helps you reach the next memory. After you trigger the memento, you have to do some light puzzle solving. Sometimes, you will have to do other things but this is the definiton of a casual game. There's no time limits, no right or wrong way to do things and you WILL eventually fulfill Johnny's wish to get to the moon. That's why I'd call this more of a visual novel than a game. The story is really what sucks you in. It's almost a nuisance to go through the gameplay because you just want to find out what happens. And I will say, this game about 80% in throws you a massive curveball I didn't see coming. Like System Shock 2 - SHODAN type curveball. Overall I'd recommend "To the Moon" for it's wonderful story of love and loss and the superb soundtrack. Yes, you can loosely call this a "game" but it's definitely worth a playthrough if you enjoy good stories. 7.5/10 from me.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												To the Moon is a beautiful short story game where you work through the main protagonists memories, heading back to when he was a child to grant him his last wish of going to the moon. Your time is spent searching for memory links to learn parts of the main protagonists life and his counterpart, in an 8 bit world. Posted: May 5, 2014
												What do Roadkill, a dying man and zombies have in common? Nothing! And yet To The Moon crafts these elements together to form such a seamless and beautiful experience that will remain with you long after the credits roll.To the Moon follows the story of two scientists whose role is to visit the dying, and alter their memories of their life so that they can die fulfilled. In this instance, they visit a comatose old man, "Johnny", whose final wish is to visit the moon - the only issue is that he has no idea why he wants to do so. Admittedly this may sound depressing, but the dialogue between the two scientists is refreshingly full of humour to keep things perky.To The Moon is an absolute masterpiece of a game - the soundtrack is unique and accompanies the story perfectly, and although the graphics are in 16 bit style and the actual 'gaming' aspect of it is more point-and-click than anything, none of this detracts in the slightest from the genius and depth of the whole experience. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - worth every last penny. You owe it to yourself to play this.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												What 'To the Moon' isn't: an action game, a role-playing game, an adventure game.What 'To the Moon' is: a beautiful interactive novel that tells a poignant, human story.Using wonderfully retro pixel art (reminicient of the SNES), To the Moon tells the story of a man's life in reverse, spinning a tale that is equal parts melancholy and uplifting.  The gameplay interacions are absolutely minimal - there are some light hidden object mechanics, and a realitive easy recurring puzzle..... but that's not really the point of the game.  To the Moon is a schmultzy (in a good way) story set against a lovingly-crafted canvas and set to some utterly captivating piano scores.  The game looks and sounds amazing, and if you don't get misty eyed at least a few times then I don't know what's wrong with you.If you loved 'Gone Home', or other recent pieces of interactive fiction, then you should nsap this gem up right away.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												I've recently played a few games that are story-driven experiences with puzzle elements. This is one of those. "Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons" is another. "Brothers" concentrates on conveying emotional story through traditional gaming conventions and unique ways of interacting using a controller. It is also presented in beautiful 3D with excellently crafted character models. In contrast, "To the Moon" uses a simple RPG engine with basic sprites but manages to pack in such a compelling, unique story through written dialogue that only being able to walk in four directions and not actually having the threat of death or overly complicated puzzles fades away.The story of "To the Moon" is front and center. And it is good. It is hard to explain without spoilers but suffice to say that it would appeal to fans of romantic movies, sci-fi and specifically the movie "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind." There is enough mystery to keep you plugging away until you finish and this can be done in one sitting fairly easily. The game clocks in at around four and a half hours.Unfortunately I have a few minor complaints. As I said, you can only walk in four directions. Unfortunately, too often you get stuck in strange terrain or are blocked by a plant or grass you thought was background. Also, at times, the walking pace seems painfully slow. To the game's credit, it often is because you can't wait to get to the next story-element and often it feels appropriate given the pacing of the story but the fact remains when you aren't dashing by default, a run option would have been nice. Also, at times the graphics are a little rough and it strikes me that there is one cut scene that utilizes the pixel art of the main game and another two that make use of hand-drawn animation. I would have liked the cut scenes to use the same style throughout.Really, my complaints are minor so I will end with one last noteworthy positive aspect of this game: the music. It's appropriate everywhere it appears and it is very good. This is a soundtrack that puts you in the mood for the story that is told and as I said before, the story is worth it. I recommend this game as an experience. It's not terribly expensive or much of a time commitment so give it a spin. I think you'll love it if you're into creative story-telling experiences.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												To be 100% honest.. I did not know about the game untill I bought it on steam by "accident".I bought it and tried it and I was stuck in the story after the first 5 minutes of the game.During my stream (I stream on twitch daily) I told my chatters that this could actually be a really good game.What I did not know was that the game had already been out for about 2½ year before I started playing.I will give the game following Puppy-Points after playing through the story twice:Story Mode: 10/10 - A really sad story that made both me and most of my chatters cry like kids who just lost their candy.Game Interaction: 9/10 - The way you move around, talk to other characters, playing around with the "puzzles".. Is amazingly well done / created. Good Job!Graphics: 9/10 - The animations, characters looks and the anumals in the game were really good looking. Animations on the main characters were stunning and you could actually FEEL what they were saying. Not just read it.Feelings: 10/10 - The feelings were following: Happyness!Start of the game was as it was supposed to be. Very humoristic and you got stuck in both Watts and Rosaline at first view. It made me really happy in the beginning that they had humor in this dark story (Yes I read the game info before I started playing). Sadness!The sad feelings came in at around 15 min mark when we started to know what was actually going to happen. When we realized that (SPOILER!!) the Lighthouse had such a big part in the story. Also that "For River" was a song that was going to be stuck inside you for the rest of your gameplay. AMAZING!Anger!Anger was something I felt during late-mid/late gameplay when I was thrown around the feelings for Rosaline and Watts when they were getting so close to their goal. What was I to belive? Happyness again!When we at the ending realized what has happened through the WHOLE story.. I couldn't bare anymore.The feelings fly throu me like a bullet and hit the heart twice.I have never been so sad about something happy ever and I will hopfully never be. Because thatf eeling was to be honest really damn scary.My Total points of the game will however end at 9/10.Why not 10/10? WHATS WRONG?!Following:The game is actually a game for kids / teens. This makes me wonder.. Is the story really going in at younger ages?I belive that people between 10 - 16 will have a hard time following the time-warps that takes place in-game. Even I (25 years old) had a hard time following this. (Hence why I played it twice).Also.. The story ends with (Sry.. no spoiler here).. and I am wondering.. What had actually happened here?Did it turn out well/good for both parts? Or was it just the one main character that actually had anything good out of this?After I played the game I went over to youtube in a flash and started reading about what people were actually thinking about the ending. And my god! So much argumentations about what was actually happening.I have however decided to belive that the good part of all of this belongs to myself.I have never played a game that short who has inspired me or touch me like To The Moon did.If you have not yet played the game.. Just do it. It will take you a maximum of 3 hours (depending on how much you will cry).If you have played the game.. What do you give this game as in points? I am intrested in knowing that. Maybe I can learn something that will make me put that last point into a full 10/10.Worth the money?No doubt - Hands down.Worth the time?Skip a movie.Worth the tears?Yes. Thank you, my dear developers, for making this game. I will play the rest of the games in the series very soon.You will hear from me again./ PuppyStream.net™

Posted: June 28, 2014
												How could I possibly put into words anything that would even remotely come close to an accurate representation of my thoughts on this?This is simply one of the greatest experiences I have ever had in my 22(at the time) years. Trying to pinpoint specific things that made it such would be difficult. Just a wonderful experience. The music, oh lord the music. The combined talents of Laura Shigihara and Kan Gao make this one of the most, alright i'll say it, beautiful soundtrack in a game that is based entirely on its narrative story. The fitting music is comforting when it needs to be as well as dark and unsettling in times where you truly feel worried. However then you have moments like Laura Shigihara's "Everythings Alright" that just bring all the emotion, struggle, hope and everything you've been obsorbing the whole time and lets it all out with you.The simplistic yet perfect medium.Using what could arguably be a simple medium for the presentation of this game, the story and music brings it to the player in a way that far surpasses some more elaborate and higher budget projects. Its just simple, raw, true storytelling. When finishing you can't help but wonder what these writing talents could do given the support of some AAA titles. However at the same time I think a lot of the magic would be lost. Which brings me to my belief that the current method works just fine.The story keeps you going.The biggest drawback people might face is the gameplay. This is where you notice the time focused more on story/music rather than gameplay elements. It is point and click at its finest. More of an interactive story than an adventure. But don't that make you think its so easy *cough* horseback riding memory *cough*. There are things that require thought. Which are kind of speed bumps on your way but provide a good way of pacing the story.Onward and upward.This is not all Kan Gao and Freebird Games have done. They have other projects worth looking into which can be found on their site. There is also an extra holiday episode that fills a gap between To the Moon and the upcoming Bird Story. All of which I highly reccomend looking into.Must do's.Others can feel free to edit in their own thoughts here, but how you play this game is a very important deal in my opinion. I should start by explaining how I came across this game. I came home from work to log into Steam and do my daily "what are my friends up to?" check. I see just one friend in game. An unfamiliar title to which I instantly message him asking what it was. I got no reply so I simply shrugged and went about my evening until about 3 hours later I finally heard the all too familiar ping of Steam messaging. Now this friend is one i've known and grown with for years. We are very alike. His reply was simply "get this game." Luckily I had money and before I even replied it was downloading.I jokingly asked something to the effect of "what the hell did I just buy." He basically told me to shut my door, disable Steam overlay, put my phone away and just play the game. So I did. Roughly 3.5 hours later I emerged after the wonderful thing I just sat through. So in playing this, I HIGHLY reccomend do it in one sitting and far from the distractions of the world. In short, this is one of the greatest things I have ever seen. All who wish for an amazing story pick this up. You can ask any of my Steam friends, I think i've bought it for almost all of them

While playing this game it felt like I was reading a book, a book that takes you on a rollercoaster of emotions. My emotions changed from being sad, happy, and to creeped out just from a single scene change. I recommend playing this game when no one will disturb you, it helps you get into the game.Now however, while this game's story was good, the gameplay was lacking. The minigames seemed to serve no purpose other than to exist. They were short, and didn't give much entertainment if any. I would have either not include them, or implement them in a way that fits the story better, instead of having them get you to the next part of it. ( Another thing, did how well you did on the minigames even affect anything? From what I have seen they don't do anything.)Besided this, the game had a good soundtrack, had no bugs/glitches (atleast for me), and it presented it story well, you never knew what was going to happen. I would rate this game at a 8/10.

Posted: February 4, 2014
												holy. Flunknugget. Where to start?First of all, as a fan of them old RM2k games I'm glad to see myself taken back to those times.Secondly, this story. This effin Story. as they say in the game "its like watching an accident". but in a good way. Since you start on the End and slowly inch back towards Johnnys Childhood you can practically see where things go wrng. and allways that one question: Why does he want to the moon?Well, even tho the Story and presentation are well made theres some small things to nag upon. 1st: the 2nd act really feels out of place after the owerful and kinda feel-heavy first act. You'll see what I mean. and 2nd: sometimes the gameplay is counterintuitive. Let me elaborate: To advance you have to find 5 memory links and a Memento. But those memory links arent really that obvious to find. Often its just "stuff lying around" but then, in bigger areas or areas without interactable stuff, its kinda hard to figure out where they are or why they are there.Noneoftheless, To The Moon is a great Story Experience.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												First thing that attracted me to this game were the soundtracks, worth buying the OST bundle. The game is like reading a novel, but with pictures and sounds, and the story is amazing. It's got funny moments, happy, sad, creepy moments and you would not stop reading/playing the game until you're finished. You can always give a try for free for 1 hour on their main website, I personally love this game and would like to read/play the game again in the future :). I don't read a lotta books and i think if they've got a book for this story i'd read it. I give it a 10/10, for the people who simply want to read a story that really catches your emotions should really give this game a try!! Amazing storyline.

Posted: February 2, 2014
												What 'To the Moon' isn't: an action game, a role-playing game, an adventure game.What 'To the Moon' is: a beautiful interactive novel that tells a poignant, human story.Using wonderfully retro pixel art (reminicient of the SNES), To the Moon tells the story of a man's life in reverse, spinning a tale that is equal parts melancholy and uplifting.  The gameplay interacions are absolutely minimal - there are some light hidden object mechanics, and a realitive easy recurring puzzle..... but that's not really the point of the game.  To the Moon is a schmultzy (in a good way) story set against a lovingly-crafted canvas and set to some utterly captivating piano scores.  The game looks and sounds amazing, and if you don't get misty eyed at least a few times then I don't know what's wrong with you.If you loved 'Gone Home', or other recent pieces of interactive fiction, then you should nsap this gem up right away.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												AT A GLANCE: A gem among the visual novels.[A more detailed review follows below.]Game Name: To The MoonOriginal Release Date: November 1, 2011My Overall Rating: AEstimated Playtime: 2.5 to 4 hours (Campaign)Multiplayer: NoneRecommended To: Visual novels lovers and those players looking for movie-like game with a great story or a good weekend pass-time game, and casual players.REVIEWTo The Moon is a example of a good indie VN game, with some RPG-ish mixed with it. It feels truly like a gem among so many VN out there. It is not a true game,yet if offers a story-rich, which you may get immersed in itself. Well, that's might sound like a bit of exaggeration, however this game is a really polished visual novel with a great story and soundtrack. Great atmosphere and aesthetic.It has got a great emotional aspect. The game blends realism greatly with human psychology. Sometimes, there are times when we humans try to do something unique even at the last stage of their life. And this game amazingly engages you in the story that you might not even remember trying to check out the menus of the game but keep on playing. It is deeply engaging that charms you to complete it in a single playthrough. I also played it non-stop for about four hours and didn't even realize there was a power cut. This is a great experience-giving game and will surely make your weekend good after all your hard work or study.Regarding the gameplay, being a visual novel, it includes a point-and-click like mechanics and keyboard support. You can play as two characters (scientists, to be precise) on a quest of fulfilling a... (Well, let's not spoil the game, shall we?) I say that you play it at least once by yourself. In summary, a great VN, which I truly recommend for any VN lovers and those looking for a short game with rich story,pleasing soundtrack,and aesthetic game contents.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												I loved it. Technologically the game was kind of mediocre (noticeable screen tearing, fixed 640x480 resolution, etc.) and the gameplay got pretty tedious at times, but the actual art - graphics, music and story are all absolutely amazing.As an autistic person I found the girl's part of the storyline kind of.. cliche, I guess? I think they pushed it just a *little* bit too hard. Christ, I get it, autistic people are often socially inept. That doesn't mean every scene with the girl has to revolve around that.Anyway, in terms of story, this is one of the best games I have played in a long time. I would definitely recommend it to anyone, assuming you aren't expetcing it to be a traditional RPG just because it uses the same format.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												First of all i'd like to say this isn't much of a game, it's more of an interactive storybook. The game is mainly dialogue between characters, with some small bits of gameplay in between. But i wouldn't have it any other way. This is something you MUST experience. It will tug at your heart strings, make you look at yourself in a different light and even give you a different view of is important in life. I can't tell you any more than that without spoilers, just do yourself a favour and set aside 3 hours of your time to experience this beautiful masterpiece. :)

Posted: January 5, 2014
												While I can't say this is a game I cried over, To The Moon is a game that will probably linger in my mind throughout the rest of my life. The story is impactful, light-hearted, and most importantly, interesting enough to keep playing through to the end.What To The Moon shows without spoiling much is that life can bring about very unfortunate circumstances, but even under them, people are determined to find happiness, and will use any means to have it. We don't live for what brings us down, but for what keeps us up and fighting to our last breath. Where it shows best is its unbelievable narration and character dialogue. You will remember the happy and humorous parts as much as you would the sad and depressing parts, but neither of the parts affect each other no matter how close they are together in the story.The music? While some may call it repetitive, I find it far from it. It fits many of the situations in the story, and uses the piano as a distinct theming tool. And let me not forget that wonderful piece by Laura Shigihara. I haven't heard a lot from her, being one song from Plants vs. Zombies. But this song is simply stunning, and even moreso in where it plays.Its gameplay can be somewhat excused considering the engine it's built off of, RPG Maker XP. So yes it does look and feel like an old JRPG, but that's not what the game's about anyway. The puzzles were intuitive, but a little too easy (maybe it was intentional so it could be enjoyed in 4 hours?). The mouse controls are convenient especially during sections where it's difficult to find pieces for mementos (which for me almost turned into a pixel-hunt without them).To conclude the review, To The Moon is a game that takes life's meaning and puts it in the hands of the player. Where it takes you is your decision alone.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												To the moon – ♫ Fly me to the moon♫ To the moon was released in 2011. I first acquired the game as part of a humble bundle and paid it no mind! Man was that a mistake!!The game is listed as an Adventure RPG. But i would call it an interactive short story told backwards. Its not so much a game as it is a great story in a game. It will make you laugh, it might make you cry, but it will certainly show you how a great story can be told through a game. Mostly To the Moon is a treasure hunt, the goal is to find clues to unlock the next stage. With even a few mini games thrown in for good old fun. The story can be hard to follow at times, so make sure you read all the clues at the start. It will not make sense at first but they soon will. This game does have high repeatable play value, because of the complexity of the story.As to the game itself, well it has the feel of an 8-16 bit JRPG.  With simple point and click movement  throughout most of the game play. There is no real combat,  unlike most RPG’s.  And you play as one of two characters, both being doctors. Your goal is to replace a dying mans last wish. It is hard to go into further detail without giving out spoilers.    I would give this game a top rating due to it is an ingenious way to tell a great story while drawing the reader in for more. You cannot beat the price, and it is a no contest debate, whether or not I will buy the next short story game from FreeBird games. I just hope you enjoy this game, err story, um ah game as much as I did.  -TheBad300

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Wow. I literally tripped over this game looking through the store, and I couldn'y believe the reviews. People were saying 10/10 best game ever, and I was like "there's now way this rpg maker game is a 10/10." I was wrong. This game has very little actual gameplay, so don't come in expecting that. Rather, it is musically and narratively driven. This is one of those games that is so intriguing that you think about it for days, weeks, years after you play it. The story is just fantastic, and the music is superb. The only con I would list for this game is that the dialogue for the scientists is pretty cringy. Nevertheless, the story and the music blows that minor complaint out of the water for a solid 10/10 and one of my favorite games ever. BUY THIS GAME. SHARE THIS GAME. PLAY THIS GAME.

Posted: August 1, 2014
												Okay, first of... I dont even have enough words to describe how good this game is... i think that by now many of the persons that will actually read this review would have played it, but i feel the need to write this anyways. If you dont know, this is a pseudo 2D game that its mainly a love story of a dying man and her deceased wife, in which you will have to alter his memorys to grant him his last wish (read below for more info)Lets first talk about the lenght of the game: you must probably be saying "what the heck, he only played for 3hs". Yes, thats enough to complete the game. Maybe the correct term for this game is an interactive movie, sort of. If this game you play as 2 "doctors" that change the memories of the persons to grant a last wish for them (as dying persons). In this case, as the title of the game says, its about making a patience go to the moon. Having that into account lets go to next part of my review.Emotional review: Oh my god... this game is a hurricane of emotions, they make you laught, they make you cry, they scare you at some points. Just to place this into context, i was playing the game while i was in the office, and i honestly cryed a couple of times... its just beautiful... WHICH brings me to the next point ->Music review: The music for the game (as they well say) its repetitive BUT its a good repetitive, not an annoying repetitive. The use of the music is just perfect, the emotional music, the scary, the "funny tracks", everything... it just fits every single part of the game.Gameplay review: You must already be tired of me saying its perfect, but it really is, the game is well polished, and i didnt enounter any problems moving through the game world. They set you up in a kindof straight map in which you have a couple of puzzles from time to time to resolve. Nothing that can take you more than 5 minutes each.------------------------Personal comments about the game: Even with the pseudo 2D graphics, the game plays with you emotions, without even the need of using real words. The dialogs are all written.I dont really know how much the game is right now, but even for the 3hs of gameplay I had it was worth whatever price I payed. It is probably on my top 5 of best games and it shall remain there for a very long time.Have no doubts on buying the game, you will not regret it.

Posted: July 25, 2015
												This is quite possibly one of the most beautiful games I have ever played story and graphics wise. The few puzzles in this are relatively simple but fun to figure out.  Fair warning that playing this produced quite a few tears, especially around the midpoint of the game. (And the music is so hauntingly beautiful, moreso after that point that I almost always had tears welling for the rest of the game.)Also, I definitely recommend playing through the whole thing in one sitting. It's short enough that it is entirely worth it, and while I found quite a few places that could make decent stopping points, I was so invested in the story that I wanted to find out what was next. I'm also definitely going to play through the story again just to find out what I'll see differently now that I know the end.And I haven't even started the two minisodes that are dlc, but I've got some high expectations based on the quality of the main story!

Posted: October 28, 2012
												A strange combination of "Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind," "Citizen Kane," and a push puzzle game. Which might sound terrible, but the results are pretty awesome. Although there are mini-puzzles to solve, it's really more an "interactive story" than a game, per se, but the "story" elements are top notch and even kind of revolutionary, considering that this was made in RPG Maker. It's rare that any piece of storytelling uses its medium to the fullest to achieve its ends so well.It is heavy on the sentimentality at times, but usually it's smart enough to pull back with a bit of humor, or a non-sequitor, or just a genuinely well observed piece of writing before things venture into "maudlin" territory. Over all, though, it is very well written.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												I had some monumental expectations for "To the Moon". Seeing all of the reviewers claiming they cried, had me hope for a story that would keep me enthralled and emotionally invested the entire time.While the story is emotional, dealing with a husband's struggles in living with a wife with a mental condition, there was one thing  with the writing that kept bothering me...the doctors.They pulled me out of the story almost every time they interacted. From snarky banter, to pop culture references, to pointless "mini-games" involving  zombies??! . I think they weren't written with the same serious tone as the rest of the story.There is a major twist towards the end that I suppose is there to pull your heart strings, but there was no real build up to it and was in a completely different direction then where I thought the story was going.  I thought Anya was going to be a lost child, which would have suited the build up more and been a great cataclyst for River's change in condition. I must say that you should complete this in one playthrough to get the impact of the story. I can see someone missing the emotion if they left the game and came back later to finish it.I recommend people play this as it is a decent story. For a little more then the cost of a movie ticket and time to devote to it (it's 4 hrs long), it's something to experience, but I wish the writers had made the script hold up as maturely as the material.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												This is such an amazing game. It's beautifully written making you fall in love with the characters as the game progresses. It's intresting plot that goes backward in time makes you almost think John's life will end differently. With some moments that just make you want to cry (usually you do) To the Moon is a well paced that game that although appears to go slowly goes just the right pace for you too fall inlove with the story of this wonderfull man. Not only does the graphics appear to be beautifully created in it's own way. Don't let the fact it has an rpg game style push you away. The soundtrack to come with it links perfectly to the mood it's tying to show and gives an amplified effect to the storyline. Not only does this game have those heart warming moments the narration between Dr Watt's and Dr Rosalene even makes you laugh at the best of times wanting you to know more into their own story. - I absolutly recommend this game it shows a story in a way you have never seen before. I cannot wait for the sequal.

Posted: May 5, 2014
												What do Roadkill, a dying man and zombies have in common? Nothing! And yet To The Moon crafts these elements together to form such a seamless and beautiful experience that will remain with you long after the credits roll.To the Moon follows the story of two scientists whose role is to visit the dying, and alter their memories of their life so that they can die fulfilled. In this instance, they visit a comatose old man, "Johnny", whose final wish is to visit the moon - the only issue is that he has no idea why he wants to do so. Admittedly this may sound depressing, but the dialogue between the two scientists is refreshingly full of humour to keep things perky.To The Moon is an absolute masterpiece of a game - the soundtrack is unique and accompanies the story perfectly, and although the graphics are in 16 bit style and the actual 'gaming' aspect of it is more point-and-click than anything, none of this detracts in the slightest from the genius and depth of the whole experience. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - worth every last penny. You owe it to yourself to play this.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Don't let my measley hours on this game fool you. I have played this game to death on another account. And let me tell you; it's worth every minute I spent on it. To The Moon is one of those games where you either take to the story right away, or you won't care much for it. But give it a try. Please. The story and the direction that it takes the player is such a good one. I'm not a cryer, but I teared up more than once playing this game. And honestly? I consider it one of my favorite games of all time. Gameplay wise... there's hardly any meat to it. But if you want some great writing, a good laugh, a good cry, and something to think about, experience this for yourself.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												The good with the bad. In the end, an excellent experience.Good: Fantastic story and concept. The music is wonderful. The graphics are full of life. The early levels are detailed and magnificent to explore.Bad: Some terrible, occasionally dreadful writing. Most of the characters are written the exact same all the way through the game. There's little differenciation between the different eras of the story. Lots of incidental "internet" humor and references to pop culture that should have been deleted after the first draft. Many eras' memory links are reused from previous levels and the game starts giving up on the memory link structure about halfway. This all adds up to a scattershot and amateur tone that any editor worth his/her salt could have corrected in an hour.Do I like the game? Definitely. Is the end result effective? Sure. But I hope chapter two is better.

Posted: August 10, 2014
												This is a FANTASTIC game. You play as one of two scientists who go to dying people and allow then to "relive" their lives, with modifications to their memories. You are able to grant a deathbed wish.You follow the life of a man and his love by tapping into his memories by using the same machine that you are using to alter his memories. You are but a ghost, observing the unfolding story and history of the man's life though his memories. You gain great insight and develop an emotional connection to the characters in the game to your own benefit to connect with them and really feel their stories, their happiness, and their sadness.There are YouTube Let's Plays of this game. Someone made a compilation "Players react to To The Moon" - specifically the ending. Even some of the most famous and comedic Let's Play broadcasters have been brought to a serious, quiet, somber demeanor as the game unfolds, and brought to tears at the end.Don't look at any reviews (well, except this one, it's too late!), don't watch the reaction video until you've beaten the game, don't listen to the music until you've completed the game. Just play it. It will take you in and immerse you. It will be one of those games you categorize in your mind as the most memorable and emotional stories in a video game ever.All this from sprites in a Final Fantasy esque presentation (but no random encounters!). It shows you don't need high definition, state of the art graphics to have a powerful game play experience. The music however is real, no midi synth or FruityLoops. Everything from a real simple piano piece (which you will find yourself YouTubing to listen to for years after playing it, if you don't outright buy the OST) to fully scored songs, one with (great) vocalization.Buy it. If you love a game for it's story over mindlessly running around killing things for XP, you will love To The Moon.

												It's so hard to say why this game is so good without spoiling it....I guess the main thing I love about it is how well-crafted the story is. There are many layers and details to consider, and I feel like there would be more to think about with each further playthrough. Posted: May 14, 2016
												I bought this game on a sheer whim, looking for something new to add to my library and hoping to have some fun. I never expected to fall in love with it. From the first 20 minutes in, I was hooked. As implausible as the plotline sounds on paper, the game developers and writers have done an immaculate job of sucking you into this world where it's not only totally possible, it's commonplace.  It's cleverly written, intelligent, and the characters feel like real people.  There are so many gems in the dialogue that made me laugh out loud -- especially a particular TV show reference early on. And I can't say enough good things about the soundtrack. It is so, so lovely.While the gameplay itself is very simplistic and easy, the story is what will keep you rooted to your seat. The pacing is perfect -- moments of sadness, elation, and well-timed comedic relief are placed very well throughout the whole story. And that ending...well, I wouldn't dream of spoiling it, but just hang onto yer butts, kids. And bring the tissues.

Posted: November 3, 2014
												To the Moon is a visual novel rather than a game. I've heard the term RPG used to describe it but that would be incorrect as there are no unique mechanics, form of progression or indeed any aspect of your characters to progress. What might be considered puzzles or game play is nothing more than the game stubbornly folding its arms and barring you from the next chapter until you have collected all five macguffins in each tiny area and a breif bullet hell section at the very end. However, in spite of what I just said, I am recommending To the Moon because it tells an amazing story that kept me interested form beginning to end. As a game designed soley to tell a story it does so in spades with an intrigueing plot, relatable characters, and an ending I didn't see comming. I'm looking foreword to A Bird Story.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												A nice, sweet, touching game (~4.5 hours). The story was really cute, gameplay unique, dialogue amusing and music captivating. I really enjoyed playing through this game. The scenes with actual art was nice too. Overall, a beautiful yet sad story was the main reason why I managed to finish the game so quickly (2 sittings), and I'm sure whoever reads this will enjoy it just as much as I did. ^^

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I know it's already been said over and over again, but I'll say it again: To The Moon is a fantastic achievement in storytelling that weaves an intricate and fully engrossing tale through the medium of games. The pixel graphics are charming and suit the game well. The music is beautiful and perfectly timed, tugging at the player's emotions at just the right moments. While there are a few kinks here and there, the story is so entrancing that these can be easily overlooked.Actual gameplay is pretty minimal, with players simply exploring areas to progress the story and solving some easy puzzles, but it's an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and despite having a linear story, the game never feels too confined. I very quickly became invested in the plot and wanted to delve deeper and discover the answers to all the questions each new progression raised. To The Moon is a story that deals with a great range of emotions and takes the player along for the ride to experience the ups and downs of life. If you're the sensitive type, be prepared for tears. I cried like a baby.In short: I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who can appreciate a good story, regardless of what your actual taste in video-games is. You might be surprised.

												I literally just finished the game less than a minute ago, and my first thought was to write my first review.  I'm a sucker for games that have an impressive story. Posted: November 29, 2014
												Let's get the bad out of the way first.- Graphics have major issues.  At least it did for me.  I had two modes of playing.  Windowed mode (hit alt-enter) which means I was playing in a tiny window, or full screen mode, which on my screen for some reason meant a lot of the things were cut off.  Put it this way when I went to the load screen instead of "Load File" it said "ile"  I had to play it in windowed mode.- Graphics were also not very good considering how low the resolution was.- Engine / path finding was a bit clunky.- Not much "game" in it.  There's a few minor puzzles.  That's about it.  - The dialogue felt a bit out of character sometimes.Now that doesn't sound like a very glowing review but if you'd notice there's a big "Yes" recommendation.  Why is that?  Well the music was quite beautiful (though it did get slightly repetitive at times).  But the most important thing...The story is beautiful.   It's almost ridiculously beautiful.  It's moving, sad, touching, and happy all in one package.  And in all honesty, if a good director got his hand on this story, I can see one heck of a great movie.  I mean you have to realize they did all of this with no voice acting and graphics that belong to the NES era (we're talking early 90s!).Highly recommended for people who enjoy melancholic stories (it starts a bit slow of course).  If you're into graphics or action or tough puzzles, this isn't the game for you though.

Posted: November 29, 2012
												Words can't be enough to describe how brilliant this is.Even though the gameplay is quite thin, focusing on collecting mementos and solving fairly easy puzzles, we're not here for that.It's the fantastic story, the brilliant musical score and the clever dialogue that steals the show immediately.The story tells about technology, which makes it possible for doctors to connect into patients' minds, see their memories and change them as they match their dreams.This corrupts though the "real" memories, so these have to be done when they're on their deathbed. I'm not getting the story any further, as you have to experience it on your own.The music is absolutely terrific, it fits to the mood of the story and enhances it at the same time.And the dialogue is both hilarious and thoughtful, it balances the game for not being too depressing or too jesting. The playful chit-chatting of doctors, the sad thoughts of Johnny (the "main" patient) and shy statements of his now-deceased autistic wife River.Now for hardcore gamers, this isn't one of your "action thrills" of the year, nor the longest games you've ever played (took me 5 hours to complete it).To The Moon is more like an interactive story than a game, but it doesn't hurt the in-game content.There are also sometimes a bit inconsistent pacing, turning suddenly from puzzling to throwing pot plants at zombies (Plants vs. Zombies?)Asides of these problems, it's hard to forget this game. It was completely different experience, and it deserves more attention than it currently has. It's one of those games that keeps reminding of what is truly important in life. From the beginning's lighthouse to the touching conclusion, it really is worth your money.

Posted: January 20, 2015
												To the moon – ♫ Fly me to the moon♫ To the moon was released in 2011. I first acquired the game as part of a humble bundle and paid it no mind! Man was that a mistake!!The game is listed as an Adventure RPG. But i would call it an interactive short story told backwards. Its not so much a game as it is a great story in a game. It will make you laugh, it might make you cry, but it will certainly show you how a great story can be told through a game. Mostly To the Moon is a treasure hunt, the goal is to find clues to unlock the next stage. With even a few mini games thrown in for good old fun. The story can be hard to follow at times, so make sure you read all the clues at the start. It will not make sense at first but they soon will. This game does have high repeatable play value, because of the complexity of the story.As to the game itself, well it has the feel of an 8-16 bit JRPG.  With simple point and click movement  throughout most of the game play. There is no real combat,  unlike most RPG’s.  And you play as one of two characters, both being doctors. Your goal is to replace a dying mans last wish. It is hard to go into further detail without giving out spoilers.    I would give this game a top rating due to it is an ingenious way to tell a great story while drawing the reader in for more. You cannot beat the price, and it is a no contest debate, whether or not I will buy the next short story game from FreeBird games. I just hope you enjoy this game, err story, um ah game as much as I did.  -TheBad300

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I'm generally not a fan of these types of games. When I first discovered this, I debated about getting this game for a few months, And only decided to when the game went onsale over the Steam Summer Sale.The game itself is very nice, I was intially intrigued by the idea of the game, I only further came to like the plot by having the perspective from the two doctors. Posted: June 25, 2014
												I know it's already been said over and over again, but I'll say it again: To The Moon is a fantastic achievement in storytelling that weaves an intricate and fully engrossing tale through the medium of games. The pixel graphics are charming and suit the game well. The music is beautiful and perfectly timed, tugging at the player's emotions at just the right moments. While there are a few kinks here and there, the story is so entrancing that these can be easily overlooked.Actual gameplay is pretty minimal, with players simply exploring areas to progress the story and solving some easy puzzles, but it's an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and despite having a linear story, the game never feels too confined. I very quickly became invested in the plot and wanted to delve deeper and discover the answers to all the questions each new progression raised. To The Moon is a story that deals with a great range of emotions and takes the player along for the ride to experience the ups and downs of life. If you're the sensitive type, be prepared for tears. I cried like a baby.In short: I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who can appreciate a good story, regardless of what your actual taste in video-games is. You might be surprised.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												This isn't a game, but it is a touching story told in reverse which still makes for a worthwhile experience. As the player you control the speed at which the story unravels but not much else and at times it all gets a bit repetive. Thankfully the 'experience' is short otherwise it could have ended up becoming tedious.Perhaps acknowledging that people will be expecting some sort of gameplay there's a single repeating image puzzle element, but it's so easy and without any risk that it doesn't qualify. It's arguable that the developer should have had the courage to stick with their vision and omit the puzzles, they add nothing to the story and feel out of place.So, this is a story, I should be reviewing that then. Well I don't want to give anything away about the ending, or should I say beginning since it's told in reverse? It's a slight love story, one of small coincidence, endurance through hardship and personal tragedy. It's not life changing or all that original, but if you have a shred of empathy and compassion then you will probably enjoy it. It's unclear whether the player has any control over the outcome, but I saw no point at which this was likely so there is no replay value.

Posted: April 4, 2013
												To the moon. This game. This fricken game is amazing. I must start off by saying this isnt much of a game, its more of an interactive storytelling with tangents for extra information, nonetheless this game is amazing. To the moon is a 2d top down sprite game that tells the story of 2 young doctors whos job is to recreate a patients wish using a machine that recreates it in thier memory. Now thats done, lets get down to it. To the moons story. one - the writer is a genius he created each interactable character with a deep and relatable storyline. This is also the first game I have ever felt so tear-jerked. It was beautiful. The story was told so well from beginning to middle to end, each with impressive plot twists that are hard to see coming. I think that was the art to this story, it was incredibly hard to predict. Now music. One - the soundtrack was beautiful with large amounts of subtle orchestra music playing to create constant ambience at the right moments. There was also some very heavy songs amoung to create unease and funnily enough they sound like they are out of a horror game. two. I bought the OST the minute I finished the game. The graphics - like I said before 2d but this works perfectly, This game is so engrossing you will soon create faces for the characters yourself imagining the perfect emotions for the characters when its really needed. Gameplay. Now the gameplay was a bit weird, the game characters handled a bit like any click to move game, you collect "momentos" to move onto new memorys generally finding a final one to move back to another memory. There were also mountains of media refrences throughout the game. I will leave you with my favourite quote. "Not cool Eva. You Never cockblock someone in the middle of a kamehameha."

Posted: November 25, 2012
												I am still very impressed, it's one of the most beautiful experiences and storytelling I have ever played. It's not JRPG or anything like that, it's wonderful story about fulfilling the last wish of dying man called John - to be an astronaut and visit the Moon. Our two scientists are slowly travelling backwards through his memory, through his life. They watch his very deep personal moments in his life, the people, the places, the hardships and joys. But don't think it's absolutely serious, our two scientists love making gags and fun from themselves. Also, every scene and place is backed with wonderful background music. Music is complementing every scene; if people are happy, you're happy, if they are sad, you are sad, if they are in love, you are in love too. And I can't forget beautiful pixel graphics. To The Moon is not just an ordinary game, it's very unique experience. It's beautiful piece of art.

Posted: January 13, 2016
												What is worth anything in the end, are fake memories better than real ones? What would you want to remember from your life when it’s nearing it’s conclusion if you had the possibility to choose? Does it even matter if the memories are real if they make you happy? Such questions together with one of the saddest relationships in gaming history makes ”To the Moon” one of my absolute favorite experiences ever in the gaming medium. It’s also not everyday the word neurotypical is used in a game narrative. If you have any connection at all in your life with high functioning autism this is probably one of the only games that discusses the topic in a relatable, albeit heartbreakingly sad way. I can’t say much about the game itself as everything is overshadowed by the tale told. It has some beautiful music and vintage graphics but also the clunky gameplay style of an old school JRPG. Some of the dialogue is rather retro as well, but the storytelling is excellent to a point where anyone even slightly interested should experience it.A huge experience in a very small, limited package it's hugely recommended!

Posted: June 24, 2014
												I was never into visual novels, but after experiencing this one - I think I might have missed on many memorable games from the genre. To the Moon is certainly one of them.Don't judge the book by its cover. Being made in RPG Maker shouldn't be a reason to avoid this game. To the Moon involves some simple mechanics to keep you engaged and let's you take an active part in the whole story. Pixelart is beautiful, every sprite is very detailed and locations are unique. Music is one of the strongest points of the game - sets the mood perfectly everytime.Throughout the game I experienced whole spectrum of feelings. It made me jump from sadness to the joy and back to the sorrow again in a blink. It also makes you curious, makes you think about current events and doesn't stop until the very end. Your main characters add humorous aspect without breaking the overall tone of the story and are easy to get along with.You won't find hardcore gameplay here, but mature story about fulifilling one's dreams.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												To the Moon is easily one of my most cherished games. There is such a wonderful story that unfolds over the course of ~4 hours that continues to resonate with you for a very long time. Although the gameplay elements are minor, essentially used to keep gamer's hands busy, the emotional impact that the story delivers vaults this game into the realm of art--a feat rarely achieved in this medium. If you're searching for something to make you bawl your eyes out, yet still be an enjoyable experience, then look no further. There are so many feels present here that just listening to one of its wonderful musical tracks, even several weeks after completing it, will result in the uncontrollable flow of tears. I cannot recommend this game highly enough.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												While I can't say this is a game I cried over, To The Moon is a game that will probably linger in my mind throughout the rest of my life. The story is impactful, light-hearted, and most importantly, interesting enough to keep playing through to the end.What To The Moon shows without spoiling much is that life can bring about very unfortunate circumstances, but even under them, people are determined to find happiness, and will use any means to have it. We don't live for what brings us down, but for what keeps us up and fighting to our last breath. Where it shows best is its unbelievable narration and character dialogue. You will remember the happy and humorous parts as much as you would the sad and depressing parts, but neither of the parts affect each other no matter how close they are together in the story.The music? While some may call it repetitive, I find it far from it. It fits many of the situations in the story, and uses the piano as a distinct theming tool. And let me not forget that wonderful piece by Laura Shigihara. I haven't heard a lot from her, being one song from Plants vs. Zombies. But this song is simply stunning, and even moreso in where it plays.Its gameplay can be somewhat excused considering the engine it's built off of, RPG Maker XP. So yes it does look and feel like an old JRPG, but that's not what the game's about anyway. The puzzles were intuitive, but a little too easy (maybe it was intentional so it could be enjoyed in 4 hours?). The mouse controls are convenient especially during sections where it's difficult to find pieces for mementos (which for me almost turned into a pixel-hunt without them).To conclude the review, To The Moon is a game that takes life's meaning and puts it in the hands of the player. Where it takes you is your decision alone.

Posted: January 9, 2014
												This is a weird game to recommend. It doesn't even really feel like a game, but more of an interacive story. So let me say this first, if you want to play something and not "play" a ~3 hour story, DO NOT BUY this title.So yeah, the gameplay consists mostly of walking around and experiencing the story with a few mini-games here and there and a small puzzle after every section. The story takes a while to unfold and at times does feel like it's too dragged out, but it keeps you guessing and after act 1 the pacing gets fixed a bit. Eventually going to the great bittersweet ending with kind of an moral question imbued.All in all, I do recommend it for the story, the beautiful art and the amazing soundtrack, but not at the original price point. Definitely get it at a discount and enjoy the story :)

Posted: March 30, 2015
												What wonderful storytelling! The less you know about this game beforehand, the better the experience will be. When you start playing, make sure you have a few hours to yourself; To The Moon is best consumed all at once or only in few sessions.I'm glad that To The Moon was brought to my attention by someone who sang its' praises but spoilt nothing, but you don't always have the trusted recommendation of a person close to you. In that case, how do you know it's for you and worth buying? What is so special about To The Moon and why does it make everyone cry? If you're reading the reviews for an answer to those questions, something about the way the game looks or what you've heard of it creates doubt.If a sob story within an indie game that looks like an old-school JRPG doesn't sound like your usual thing, or conversely if you're thinking that you've seen this already because it's "just another artsy indie game", then that's even more of a reason to buy To The Moon. It goes beyond the boundaries of game genres and will expand your idea of how a story can be told. It's not unique in the sense that it's the first or only one of it's kind doing that, but To The Moon is so original in content and perfectly fitting in its delivery that you're in for an unfogettable experience.

Posted: April 8, 2015
												Okay so I am not into the whole interactive story genre, nor am I into anime, pokemon-esque or similar art styles. But a friend of mine, not knowing this, gave me this game. I let it sit in my Library undownloaded for a few months, then, when I was finally bored, gave it a try.I entered the game with the preconception it was entirely a puzzle game with some love backstory. Fine. Bits of Humor here, Flamboyant love there, cute. Puzzles that are relatively easy, minigames thart would be dorky and simple. Wrong.Instantly I was hit with humor and mystery, enough so to just grab my curiosity. After some modest investiagtion of my surroundings and enviroment, I gained a vague context to a problem that delved much deeper than I ever imagined. Love is not isolated, it is connected, resilient, and defiant. Memory is fragile, warpeable and unstable. Dreams are wavering, unclear, yet hold a certainty unexplainable to them. In this game, where mystery and curiousity pulls you deeper, and the story developes unpredictably yet smoothly, you are not a player. You are not an interaction. You are a human, exposed to all weakness humanity can suffer, from life to death, from happinesss to misery, and from isolation to open compassion. This game, which is by absolutely no means in any format I care to try or enjoy, has rendered me utterly wordless from start to finish, and is without any amount of doubt the best game I have ever played. Yes, this small indie game to me surpasses what Assassin's Creed, Halo, Call of Duty, Walking Dead (telltale), Uncharted, Far Cry, or even Last of Us have ever achieved. Few games make me care for its characters, its plot, its enviroment, or its purpose. Fewer games I enjoy afterward and replay again to try to experience again, like reading an old book. This game resonates so strongly, concludes so dramatically, that it IS the best game I have ever had the honor to experience, participate, and immerse myself in. Thank you developers for creating sucha wonderful and intimate interactive experience.(11/10 5 stars Would Recommend to any Human who loves Games for the Games)(That is a serious rating)UPDATE: I recently went back to this game and replayed it for the story. Just like rereading a great book, I love this game, and strongly encourage anyone and everyone to play it!

Posted: June 21, 2015
												I don't normally write reviews for games. Most games I play are well known and don't need me to say whether they are good or not. I'd never heard of this before though.. it sounded interesting, and then it was on sale, so why not?My god... I don't think I've ever experienced a more touching story that was told so eloquently. Tugged at all the heartstrings. Sad moment, happy moments, even hilariously funny moments. The two main characters are wonderfully animated (in personality that is) and make adventuring through the story amusing and fun. The story itself is just magnificent and if you don't get hit with a full force of the feels by the end you either weren't paying attention or you weren't quite human.This game isn't really about space travel despite its name and ending, it is about people, love, and relationships through the ages. I could play tons of games with the latest graphics and the highest price points that don't match the story this one tells. If you buy this, you'll enjoy it.Highly Recommended.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												To the Moon is a great story with limited game elements. Maybe it's because I have a soft spot for 16-bit games due to growing up on the SNES, but this game made me care about the characters like few modern games can. Think of it like Chrono Trigger or Mother 3 without the grinding RPG elements. I'd play both of those games just for their stories and as long as you would too, then this game is for you even if you don't typically like interactive stories. I don't compare games to CT or M3 lightly, as I consider them to be two of greatest games ever made, so I'll let that be the highest praise that I can offer this wonderful game.*Obligatory Steam Awared Update*

Posted: February 13, 2015
												I have finally discovered the brain drug that I was so badly missing for my entire life.  For the past 2 nights, before slipping into sleepville, I crawled into bed with my cute purple baby macbook Air, turned out the lights, turned up the backlit keyboard, put my space heater on timer for 1 hour, and entered the wild and wonderful world of "To the Moon."This was the first video game that I have ever played to completion (the last was "Leisure Suit Larry" which I played with my brother when I was 8 years old).  It took me three evenings (maybe 4-6 hours), and was almost entirely brain pacifying in the best way ever.  There was a brief zombie encounter at one point (I HATE ZOMBIES) but my virtual life was never truly in danger, and there is no way to "lose" this game.  Here's why I loved it:1. I couldn't die2. I didn't have to kill anyone (except a few powerless zombies)3. the background music throughtout the entire game (almost) was sweet, lovely, gentle, comforting, dreamy, and everything nice, and set the tone of the whole game into the zone I am so desperately trying to make into my life4. the story had depth, much of which I missed prior to reading online game analysis5. it was more like a comic book or particpatory visual narrative than a game, which I liked.  My lIfe is too competitive as it is....6. there are no losers7 there was no stress...only curiousity and intrigue8. Love story!9. the plot was about making someone's dreams come true, and making life better  I am open to more recomendations for sweet and lovely love filled games with good music.  No zombies or killing please.  and preferibly no way to "lose".  I guess I just like pretty interactive meaningfilled stories.

Posted: March 10, 2015
												Ok, here's the thing : To the Moon is not a typical 'game'; There's no leveling, there's no monster fighting/killing, and no HP or MP. In fact, it's kinda like a highly interactive visual novel where the characters get to walk around and perform certain actions to enable the story to move forward. While the 'gameplay' might not be everyone's cup of tea, I highy suggest this game for its great soundtrack and story.Con : Not a fan of the game's point-and-click controls; Requires 2 clicks at times to get the characters to move to the require spot or walk through a door/next screen (not that big an issue but a mild annoyance nonetheless)Pros : Where do I start??1. AWESOME soundtrack (I immediately bought the Game + Soundtrack bundle after the trailer finished playing)2. Great storyline3. Nostalgic graphicsTo the Moon is a great example of an extremely well done game. There's no need for flashy graphics or high requirements; All that is needed is a great storyline and soundtrack.
