Posted: March 22, 2015
												To the Moon from Freebird games is quite simply a work of art! In the game you play as Dr. Rosalene and Dr. Watts as they try to make a dying man’s wish to go to the moon come true.I simply fell in love with this game, from the start to the end I was going straight from laughing until my belly hurt to sobbing like a giant mess on the floor. The characters all seem very real, they all have unique personalities and flaws which are essential in a story-driven game like this one.The story itself was very well written, every scene and action added to the story which is probably the reason it only had 3-5 hours of gameplay; depending how quickly you went through the game. There was however very little actual gameplay, mostly you walked around finding objects with memories attached to them so you could go further back into Johnny’s life. However these objects never felt random and always told you more about the characters.The soundtrack for this game is absolutely breath-taking, it really adds to the emotion of the story and River’s Song will get stuck in your head (I was humming it for weeks). I would definably recommend buying the soundtrack bundle on Steam.My one flaw is that I feel it is overpriced for £7, for this kind of game I would usually spend £3-£5 so I would recommend waiting for a sale. However Freebird have released two ‘minisodes’ for free as a holiday special.Overall I would proudly give this game a 9.5 out of 10If you want gameplay, I’d stay away. But if you want to experience a truly heart-wrenching story, you must pick this up!

Posted: December 23, 2014
												Feel free to read this, I won't include any spoilers, if you're thinking of getting the game. This game is beyond amazing, I picked up simply cause I heard nothing but good things about it, so I gave it a shot. Where to begin... I didn't think much of it at first, kind of expected the ordinary, but it was beyond my expectations.- 8/10 Graphics: For it being an Indie game, I enjoy the sprite animations, since it's limited to what can occur throughout the game.- 10/10 Music: It does get a bit repetitive at some points, but it doesn't lose it's values within the sentimental emotions in the scenario. There is a lot of memorable soothing songs the game lives up to express.- 7/10 Characters: As much as I enjoy watching Dr. Watts having his moments and Dr. Rosalina correcting him, even if he's right, I felt like Johnny could have been displayed differently to "understand" him more, personality and characteristic wise.- 8/10 Gameplay: This is a game where you want to play in a single run-through to grab a bigger feel of what's going on as you put the pieces together. I didn't enjoy finding items that "stick out" to progress, but it was pretty straight-forward anyway even if you're a casual gamer.- 10/10 Story-Line: This game is all story-line based, and was creatively done. It's completely original and met it's expectations. This game will make you feel every single emotion, I kid you not. Happiness, Anger, Sadness, Confusion, Regret... in fact, this game makes you think about your life as well. It expresses that any small thing you say or do can be the difference between you and your future.= 10/10 Cost: Is the game worth the money? For me, it was, and I'd even consider re-playing, even if I know what to expect, it's just one of those games where you might find something new and put reason to it.4.5/5 Overall: I loved this game and it's really inspiring. If you've played Ib, Witch's House, or Mad Father type of games, this should be very similar gameplay. I recommend it, just be sharp with every little detail, it'll help understand the characters' feelings it truly conveys.

												Even if this game wins the “I'm Not Crying, There's Something In My Eye” award, you're being lied to.You'll most likely cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥ during this game.3-4 hours for a playthrough and obviously not really much replay-value. Combined with the lack of options menu and actual gameplay-elements this might seem bad. But To The Moon tells a story and does it so incredibly well. Which is amazing since storytelling is something only very few games actually do a good job on (the only other example I can think of is Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons). That great story and the amazing soundtrack which always sets the mood perfectly makes for a real gem of a small indie game.

Posted: November 23, 2012
												It's hard to define this as a "game." While it does have a few game-like elements in it, it feels more like a story than anything else. However, that is not a bad thing. The story is amazing. You learn the ending to an old man's story and you gradually learn how he got to that point. I kept wanting to go back further to learn more as the story went on. There is certainly more to the story. However 90% of what I could say is a spoiler. The soundtrack is also quite outstanding. It helps convey the mood to help you feel what if wants you to. However, the gameplay itself is not a a reason to buy. There is no replay value, and once you play it once, you don't need to again. Furthermore, the story, while good, it won't last you long. I beat the game in three hours. For that reason, I do not reccomend paying full price for this. Buy it when it is a cheaper price and buy the soundtrack bundle. To reiterate, the story and soundtrack make up for the lack of a real game mechanic, but the asking price is unfortunaltely too expensive for such a short and story diven game.

Posted: November 2, 2014
												Someone once said (I think) that the meaning of tragedy in narrative is to let us channel our sadness, sorrow, into something far greater: an escape or an elevation. To consume a tragedy and shed tears because of it is to see our own shortcomings and faults, to understand the human condition and, while feeling sorrow for it, to overcome the mere sadness of unpleasant and unwanted things. The goal is to understand that while we are "only" human, each and every life story in the context of humanity is an epic in itself. Sounds grandiose, doesn't it?Well, I think that if we agree with what I said before, To the Moon is one of the great tragedies of modern gaming. It is a story monumental by itself: it is mostly the story of a single man and his love and memories, but in its execution it brings us to the shore of nostalgia, fondness, appreciation and - most of all - empathy for our fellow man. This is one of the greatest stories I have experienced. I recommend it for everyone.

Posted: November 4, 2014
												“To the Moon” is a simple but remarkable around four hour story-first game. That is somewhat limited on actual gameplay. Yet, makes-up for this fact with its extremely well-written and emotionally driven storyline. This game will tug at your heart strings one moment and make your side split with laughter by making fun of itself on the next. Each of the main characters are wonderfully written, even though they are a bit simple and stereotypical at times. I highly recommend this game to anyone who does not mind a little reading and enjoys a good story in their games.The gameplay is realistically only a few steps above a traditional visual novel. As you spend a lot of time reading its plotline and/or exploring the various locations to find triggers to advance the story. As a means to break-up the large amount of reading there are puzzles thrown in, which are relatively limited in difficulty. With some mini-games latter on comparable to virtual dodge ball and classic tag. Music-wise this game tends to repeats its few pieces over and over again. But what songs it does use are of high quality and really add to the emotional storyline. Particularly, the game loves playing its main theme: a wonderful piano piece throughout the course of the game during its various emotional scenes. Although, the limited selection is kind of to be expect to a certain point, since this is an indie game and was most likely developed on an extremely small budget; if any.Graphics-wise the game is retro Super Nintendo/Sega Genesis (16bit) era JRPG style. The artistry used is truly top-notch and would have been considered AAA quality in the heyday of 2D sprites. Which of course will strike a nostalgic vibe with older gamers.

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Fantastic story, soundtrack, and characters that will tug at your heartstrings. Easily one of my favorite indie games. It is a short game, but last as long as it needs to to tell a conniving story. If you want to extend your play time the short free holiday specials are also worth playing as it dose expand the lore of the game. As well the follow up game looks promising but only time will tell. The only problems I have with it are incredibly superficial. As a artist I do see some miner flaws in the hand drawn images as its missing some basic fundamentals. Such as composition, detail separation, anatomy, perceptive, line weight, and so on. but it almost docent matter, As it still works fine for telling the story at hand. and the average viewer probably wont notice the minute details. (and if you follow the creators it also shows just how much the artists has grown since this game was made, so it takes your on a artistic journey though there games as well as a literal one)

Posted: January 14, 2014
												AT A GLANCE: A gem among the visual novels.[A more detailed review follows below.]Game Name: To The MoonOriginal Release Date: November 1, 2011My Overall Rating: AEstimated Playtime: 2.5 to 4 hours (Campaign)Multiplayer: NoneRecommended To: Visual novels lovers and those players looking for movie-like game with a great story or a good weekend pass-time game, and casual players.REVIEWTo The Moon is a example of a good indie VN game, with some RPG-ish mixed with it. It feels truly like a gem among so many VN out there. It is not a true game,yet if offers a story-rich, which you may get immersed in itself. Well, that's might sound like a bit of exaggeration, however this game is a really polished visual novel with a great story and soundtrack. Great atmosphere and aesthetic.It has got a great emotional aspect. The game blends realism greatly with human psychology. Sometimes, there are times when we humans try to do something unique even at the last stage of their life. And this game amazingly engages you in the story that you might not even remember trying to check out the menus of the game but keep on playing. It is deeply engaging that charms you to complete it in a single playthrough. I also played it non-stop for about four hours and didn't even realize there was a power cut. This is a great experience-giving game and will surely make your weekend good after all your hard work or study.Regarding the gameplay, being a visual novel, it includes a point-and-click like mechanics and keyboard support. You can play as two characters (scientists, to be precise) on a quest of fulfilling a... (Well, let's not spoil the game, shall we?) I say that you play it at least once by yourself. In summary, a great VN, which I truly recommend for any VN lovers and those looking for a short game with rich story,pleasing soundtrack,and aesthetic game contents.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												Seriously one of the best games I have ever played. A very simple game with very simple mechanics/puzzles that is all about telling a story that will bring tears to your eyes (I will freely admit that this story made me cry).

Posted: March 21, 2014
												It is very infrequent that I play a game that I consider truly beautiful, and nothing less than genuinely lovely. To the Moon is entirely story based, and the only gameplay to be found is in the form of tile puzzles and a later (apalling) action sequence. Yet the story involved is so heart-wrenchingly engaging that I found myself playing through the 4/5 hour process in merely a few hours. Along with a few intelligent twists, this story reaches a satisfying conclusion. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with To the Moon, despite the terrible controls, and would recommend it to anybody with a heart.

Posted: January 15, 2014
												This game aims right for the feels. Make no mistake, this is one of those games that's on the level of "interactive story" or "art game", but I think it is well worth a play. If you like love stories, this is for you, and I found it especially heartstring-pulling because of how much I can relate to River. This is a sweet story and you'll love every minute of it.Edit: Four months later and noticing this title in my game list still makes me a little teary-eyed. The soundtrack combined with the story and lovely gameplay has made this one of my favourite games of all time. I cried so hard at the end because it was so very lovely. Still even now I think about this game whever I see or hear about a lighthouse.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												I'm going to be completely honest. I installed and played the game only for the trading cards...And I was going to leave it as soon as I got all the cards I needed...However, things...didn't go as planned.The game is simple beautiful. I'm a fan of pixel graphics thus I fell in love with the design. Although the game is almost purely story driven, it kept me hooked (which rarely happens with these kind of games).The story begins with all kinds of weird doohikeys. Secrets in the basement. Attatchment to a lighthouse.And the strange wish to visit the moon...As the story unravels, things start to make sense. And just when you think you've got everything sorted out...it hits you. The mandatory "right in the feels" scene. Even though I rarely cry, I was weeping during this game. I do not remember the last time I cried this much during a 4 hour period. The fun fair scene and the ending were the two main manhood killers. And the soundtrack didn't help either. Simply magnificent. On the lighter side, I had quite a few good laughs during the game. I especially enjoyed references made through out the game, even though that gets thrown around too much nowadays.A magnificent game. 10/10, bring tissues.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												It is hard to give a review on a game like this. I cant give it a 10 based on graphics or sound or any usual concept that we measure games on but in this particular case and this particular game, If you dont like click and point games, or games with outdated graphics, outdated music, and a story that has very chick flick like elements than you shouldnt like it just like i should not have liked it but I absolutlely love this game. it goes against everthing that i ever enjoyed as a gamer. It is almost as if this is not a game but a visual novel that is extremely interactive. Puzzles can be tedious but with all of the plot twists and the great easter eggs that eventually lead to a dramatic larger than life ending. This game has a ending that is more than just a resolution but a reminder of what it means to be human. I never have played an indie game that i felt could contend with a big time game but this has to be on of my favorite games of all time. i give it a 10 because anything else would make you question if you should give this game a try.

Posted: March 20, 2014
												So this game was one that I had boughten when it was on sale a while back and I had almost no idea what I was getting into other than what the video showed but oh was this game so much more than anything I had expected. This game has one of the most beautiful stories I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing and I would absolutely play it again and again. This game is patience and anticipation, loss and gain, grief and happiness all in one. The simplistic way you move through the game allows for you to focus on the story and the puzzles are simple but placed perfectly to give your brain a break from all the emotions. If anyone is looking for a game where they can interact and be pulled into one of the most terrific stories of love and dreams, it would be through this game. It's a very linear game but going into it with no expectations is what should be done because having too many options in this game would ruin the story. There might be more to say here but all I keep thinking is 'wow, that was amazing." Sometimes we just need stories like this.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												An amazing, touching story for anyone, including non-gamers, to play. While the "gameplay" isn't the its best feature, the story and music are the shining treasures of this game. The story will definitely touch you in some way. Don't watch the ending first. This is one of those games where you just have to watch it from the beginning as everything has meaning to it. Watch a Let's Play if you have to, but I recommend supporting FreeBird Games by purchasing it yourself. Especially since one of the artists for the game is currently hospitalized. The music is one of my favorite parts of the game. I've learned most of the songs from this game on the piano. Definitely get the soundtrack with it. It hits the right mix between calm yet emotional. Just play the game before you listen to the soundtrack. It will make the music more memorable. All in all, definitely get this game for the story. If you like Mother 3 or sad stories, this is the game for you.

Posted: January 7, 2014
												A recommendation isn't enough for this game, simply put, it's a masterpiece. It deals with the subjects of death, tragedy, buried memories and so much more and although some of the twists may be pretty easy to guess, the way in which the story is told ensures that this does not lower the quality of the game whatsoever. Easily the greatest element to this game though, is the way it creates emotion in the player. The humour is top notch, when something good happens for someone you are genuinely happy for them and most of all, this game is SAD. I have seen many different reactions about the ending, personally, I think it's tragic, but it works and it brings the game to a fantastic close.Presentation wise, the first thign you may notice is that the graphics are very similar to the style of the SNES (in my opinion, it is particularly reminiscent of Chrono Trigger). This works perfectly and after playing through the game, I can't imagine it with another art style. However, despite all this, the one thing I haven't mentioned yet is easily the games greatest asset, which is saying a lot considering everything else. The music in this game is just... stunning, probably my favourite soundtrack of all time, or at least in the last few years. A great mixture of instruments, mainly piano, adds to the games already fantastic environment, and each song sets the tone amazingly and is absolutely perfect for what is happening in the game. Should you buy it? If you're a fan of heavily story based games, then yes and if not, give it a go anyway. 10/10

Posted: May 11, 2016
												This game is hard to review because it has so many faults and yet I still recommend it. The controls are beyond awful, the "puzzle" and "action" sequences are worse than amateur attempts you'd find on Newgrounds and in fact detract from the game itself, and worst of all: the "humor" that is non-stop present in the game is so idiotic and childish that it undermines the rest of the experience. The "humor" is essentially the dumbest smartass comments I've ever heard spewed so nonstop I felt like I couldn't go a minute without it being displayed. I laughed maybe once and I don't believe humor in a story based game that is about something so deep and serious is necessarily a bad thing, just done very poorly in this case. Also as a composer, I feel the music is very tacky "pop art" and poorly composed, as well as repeated nonstop (but I suppose that goes well with the theme of the game) and overall it also undermines the story for me.However, I feel that this game still has a very deep and interesting story that brought about a lot of emotions in me and I feel the overall writing was superb. It's cheesy in all of the right ways...by actually delving into serious real life issues and being bitterwsweet about it the entire time. And on top of that, it personally struck home with me both because of the story and because of the surrealistic aspect of the entire game. I consider all video games as art but for the sake of categorization, I would call this an "art game" in the sense that it clearly tries to be more than simple mindless entertainment.I recommend it to anybody but it should probably be played in short stints to avoid frustration at the issues mentioned.

Posted: October 25, 2015
												To be clear, only the first couple hours at most have anything resembling 'gameplay', with a 'search the level for things' puzzle and 'flip tiles' puzzle coming up every 5 to 10 minutes. After those first two hours, the remainder of the experience is all one long 16-bit era RPG-like cutscene.That said, I still enjoyed the story that unfolded. It touched on a few issues I hadn't seen handled in a video game before and the central premise (as described in the flavor text on the store) is an interesting concept that I could really imagine being turned either into a series of stories or a movie someday. But probably the most compelling aspect is how the narrative explores what a profound difference one moment in time can make on the trajectory our lives take. This is always interesting food for thought to contemplate for ourselves, so being reminded of that via this game was nice.The soundtrack is soothing and fits the game perfectly.The controls are the only thing that had me grimacing from time to time. There are a lot of path blockers that serve no actual purpose and make navigating around them a bit tedious either by keyboard or mouse controls. This wasn't a major detraction, but was mildly annoying from time to time.Overall, quality experience, took about 3.5'ish hours. If you enjoy '90% story/10% game' style games as I do, you should appreciate this one.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												An absolute masterpiece of a game. As you start it's like a mystery trying to figure out how all the pieces line up and when you start to figure it out everything starts to line up and come together for a fantastic (and emotional) experience. The soundtrack is absolutely stellar and quite literally, out of this world if you will. If you like an amazing story with amazing music you will not want to miss this gem of a game.

Posted: August 25, 2013
												When I read about this game, I thought it would be some kind of anime story with some memory exploring. Oh boy was I in for a surprise, I had never expected how much this game would affect me.There aren't enough words to describe how amazing this game is. The story is excellently weaved together. The characters all have very distinct personalities, even the two scientists have such distinct personalities you can clearly tell how they would react in situations. (The male one being the sillier and quirky) Exploring the old mans past makes you relate to him as if he was a person you knew in your real life. It's so easy to like him, but also relate to all of his struggles. There are many moments of sadness where my heart aches for him.The most striking character for me is potrayed with a disability in the autism spectrum. Usually when you see these kind of characters, they are either stereotypically good at math (autism) or they are self-absorbed ragers (aspberger). As I have high functioning autism myself (basically between autism and asperger), there are so many ways I could relate to this character and her perception of what love and friendship is. People in the game are also portrayed in the way they view her, because she really stands out as strange and emotionally distant. But the main character, Johnny, just likes her so much he won't let the things get in the way. He spends enough time with her to understand how she works, instead of others that look at her and think she just refuses to be civilized. Excellent portrayal of this disability.The soundtrack is fantastic. Especially "Moonwhisher". I have spent hours and hours crying to this lovely track. It's so incredibly touching. There are few wordless tracks which moves me in the way this one does. It really sets the mood when you are watching a sad scene in the game. Many of the other musical pieces are also great. One of them, "For River", even has a background story in the game as to why the musical piece is so simple at the beginning with just two notes. So when you follow the story to the end, then hear the musical piece in the various adaptions, it really fills my eyes with tears. I liked the graphic of the game. The old school pixels were all very well done and the areas portrayed all feels like they spent a good time to make sure it wouldn't be repeatetive. Nowhere do I remember feeling myself lost. Each area has their own uniqueness, so it is easy to find your way.I love the way the story is told. It literally starts you near the end, then you tread your way back slowly until you reach the start of Johnnys life, then it is like climbing back up again to find parts that were skipped over during the transition there. It doesn't just end there though, the game offers a final piece to the puzzle with a great plot twist. The game starts out by making it seem the issue is easily solved, then it builds up and you realize there is so much more to the game.The only possible complaint I could make about the game is a mini-game you play each time you transistion in a memory. I just thought it was distracting and not fun. It's over quite fast though.This is a game I would recommend to everyone to play at least once. Especially if you enjoy deep, emotional stories that truly explores the personalities and life of the characters.

Posted: July 30, 2014
												Man, this game...I very rarely write reviews for anything, let alone Steam games. If I wrote a review for every steam game I owned, I'd be here a long time.I originally fired up this game because it has steam cards. I don't even remember how I ended up with a copy. Probably from a Humble Bundle. Regardless, the steam cards enticed me to open it up. With every game I've ever opened for steam cards, I gave it a spin, and I am happy I did.Initial thoughts were ho hum as it took a little bit to get into the game. It was also very focused on trying to get me to use the mouse. Let me say right now to anyone thinking of playing this game, only use the mouse to try and identify items to click on. Move around with the keyboard, it'll make things much easier on you.Initial thoughts aside, I trudged on as I watched my steam inventory tick up on the cards collected. However, as I got deeper and deeper into the game, I found myself fascinated as story events started to reveal. There was quirky humor, shocking reveals, and sad moments. However, the story wraps itself up well and I found myself amazed as I looked back, picking up on small things that happened with no reasoning until things revealed through the ending.The story flows together well. The soundtrack fits in perfectly. The characters have enough depth to keep them interesting, without being overbearing. Overall, this game is fantastic and I recommend it to anyone. I'm not normally an artsy fartsy story telling game kinda guy, but this one was fantastic. Just get ready for tears, because holy crap that reveal.Now if you excuse me, I need to go play 12 hours of Street Fighter to make up for the emotional carnage this game has played on me. :D

												Pros:-It's an excellent narrative driven indie adventure. -Well done soundtrack that seems to take its inspirations from classic slice-of-life animes.-Will make you cryCons:-There were some real pork tenderloin moments that felt a tad too cliché for my liking, however; these moments had minimal negative impact on the effectiveness of the overall story because the story as a whole was so well realized.-Low resolution and a lack of graphical options conspire to keep this game from unlocking its full visual potential.-Will make you cry.I recommend completing it in a single sitting.-Jack

Posted: July 11, 2014
												There is so much to say about this game. I absolutely do not want to ruin it however, so I will cut this down and keep it short. I am going to rate it for its seperate quilities and come up with an overall rating. Music: 10/10Graphics and art: 9/10Storyline: 10/10Overall gameplay: 7/10OVERALL GAME EXPERIENCE: 10/10.This game successfully had every aspect of a good story. It was incredibly sad at parts, yet was able to throw in humor ever so often. It made me connect with each character, and feel attached to them. They all reacted to problems the same way I feel I would, and probably most of you would. The makes of this game most likely did this on purpose to humanize the player and make them feel the emotions the characters are feeling. I would abosutely reccomend this game to anyone. For $ 10.00 you can have an incredibly interactive story, that will truely drive the experience. The only problem I ever thought of in regards to To The Moon, was the gameplay wasnt very full. Manly, the entire game is you collecting mementos to go to a new memory. However, if you feel a good story is worth it, then BUY THIS GAME NOW. I LOVED PLAYING EVERY MINUTE OF IT.

Posted: November 29, 2014
												Let's get the bad out of the way first.- Graphics have major issues.  At least it did for me.  I had two modes of playing.  Windowed mode (hit alt-enter) which means I was playing in a tiny window, or full screen mode, which on my screen for some reason meant a lot of the things were cut off.  Put it this way when I went to the load screen instead of "Load File" it said "ile"  I had to play it in windowed mode.- Graphics were also not very good considering how low the resolution was.- Engine / path finding was a bit clunky.- Not much "game" in it.  There's a few minor puzzles.  That's about it.  - The dialogue felt a bit out of character sometimes.Now that doesn't sound like a very glowing review but if you'd notice there's a big "Yes" recommendation.  Why is that?  Well the music was quite beautiful (though it did get slightly repetitive at times).  But the most important thing...The story is beautiful.   It's almost ridiculously beautiful.  It's moving, sad, touching, and happy all in one package.  And in all honesty, if a good director got his hand on this story, I can see one heck of a great movie.  I mean you have to realize they did all of this with no voice acting and graphics that belong to the NES era (we're talking early 90s!).Highly recommended for people who enjoy melancholic stories (it starts a bit slow of course).  If you're into graphics or action or tough puzzles, this isn't the game for you though.

Posted: November 29, 2016
												To the Moon is one of the best story telling games out there. You can easily finish the whole game in one sitting and it really makes you think about deep stuff. The soundtrack in this game is also one of the most memorable soundtracks I've ever heard.However the game has a very linear plot and thus a lower replay value due to the limited choices you can make. Of course  you can easily play it again after a while and it will feel as good and heartbreaking as in the first playthrough. It might not suit you if you're very impatient because the game is really slow. But hey, it's meant to tell you a story and it really gives you one of the best stories out there.10/10

Posted: December 28, 2016
												I first came across this game when I was younger, when I watched PewDiePie play it four years ago. I was 14 and completely moved, marathoning the entire series in one night, until about four in the morning. The song that Johnny plays stuck with me for days afterwards, along with the heartbreakingly bittersweet story.Then, a few years later when I was 16, I remembered the game fondly but I had mostly forgotten about it when I saw in my subscribtion feed that Markiplier had begun playing it, and I was overwhelmed with emotion. I was older, and some things that happened in the game had begun to happen in my life, and the game went from "completely moving" to "soul crushing masterpiece". My brother and I watched the game together, and despite only being in piano lessons for about three months, I began learning the songs.Now, at 18, "For River" is a song that my entire family asks me to play at every gathering, especially my Nana, whose husband is very ill. I wish I could tell her what that song means, because everyone, especially her, should know. This game is brilliant. It's heartbreaking, bittersweet, and emotional. It manages to crush your soul while also providing light comic relief, until you're left sobbing with a smile, gasping for air through your laugh-crying while you text your loved ones that you love them.

Posted: March 21, 2014
												It is very infrequent that I play a game that I consider truly beautiful, and nothing less than genuinely lovely. To the Moon is entirely story based, and the only gameplay to be found is in the form of tile puzzles and a later (apalling) action sequence. Yet the story involved is so heart-wrenchingly engaging that I found myself playing through the 4/5 hour process in merely a few hours. Along with a few intelligent twists, this story reaches a satisfying conclusion. I thoroughly enjoyed my time with To the Moon, despite the terrible controls, and would recommend it to anybody with a heart.

												Gorgeous piece of art. This is not just a game but an experience. Its meant to make you feel. Even though its short but its dense. There wasnt a single moment where  I felt as if I was getting bored or anything. Throughout, the story felt dynamic and the plot was very original. Being a completely story driven game, the little gameplay and puzzles it had were good enough to make you feel as if you were doing something but they never came in the way of the story or its interesting plot twists. The entire game is well balanaced and the writing and the plot itself is very original and doesnt feel like cliched at all. And the music is amazing too.I would definitely recommend it. Its one of those games that you play and you never forget. The experience lives with you.

Posted: March 30, 2015
												What wonderful storytelling! The less you know about this game beforehand, the better the experience will be. When you start playing, make sure you have a few hours to yourself; To The Moon is best consumed all at once or only in few sessions.I'm glad that To The Moon was brought to my attention by someone who sang its' praises but spoilt nothing, but you don't always have the trusted recommendation of a person close to you. In that case, how do you know it's for you and worth buying? What is so special about To The Moon and why does it make everyone cry? If you're reading the reviews for an answer to those questions, something about the way the game looks or what you've heard of it creates doubt.If a sob story within an indie game that looks like an old-school JRPG doesn't sound like your usual thing, or conversely if you're thinking that you've seen this already because it's "just another artsy indie game", then that's even more of a reason to buy To The Moon. It goes beyond the boundaries of game genres and will expand your idea of how a story can be told. It's not unique in the sense that it's the first or only one of it's kind doing that, but To The Moon is so original in content and perfectly fitting in its delivery that you're in for an unfogettable experience.

Posted: May 11, 2016
												This game is hard to review because it has so many faults and yet I still recommend it. The controls are beyond awful, the "puzzle" and "action" sequences are worse than amateur attempts you'd find on Newgrounds and in fact detract from the game itself, and worst of all: the "humor" that is non-stop present in the game is so idiotic and childish that it undermines the rest of the experience. The "humor" is essentially the dumbest smartass comments I've ever heard spewed so nonstop I felt like I couldn't go a minute without it being displayed. I laughed maybe once and I don't believe humor in a story based game that is about something so deep and serious is necessarily a bad thing, just done very poorly in this case. Also as a composer, I feel the music is very tacky "pop art" and poorly composed, as well as repeated nonstop (but I suppose that goes well with the theme of the game) and overall it also undermines the story for me.However, I feel that this game still has a very deep and interesting story that brought about a lot of emotions in me and I feel the overall writing was superb. It's cheesy in all of the right ways...by actually delving into serious real life issues and being bitterwsweet about it the entire time. And on top of that, it personally struck home with me both because of the story and because of the surrealistic aspect of the entire game. I consider all video games as art but for the sake of categorization, I would call this an "art game" in the sense that it clearly tries to be more than simple mindless entertainment.I recommend it to anybody but it should probably be played in short stints to avoid frustration at the issues mentioned.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I know it's already been said over and over again, but I'll say it again: To The Moon is a fantastic achievement in storytelling that weaves an intricate and fully engrossing tale through the medium of games. The pixel graphics are charming and suit the game well. The music is beautiful and perfectly timed, tugging at the player's emotions at just the right moments. While there are a few kinks here and there, the story is so entrancing that these can be easily overlooked.Actual gameplay is pretty minimal, with players simply exploring areas to progress the story and solving some easy puzzles, but it's an enjoyable experience nonetheless, and despite having a linear story, the game never feels too confined. I very quickly became invested in the plot and wanted to delve deeper and discover the answers to all the questions each new progression raised. To The Moon is a story that deals with a great range of emotions and takes the player along for the ride to experience the ups and downs of life. If you're the sensitive type, be prepared for tears. I cried like a baby.In short: I'd recommend this game to anyone and everyone who can appreciate a good story, regardless of what your actual taste in video-games is. You might be surprised.

Posted: June 17, 2014
												One of the best RPG Maker games I've ever played, with some heavily emotional moments. If you're looking for an actual RPG, you won't find one here.This is a story driven point-and-click mystery game, with great music, and with some creative usages of the scripting tools that the software offers. Well worth the money, for an average of 4 hours to complete the game. Shame that it didn't offer multiple endings, especially given that the game keeps track of your overall score for the minigames, but doesn't end up doing anything with that. An extra scene at the end, as a reward for having a good record, would've been nice. Maybe that's something to consider for the upcoming sequel?10/10, right in the feels.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												I always liked pros and cons lists for reviews.  Here's my attempt at a good one (sorry about the crappy formatting, I can't figure out how to clean it up):Pros: Tear-jerker.  I cried.  Most people that played this cried.  Those that say they didn't cry, probably cried. Creative story telling!  It's such a well-written game.  Because of it's unorthodox approach it keeps you interested throughout the game.  Simple game mechanics.  It's practically a point&click adventure.  Retro graphics pull you in.  The game is simple but looks beautiful.  A lot of love went into piecing this game together.  Short.  You can finish this game in one sitting.   The music is fantastic.  This game has such a great soundtrack.  Some games have good background music, then there's those rare gems where the background music might as well be another character in the game since it plays such a huge role.Cons: Clunky unresponsive controls at times.  I got stuck a lot. Humor just didn't work with me.  The game presents such a beautiful premise about love and regret so the humor at times felt out of place and awkward.  Specifically the male doctor.  I feel like the game would've been much better without Dr. Watts.  Gameplay, because it's so simple, feels repetitive by the time you reach the final act.   I don't really think this is a con, but I can't list it as a pro:  The game isn't suited for younger audiences.  I feel like quality of story-telling this game provides would be wasted on a younger person who can't relate to the themes in this game.   The ending of the game will leave you with questions and you will want to know more about the characters, and realizing they're not real people will make you sad.All-in-all, this game was a treat.  It got such good reviews and I'm glad I finally tried it.  Definitely recommend it.

Posted: February 11, 2016
												I would certainly consider this more of an interactive movie than a game, but with that being said- I'm incredibly impressed! The amount of feel and sentiment the authors were able to evoke so seamlessly shows a lot of raw talent. Also, the story progressed quite naturally. It has all the proper elements to keep you interested and hooked. You really want to find out what's going to happen next! This is really refreshing because so many times the games I play with dynamic, super-interesting plots don't make a profound impact on me due to a lack of flow and direction. Call me crazy, but I feel a lot of time games with a super huge production team can give you that copy and paste feel. I guess having so much different influence under improper guidance makes it difficult to craft something coherent. Anyways, this game isn't like that at all. It's touching, beautiful, and wonderful. I wouldn't exactly recommend this romantic epic to all of my friends since it's more in the touchy-feely realm of things, but to those who are more intune with their emotional side, this game (movie) is a must play (watch). ;) <3

Posted: March 31, 2014
												To the Moon is a fantastic game. It's a story about two people named Dr. Rosaline and Dr. Watts and they give people a last chance to live out their final wish through their memories and make them think they actually did it. The patient they are currently working on is a man named Johnny whose final wish is to go to the moon. He doesn't remember why, but that's all he wants to do.Simple right? No, his story goes far back to his childhood and you must travel through the years of his life, find out why he wants to go to the moon, and give it to him.The story is fantastic, the soundtrack is great too, and characters are likable and memorable. It is also a game that will tug at your heart strings as you journey along. It is a very emotional game, and I bet you will be tearing up at the end at how good it is.Pick it up now and play through a fantastic experience. Also get the soundtrack too because it too is also great.

Posted: May 20, 2014
												Very emotional and fascinating adventure about two professors who attempt to fulfill the last wish/dream (...going to the moon) of an elderly man on his deathbed and enter the memories of his life time to manipulate it.Great storyline, but feels more like reading a book than playing a game.Good dialogues with cheap jokes ^.^Satisfying Ending =DBased on the "RPG-Maker"-Engine.Unfortunately it has a very short playtime !

Posted: October 3, 2015
												To The Moon is probably one of the best games I have ever played. This game manages to hook the player in right from the very start with its lovable characters and amazing story. Its probably one of the only games I admired in terms of its music as it fits perfectley well with the game, and just sounds damn beautiful. For those of you who are wondering, although the game was made by RPG Maker VX, this game isn't an RPG. There is one scene where it is turned based, but this is a mere joke. The game itself is an adventure point and click game. I reccommend anyone who loves a good story and great music to get this game immedietley. There isn't much more beyond I can say at this point without ruining the story.I also advice anyone who got this to get A Bird Story.

Posted: November 3, 2014
												To the Moon is a visual novel rather than a game. I've heard the term RPG used to describe it but that would be incorrect as there are no unique mechanics, form of progression or indeed any aspect of your characters to progress. What might be considered puzzles or game play is nothing more than the game stubbornly folding its arms and barring you from the next chapter until you have collected all five macguffins in each tiny area and a breif bullet hell section at the very end. However, in spite of what I just said, I am recommending To the Moon because it tells an amazing story that kept me interested form beginning to end. As a game designed soley to tell a story it does so in spades with an intrigueing plot, relatable characters, and an ending I didn't see comming. I'm looking foreword to A Bird Story.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Despite being made in RPG Maker To the Moon stands among Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons as one of the most emotional thought provoking games ever released.The premise is simple; Fulfill a dying man's wish to go to the moon. The journey is anything but. Amazingly written characters, gorgeous art (both drawn and in-engine), one of the best soundtracks you will ever hear in any game, and a compelling funny at times, sad at others, and ultimately overall stellar story make To the Moon an experience like no other. The game starts off a bit slow but quickly engages the player. I heartily recommend this master piece for anyone looking for a deeper experience than what today's triple A gaming industry has to offer.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												Prior to experiencing this literary masterpiece, I've read countless reviews of To the Moon and often wondered if it was overrated. I'm glad I was proven wrong after finally being able to finish it.To the Moon is a visual novel through and through. There's very little in the way of standard gaming, save for a few puzzles. Don't let this deter you though; To the Moon is a fantastic, emotional trip graced by smart (and often humorous) writing, coupled with a sweeping soundtrack. The whole experience is a bit short - I delayed a few sections, and I've only managed to put in 4 hours. But that's part of the charm - To the Moon is excellently paced that those 4 sweet hours feel natural and rewarding already.Play alone, specially during the half and towards the end - if you don't like people to see you get teary eyed over a "game". Most of all, prepare for an unparalleled emotional journey.

Posted: April 5, 2016
												 From the storyline to every detail of graphics of this game, I would say that this is one heck of a game! A great game does not have to have amazing graphics; FreeBird Games proved it through this game. Indeed I understand how this game got of awards for its story, and no wonder there are so many people who are recommending this game to others. This game is a real tear-jerker – but in a good way. It made me reflect about all my wishes and how most of it were forgotten when I got older. Not only was the story well written, but also the music throughout the game was really good. I would say that one of the most memorable items of this game is probably its music because it has this strong emotional content to it that makes the people fall in love with it even though they were not able to play the game. I'm going to be honest now, I thought that this game will be boring at first even though it had an overwhelmingly positive review in Steam, but when I actually played it, I just ate all the words I said. Overall, I would give this game a 10 out of 10. If someone really wants to know why I gave it a perfect score, well, try playing the game. #BestGameEver

Posted: September 9, 2015
VirtuesTo the moon is a story about the life a couple has shared and all the friends, love, hardships and ceremony that entails. This game has it's sights set on your feels and you may find a few things quite touching.The gameplay is generally watching canned bits of plot, proceeding to explore the area to find 5 colored orbs, & locating a memento. Once you've done this and located the memento you break a barrier around the memento with the orbs and finish things off with a tile flipping puzzle. You then move on to the next area and repeat the whole process.I enjoy the humor in this game quite a bit. It's a good mix of cornball, referential, and just plain odd.PitfallsThe game doesn't seem to support multiple resolutions or even the steam overlay. Screenshots don't work well because of this. I'm used to taking an excess of screenshots during gameplay and constantly found myself missing the ability to do so easily.I experienced an odd glitch during the course of my playthrough in which I became capable of walking on any surface of the current screen. I was forced to reload due to inability to interact with anything at that point though.The controls feel a bit loose an imprecise on a wireless xbox 360 controller. The D-pad cannot even be used in an attempt to counter this frustration. You are limited to the left analog joystick. It's necessary to utilize the mouse for the tile flipping puzzle sections. Near the end of the game there's some different gameplay mechanics that I just switched entirely to keyboard in order to better aid in progression.Spoilerific ShortI felt the game could've ended appropriately shortly after finding out about the death of the twin brother. Instead the game continues trying to right wrongs Quantum Leap style inside the dying seniors brain. This makes sense only in the context of the altruistic attitude of Dr. Rosalene. I don't feel it actually helps the story. Instead of just discovering what actually had happened in the past and bringing it to the surface to be faced she retcon's the past and tries to remedy it with a pretty bow of modified memories. This left the ending feeling kind of lame and predictable to me.All told I rather enjoyed this game despite any issues I had with it.70\100

Posted: March 6, 2016
												To the Moon is the simplest, shortest, most emotional game that I've ever played. The only other game close to meeting that description is Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons, but that game requires more effort than To the Moon, and therefore does not get "simplest." Nothing else that I've played has really gotten near these attributes.I went into this game expecting it to be highly overrated. My main reasoning for that is because I have played many RPG Maker games before, years and years back, and never found any to be really great. Therefore, I was extremely surprised to hear this RPG Maker game getting so much praise almost universally, for so long.And surprise hit me again when I realized how much I agreed with everybody else. To the Moon has very great artistic style for something made in RPG Maker. The maps are simple but very well-made, with lots of thought in organization and layout. The characters actually have nice movements to fit their actions. The animations and designs work with the premise of the story - all are done well.The story itself, so unexpectedly emotional. Learning about the old man in reverse time is, theoretically, a simple idea in such a sci-fi / futuristic type of story, but it was so efficiently planned. There are so much questions that pop up along the way, and as you slowly get your answers, they just make you feel more attached to the story, to the characters, despite only being invested in them for a few hours. Every little 16-bit person seems like they are real. They seem more natural than many people I've ever seen in such a simple video game.The music and sound fit in so well with all of their scenes, and only serve to help the emotions you get as you play. It all made me smile, laugh, get angry, want to cry - you name it. The ending of the game and the song played there... I think many people have gone to listen to the soundtrack long after playing this game, and I understand why.As I said, the game is the "simplest" - and really, it is a story. You have control of the characters; you explore to learn; you solve puzzles to continue. But the game does not require much effort to keep moving, and in many ways, it makes sense that this choice was made. The story would not be so touching if you had to spend a lot of time trying to get past difficult puzzles, as you would only get more angry at the game itself.I definitely wish that I could experience this game again, without knowing anything about it. But of course that is not possible... unless Neil and Eva were to help me out.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												I'm not used to do that kind of things and actually it's the first time that i do a true evaluation for a game but, on this one, clearly it deserve it.To let you know, i'm not that you can say a "big fan" of retro or pixel games but, clearly developpers and game designers have done an amazing job, graphics are really well done. I often say that "pixel games are hurting my eyes" but this one has been made a sort that my eyes were perfectly fine with it and i can ensure you that it is something pretty difficult to do.Now, the soundtrack... I'm a guy that love when there is some good soundtrack on a game and actually, even tho it could have been repetitiv, it fit well with the game + actually there is some others songs, like the one at the end when they're with "river's case" (to not spoil) is just wonderfull ! Clearly sound designers have done a great job too.Now, the best part : the story. Clearly on this one, people can't argue, it has been well made too. Main story is interesting with every important settings needed for a good story. Main characters are interesting and quite appealing, there is also some background that is nice, even tho i'm pretty sure we could have like some more but on the actual state it's quite nice and probably enough.  There is comedy, some drama, some suspens, etc... i would say that's a complete story with every good components that we like (and yeah, i had a tear at the edge of my right eye at some moment while laughing at other ones).I'd like to congratz the "french traduction team" because it has been majestic, even some "triple-A" games has worse trad that you have.Like, seriously, we can feel that every person that worked on this masterpiece has put into the game their soul and not takings shortcuts. To do a great game, that's what you need to do.Actually, i can't only be positiv or it wouldn't be a real evaluation... I only have one issue with this game, is about the "gaming" itself. I don't know if it's because of the 2.5D but some textures have bad hitbox and so characters have often some difficulties to use some specific objetcs when you directly click on the item to let them go and use it, you have to manually put them right in front + even worst, sometimes even if you're in front of it, the characters can't use it, because some part of the "hitbox" is not working...But don't worry, it is not that much of a problem because the rest of the game really make this small cloud something that don't stay in mind ; but yeah, because of that i can't say that i gave a 10 to this game, but clearly i give it a 9.5/10.To everyone that wonder if it's a good game, yep it is ! Clearly it's worth to buy it but not buying it when there is some huge discount on him, it's probably criminal (i'm joking, but yeah, i don't like to do some "free advertizing" but this game really deserve at least your attention).

Posted: May 14, 2016
												I bought this game on a sheer whim, looking for something new to add to my library and hoping to have some fun. I never expected to fall in love with it. From the first 20 minutes in, I was hooked. As implausible as the plotline sounds on paper, the game developers and writers have done an immaculate job of sucking you into this world where it's not only totally possible, it's commonplace.  It's cleverly written, intelligent, and the characters feel like real people.  There are so many gems in the dialogue that made me laugh out loud -- especially a particular TV show reference early on. And I can't say enough good things about the soundtrack. It is so, so lovely.While the gameplay itself is very simplistic and easy, the story is what will keep you rooted to your seat. The pacing is perfect -- moments of sadness, elation, and well-timed comedic relief are placed very well throughout the whole story. And that ending...well, I wouldn't dream of spoiling it, but just hang onto yer butts, kids. And bring the tissues.

Posted: January 1, 2016
												"To the Moon" is a simple story based and enigmatic RPG that will:- Surprise you;- Keep you glued to the monitor screen just to see and understand how the plot develops;- Break your heart and leave you on the corner of the room crying while shiverring.Highly recommended as the product is innovative in its mini-games and way of proceeding, not to mention all the awesome puns and humour in the dialogues combined with strong sarcasm and irony of the two main characters, which will amuse you for sure.Perhaps "To the Moon" might not be very long, as a matter of fact you should be able to complete the game in a maximum of 4 hours if you are going to check carefully every single dialogue and click on all the things possible and imaginable to find more information, but it is pretty much understandable that this game made success for a reason, being the amazing experience this emotional story can actually provide you, making every cent you spent on the product acceptable, as myself can assure you that you are not going to forget it any time sooner either.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												The story is beautiful and unique. The art style, well, it is a pixel art, which i'm not a big fan of, but it was fine and they've managed to even get some subtle emotions with this technique. The gameplay.. well, it just proves, that i won't be playing any of these "telltale" "games". You are hunting some pixels (and usually you don't even know what exactly, you have to just stumble upon it) and you solve a simple puzzle many times (though it doesn't matter how well or fast you do it). And you have a lot of dialogues without options. That's it. This is just some interactive stoty and as it is it deserves 10 out of 10, but as a game.. there is not much. Still giving it a positive review for all the work and a story and the music.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												One of my favourite stories told in any medium, and a brilliant bit of science fiction.Unlike 99.9% of games, I feel like the creator really had something he wanted to say, and unfortunately for him he wasn't involved with a big animation studio that could have turned this into a wonderful film. Instead, he made a game out of it, one with lacklustre gameplay and interactive elements that don't add anything to (and can sometimes halt) the wonderful narrative.

My main reasoning for that is because I have played many RPG Maker games before, years and years back, and never found any to be really great. Therefore, I was extremely surprised to hear this RPG Maker game getting so much praise almost universally, for so long.And surprise hit me again when I realized how much I agreed with everybody else. To the Moon has very great artistic style for something made in RPG Maker. The maps are simple but very well-made, with lots of thought in organization and layout. The characters actually have nice movements to fit their actions. The animations and designs work with the premise of the story - all are done well.The story itself, so unexpectedly emotional. Learning about the old man in reverse time is, theoretically, a simple idea in such a sci-fi / futuristic type of story, but it was so efficiently planned. There are so much questions that pop up along the way, and as you slowly get your answers, they just make you feel more attached to the story, to the characters, despite only being invested in them for a few hours. Every little 16-bit person seems like they are real. They seem more natural than many people I've ever seen in such a simple video game.The music and sound fit in so well with all of their scenes, and only serve to help the emotions you get as you play. It all made me smile, laugh, get angry, want to cry - you name it. The ending of the game and the song played there... I think many people have gone to listen to the soundtrack long after playing this game, and I understand why.As I said, the game is the "simplest" - and really, it is a story. You have control of the characters; you explore to learn; you solve puzzles to continue. But the game does not require much effort to keep moving, and in many ways, it makes sense that this choice was made. The story would not be so touching if you had to spend a lot of time trying to get past difficult puzzles, as you would only get more angry at the game itself.I definitely wish that I could experience this game again, without knowing anything about it. But of course that is not possible... unless Neil and Eva were to help me out.

Posted: December 25, 2014
												"To the Moon" is a beautiful game with great soundtrack and a beautiful story. Posted: January 1, 2016
												"To the Moon" is a simple story based and enigmatic RPG that will:- Surprise you;- Keep you glued to the monitor screen just to see and understand how the plot develops;- Break your heart and leave you on the corner of the room crying while shiverring.Highly recommended as the product is innovative in its mini-games and way of proceeding, not to mention all the awesome puns and humour in the dialogues combined with strong sarcasm and irony of the two main characters, which will amuse you for sure.Perhaps "To the Moon" might not be very long, as a matter of fact you should be able to complete the game in a maximum of 4 hours if you are going to check carefully every single dialogue and click on all the things possible and imaginable to find more information, but it is pretty much understandable that this game made success for a reason, being the amazing experience this emotional story can actually provide you, making every cent you spent on the product acceptable, as myself can assure you that you are not going to forget it any time sooner either.
